PETITION.TITLE: Child-Care Fee Relief Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the Senators in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the two-tiered child care fee relief scheme to be introduced by the Federal Government from 1 January 1992 will discriminate against families needing child care for "non-work" related" reasons.
That fees for these families will rise to such an extent that thousands of parents will not be able to afford access to child care services.

That as a result the viability of many child care centres and services will be significantly affected causing increases in fees for families who need access to child care services for "work related" reasons.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Senate should disallow the Federal Government's new two tiered child care fee relief scheme.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:
Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms
Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

TAB.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia our head of State and as in duty bound will ever pray. God save The Queen.

PETITION.TITLE: Non-custodial Access to Children
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Parliament will consider the plight of the father in the Family Court.

Fathers, according to the Laws of Australia, should have equal rights to their children, in both custody and access applications before the Family Court. Immediate amendments to the Family Law Act should be implemented for inclusion of parental rights as distinct from children's rights. It should be made possible for fathers to obtain a fair deal in the Family Court and be able to continue involvement in their siblings upbringing at all times throughout every stage of their children's development, thus being in the best interest of the children themselves, without incurring exorbitant legal costs and manipulated by many of the legal profession. Access Orders from the Family Court should be implemented without delay and at no cost to the non-custodial parent, thus eliminating denial of access. We humbly urge Parliament to direct the Family Court by way of immediate legislation to jealously guard visitation rights and become more liberal with them.

We further do humbly seek that a private members bill be introduced on an urgent basis to consider the plight of Mr. John Zabaneh, a fellow citizen and father of four young children whom he had no access to for nearly seven years despite that he had obtained unenforceable orders from the courts. John Zabaneh has been denied any input in his children's development and upbringing and has little or no knowledge of his children's progress and wellbeing.
As this matter is of human-rights nature, of paramount importance, it is specially requested that this petition be read to Parliament assembled in full.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: Whereas the people of East Timor are being subjected to oppressive control by a foreign power of quite different culture, imposed by a brutal military, as demonstrated by the recent massacre or massacres:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, ask the Senate to support by all means at its disposal, the suggestion of the Australian Council for Overseas Aid, that the United Nations instigate constructive discussions between representatives of East Timor, Indonesia and the United Nations itself.

DEBATE.TITLE: CORPORATIONS (UNLISTED PROPERTY TRUSTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1991CORPORATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 9 December, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is debating together the Corporations (Unlisted Property Trusts) Amendment Bill and the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). The first Bill's enactment will give breathing space to unlisted property trusts, allowing them to reach agreement with their depositors and thus preventing a run on their funds and ensuring their survival through the current recession. As such, the Bill is a welcome move.

PARA.TAB: One of the main features of the Bill is the introduction of a standard 12-month buy-back or redemption notice period for unlisted property trusts in existence as at 23 July 1991. Unit holders will be able to elect to vary that notice period where it is commercially viable to do so. However, the Australian Securities Commission will have the power to disallow the shortening of the notice period where it is satisfied that it would seriously threaten the liquidity of the trust or the management company.

Unit holders in financial hardship will also be able immediately to withdraw funds at a discount not exceeding 7.5 per cent. Buy-backs or redemptions are to be made at the price prevailing as at the date of payment as opposed to the date of giving notice or any other date which may be specified in the trust deed. Unit holders who have given to the trust a buy-back redemption notice will retain any entitlements to income or other benefits between the date of giving that notice and the date the funds are actually paid out. The Australian Securities Commission will be given the power to permit the trustee to refuse redemptions where they would have a materially adverse effect on the value of remaining units or otherwise adversely affect the interests of unit holders.

The Bill also contains some provisions applicable to all prescribed interest schemes which will enable trust deeds to be amended when the amendments are approved by 75 per cent of unit holders—that is, by value—voting at a meeting, provided that at least 25 per cent of unit holders, again by value, are eligible to vote. Another provision will also enable unit holders to requisition meetings for the purpose of giving directions to either the trustee or management company, provided that the directions are not inconsistent with the provisions of the trust deed.

Some matters will be left for future enactment in regulations, and in this bracket management companies and trusts will be required to maintain an adequate level of liquidity at all times. This is a long overdue provision, and a breach of the liquidity requirements will result in the calling of a meeting of investors to consider, among other things, the removal of the manager, the listing of the trust or the winding up of the trust. Borrowings by trusts will be limited to 20 per cent of the gross assets of the trust—again, a very worthwhile measure and a long overdue limit—and there will be a capital adequacy requirement for management companies.

As I said before, the Australian Democrats welcome this legislation and will support it. However, we note that this is regulation after the event. Unfortunately, the Government has engaged in a deregulation binge in the financial area which has allowed the practices that we have seen in the late 1980s to take over and to take root in our financial system, much to the detriment of our reputation as a nation in capital markets overseas—not to mention the losses that have been sustained by people who have deposited funds in non-bank financial institutions.

I now turn to the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, which is part of the continuing reform of corporate law. It follows a Bill which was brought in earlier last year to require companies to consolidate accounts and which also introduced provisions to strengthen the regulations against insider trading. This Bill today is essentially a machinery Bill. It provides for fixed five-day settlements in our securities markets to ensure that all share transactions are settled promptly. In order to achieve that, these transactions will be supported by expanded securities lending provisions and the national guarantee fund. The Securities Exchanges Guarantee Corporation Ltd is given powers to borrow funds and to levy borrowers.

Amendments in this Bill will also clarify the fact that the fundraising provisions applicable to prospectuses do not apply to the trading of securities on stock exchanges. Other amendments exclude offers related to capital raisings, which do not require a prospectus, from the provisions making it an offence to make false or misleading statements or to have material omissions in such offers. Other amendments in the Bill clarify the operation of various offences against civil liability for misstatements in, and omissions from, prospectuses.

There is also a set of provisions regarding registration numbers of companies and other bodies. The moratorium for the display of company numbers on public documents expires at the end of this year. The amendments contained in this Bill exempt cash register receipts produced by an electronic machine and advertising documents which are also not used to make an undertaking for a transaction. In addition, certain abbreviations of company numbers will be allowed in official documents. The Australian Securities Commission will be empowered to exempt companies operating in the transportation of persons or goods to bring these provisions into line with international practice.

The Democrats support this Bill, particularly as it is part of an overall program of corporations legislation designed to lift the standards that should be applied to the corporate sector in Australia. Clearly, we need more integrity and more control over what people are permitted to do to ensure that our standing in international markets is redeemed and that our own shareholders and depositors in Australia are protected.

Speaking of integrity, I must refer to some of the remarks that Senator Campbell made in this debate yesterday. He chose to use considerable invective against the Australian Democrats on the basis of our position on political advertising. It must hurt very much that from now on the rich parties will not be able to buy time. From now on the playing field is a little more level for people who obtain a certain number of votes. It shows the paucity of the Opposition's arguments if it has to resort to such language, to invective, when it has clearly run out of substantive arguments.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —All Australians will be aware that the real estate market, particularly in the commercial parts of our major cities, has collapsed. With that collapse has come about a need to restore confidence and stability in the unlisted property trust industry. For that reason the Government has decided to legislate, with effect from the time of the announcement made by the then Treasurer and the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) back in late July, for the imposition of a standard 12-month notice period for the withdrawal of funds from existing public unlisted property trusts.

PARA.TAB: I think all honourable senators will agree and have acknowledged during the debate already that at the moment unlisted property trusts are unable to attract new investments or sell property at realistic values in the current depressed market. Whereas previously these avenues had enabled managers to achieve the liquidity necessary to meet buy-back or redemption requests on short notice, the fact is that the situation is now completely transformed and there has been a need for the Government to ensure that large bundles of property are not forced onto the market because, quite clearly, not only would that have been to the detriment of the trusts themselves but, we believe, it would also have led to a broader systemic problem for the financial system as a whole. In particular, a significant proportion of the approximately $29 billion of non-performing loans currently being carried by the banking system is secured by commercial property, so no further pressure was needed in that area.

Faced with a further substantial fall in property values, the banks would have been forced to increase their loss provisioning against these loans and to reassess the asset quality of currently performing borrowers. A consequent reduction in the supply of credit flowing from that process could have led to more business failures and further job losses in the economy.

This was a very necessary step to be taken by the Government back in late July. The reasons impelling or requiring that action, that intervention, in the marketplace are still valid and, as I say, the consequences would have been detrimental not only to those who were involved in the trusts themselves but also, I believe, to the whole of the financial system in so far as it was considerably exposed to the security of commercial property and the deterioration there.

Of course, the introduction of the standard 12-month notice of withdrawal period does not of itself solve the liquidity problem of unlisted property trusts, and it was not intended to do so. Many of those trusts need to restructure their operations so as to provide a better match between the essentially long term nature of real property as an investment and investor demands for ready liquidity. All this does is give a breathing space to management companies and their trustees to reach agreement with unit holders on restructuring proposals. One would hope that by the end of July next year that process will be completed. In fact, I understand it is very largely under way.

The industry, having recognised the difficulties, is restructuring. I am advised that many trust managers are pursuing the option of listing their trusts on the stock exchange. Such listing gives investors an immediate market for their investment. Another option is to convert existing trusts into fixed term trusts which do not have a buy-back or redemption obligation, but which operate on the basis that all the properties will be sold and proceeds distributed to investors at the end of a fixed period. They are the sorts of things that are happening during this 12-month breathing period which managers and trustees have been given. I have outlined the main purpose of the Corporations (Unlisted Property Trusts) Amendment Bill. I hope that the Bill will have the desired effect.

The Bill also contains an amendment to the corporations legislation to make it clear that the Corporations and Securities Panel has the power to make interim orders pending the final outcome of proceedings brought before it by the Australian Securities Commission. The Full Court of the Federal Court of Australia recently ruled that, as a matter of statutory construction, the Panel does not have the power to make interim orders to preserve the rights of persons pending the final determination of an application before it. This amendment will make sure that the Panel has such powers.

In relation to the second Bill before the Senate, the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991, Senator Spindler this morning and, I think, Senator Campbell last night well pointed out an absolute imperative for Australia: if the reputation of this nation as a place which is attractive to investors is to be restored, having been tarnished so badly in the late 1980s by the activities of some entrepreneurs, it is essential that the restoration of an environment which is attractive to investors has as a very firm foundation secure, well understood, well operating companies and securities legislation.

This particular reform measure, which does not go to very substantive matters will, nevertheless, help to foster the correct impression that since 1 January 1991 Australia has a corporate and securities regulatory environment which is under the control of this Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia, where one Federal Minister, the Federal Attorney-General, is responsible to the Parliament in this area of such importance to the nation and where the Australian Securities Commission, the regulatory authority, is responsible to this Parliament. In addition, a special parliamentary committee, the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, has been set up to continue the supervisory role and the reforming role of the Parliament by means of one of its committees. I know that Senator Campbell is a member of that Committee.

In order to continue the process of reform in which this Parliament is engaged in the corporations area, this Bill deals with fundraising, the Australian company number provisions and the settlement of securities transactions. I must say that, in getting the legislation to this chamber this morning, the process which has been devised to allow for public exposure has worked extremely well. It has included the receiving of submissions from interested persons and organisations; the acceptance of the validity of many of the suggestions, which have been incorporated in the amending Bill; and the agreement of the States, the Northern Territory and the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities to the introduction of the Bill into the Parliament. I think that indicates that the machinery to bring corporations reform matters into the Parliament is well structured.

However, there have been a number of matters which warrant clarification, for example, in the fundraising area. This Bill includes a number of largely technical amendments for this purpose with a view to ensuring commercial certainty. The amendments have been set out in the exposure draft; everyone in the investment community is aware of them. With some minor modifications having been made as a result of the exposure period, the Bill is now before us.

As far as the Australian company number is concerned, as Senator Campbell and Senator Spindler pointed out, cash register receipts produced by an electronic machine which set out the information stored in the machine will not be required to contain the Australian company number. Apparently, that is an important matter to those who are involved in the selling of goods in the marketplace. Alternative abbreviations for the Australian company number without full stops will be available for use by companies and bodies in all official documents.

An advertising document issued by a company which is not also used as a document for undertaking some form of transaction with a person will not be required to contain the company's number. The ASC will be empowered to exempt a company or bodies that operate in the transportation of persons or goods from being required to place its company number on documents that are used in connection with transportation, where it is necessary or desirable in the interests of promoting or maintaining consistency in international practice relating to transport documents.
The need to keep in mind best international practice in this area is absolutely fundamental and explains the third measure in this Bill—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, the regime being introduced by the Exchange to follow internationally accepted standards for settlement of on-market transactions. Failure to implement such a regime would, of course, lead to the temptation for people to turn to offshore markets which are more efficient or more competitive in this respect, and that, of course, would erode the liquidity of Australian securities markets. This is a great danger that has to be avoided. The way in which this Bill does that is to be commended.

PARA.TAB: The Bill also extends the coverage of the national guarantee fund facilities that have been developed by the Australian Stock Exchange to assist traders to comply with the new settlement requirements. The Exchange will also have access to the fund for losses suffered by the Exchange as a result of brokers defaulting their obligations under these new facilities. The big point I want to make is that this should lead to a great improvement in the international competitiveness of the Australian Stock Exchange, and that is a very important and welcome matter indeed. I thank those Opposition and Democrats senators who have indicated their support for these proposals. I commend the legislation to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991AUSTRALIAN CITIZENSHIP AMENDMENT BILL 1991MIGRATION (HEALTH SERVICES) CHARGE BILL 1991MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1991

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 12, 13 and 26 November, on motions by Senator McMullan and Senator Collins:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Amendment Bill (No. 2) introduces amendments expected to strengthen Australia's immigration border controls. It may be something that we would rather bury our heads in the sand about, but we have to face the fact that with the general unrest and increasing number of war zones throughout the world Australia's border problems will increase significantly in the next few years. They need added legislative protection.

PARA.TAB: Australia is a much sought after destination. While European countries would say that our illegal and refugee problem is insignificant in comparison with their problem, it is certainly not under control. I resist using the phrase `out of control' because, in fairness to the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, I believe that there is a difference. However, it ought to be noted that `out of control' may soon be an apt description if the present problems are not corralled.

I accept that we do not have the problems of Europe or the UK, but we need to learn from them rather than to blithely ignore them. Too often we are told that it is different in Australia. That is true, but it is also the same. Numbers and reasons for illegals may well be different; numbers and reasons for claiming refugee status may well be different also. I am not arguing that. But the United Kingdom has had 55,000 people claiming refugee status in the past year, with 44,000 apparently lying, and the result was a bill of #325m. The viewpoint outside the UK was that its immigration legislation, as it applied to refugees and illegals, was weak—with a capital W. The bogus refugee bush telegraph got to work, the flood started and the UK has a crisis.

I contest that the way Australia's immigration legislation is affected or not affected—depending on how critical one wishes to be—leaves us wide open to gaining the reputation of being weak with regard to border problems. Sure, we are harder to reach, but the fact that 300 boat people have reached us in the past 18 months claiming to be refugees from Cambodia and Vietnam indicates that where there is a will there is always a way. It is estimated that there are already 110,000 to 120,000 illegals in Australia, most arriving on temporary visas and disappearing. Add to that some 24,000 people claiming refugee status, 17,000 of whom are students from the People's Republic of China, and the numbers begin to mount. In fact, the number of people claiming refugee status in Australia is growing at 1,000 a month. That is an alarming statistic which, so far, has not attracted much attention. It has doubled from 500 a month in a relatively short period of time.

We never want to reach the UK situation where its Government was forced to admit publicly it had uncovered that as many as four out of five refugees were not genuine. Emergency legislation to deal with this crisis in the form of the asylum Bill was one of the 12 main Bills in the Queen's Speech some weeks ago. The Bill has just passed through the House of Commons and, with rigid guidelines to allow for fast tracking of applications, increased staff numbers, severe penalties for anyone who aids bogus refugees and immediate deportation for false claims, it is a virtual state of emergency. The UK social services simply cannot cope. The British media headline it as an uncontrollable border crisis.

By virtue of Australia's location, we are saved the severity of the British problem with its geographic and historical connections to areas of present political unrest. But our own problems are very much with us. If the Government were honest, it would admit that it has absolutely no idea how many illegals are running around undiscovered in Australia, that it costs more than $10,000 to locate each one, but that when we find them we also find that some who are denied immigration rights under one category simply try under another category. During 1991, 9,253 illegals were uncovered—a minute proportion—and only 4,862 of the 9,000 left the country. The others exercised their entitlement to apply for grant of residence or refugee status.

As a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration Regulations, I have also heard evidence which substantiates the severity of the problem of sham marriages and sham de facto relationships for the purpose of gaining a visa or entry permit to Australia. Abuse in this area is unacceptably high, to the extent that figures have been bandied around to suggest abuse levels of some 70 per cent—a massive problem when it is realised that some 13,000 people entered Australia on spouse or de facto visas in 1989-90.

Pieced together, the many different difficulties in the immigration area indicate that Australia must ensure it is perceived overseas as tough but fair. We must also be perceived as being in control of our migration regulations. At this point we are limping along, attempting to block leaks and cover discrepancies as they are uncovered. It is far from a picture which engenders much faith in the long term success of our current migration policy. The very nearly not in control could jump the barrier, in the future, to out of control.

For these reasons the Opposition will be supporting this Bill, which attempts to deal with some very real problems according to sensible parameters. It must be said, however, that in supporting it we do retain some serious reservations about the workings of the Government's immigration policies. We wish to put it on record that we also have serious reservations about the continued constant propping of these policies received from a long line of Bills, four of which we are dealing with today.

The Migration Amendment Act (No. 2) has three main components. Firstly, it creates new offences in relation to immigration due to marriage or de facto relationships. Secondly, it increases the Government's information gathering powers in relation to those believed to be illegal immigrants. Thirdly, it allows for regulations to authorise the Minister to fix a limit on the number of visas or permits in a particular class which may be granted in a particular financial year.

Dealing with sham marriages and de facto relationships, the Bill makes it an offence for a person to arrange a marriage for the purpose of assisting one of the parties to obtain a permit to stay in Australia. The maximum penalty for a breach of this provision will be a $100,000 fine, 10 years imprisonment, or both. If a person believes, on reasonable grounds, that two people are not de facto spouses and makes it look as if they are for the purpose of obtaining a permit to stay in Australia, the same penalty will apply—as it should.

It is hoped that this provision will help deal with the unscrupulous migration agents who, for a price, arrange sham marriages and set up de facto spouses. It will also be an offence for a person to apply to stay in Australia on the basis of a marriage or de facto relationship if he or she does not intend to live permanently with the other person in a genuine and continuing relationship. Any non-citizen convicted will become an illegal entrant. It will also be an offence to nominate persons to stay in Australia if they do not have any such intention. The maximum penalty is two years imprisonment. Given the proven massive level of abuse in this area, these amendments are essential.

The Bill also permits the obtaining of information and documents about the identity and location of illegal entrants. The provisions in clause 3, new subsection 22A, require any person whom the Minister believes capable of supplying information on a suspected illegal immigrant to supply information on that person. The maximum penalty for a breach of this provision will be 12 months imprisonment. It will be an offence to protect a suspected illegal by giving false and misleading statements, and the maximum penalty will be $12,000.

We do have concerns about the ramifications to lawyers of this provision. While principles of interpretation of common law rule that legal privilege cannot be overridden by statute unless specifically stated in the legislation, the legal community has the view that the Minister does not intend to be bound by this as it relates to the workings of clause 22A of this Bill. He apparently is of the view that we should test it and see and let the courts decide, and has said as much in a letter to Mr Phillip Ruddock, the shadow Minister for immigration and ethnic affairs.

While we do not seek to amend the Bill, we wish to put on record that we will be following this particular problem with interest. For surely it is crucial that anyone who is unsure of his immigration status and his rights under Australian law should be able to express without fear and in confidence his situation to a lawyer. It does nothing for the rights of the individual to fear that his lawyer will be obliged to reveal confidential conversations and documentation.

I also feel it is worth making the point at this stage of the Bill that the loopholes remain huge. After all, we have illegals who have no trouble managing to acquire a tax file number, not to mention a Medicare card. The Opposition has presented suggestions of employer sanctions for hiring illegals, which seem quite logical. The Minister has resisted this thrust thus far. I suggest it be re-examined rather than ridiculed or put aside simply because the Opposition has proposed it.

The legislation also provides the Minister with greater control to ensure published limits are not exceeded by amendments which set limits on the number of visas or permits which can be granted in a particular class. I understand this is to deal primarily with the special assistance class of migrant announced some time ago. We accept the need for such amendments.

This Bill, in total, tidies up and strengthens areas of the immigration program. We do not oppose it. As explained, our concerns are with the limited success of the present immigration program and regulations. It is not an area we can allow to drift, yet the Government appears reluctant to face up to some of the problems that are clear and quite evident.

The Australian Citizenship Amendment Bill 1991 proposes minor amendments to the Australian Citizenship Act to provide for a person to obtain citizenship by descent through registration. The Opposition supports this legislation because it addresses a concern we have fought to have dealt with. However, we make the point that we still have concerns that this is yet another amendment Bill dealing with yet another element of a much larger problem which good government would take the time, and make the effort, to consider as a whole, instead of in this typical ad hoc crisis management style which is the hallmark of Australia's current immigration policy.

This Bill will redress a number of unfortunate incidences created by changes to the Citizenship Act in 1984. These changes led to many people who believed they were Australian citizens, either through descent, armed service or possession of an Australian passport, discovering that they did not have entitlement to Australian citizenship. Until November 1984, British subjects with close ties to Australia, spouses of Australians, children born abroad to Australian parents and frequent business travellers to Australia were all granted Australian passports. But the 1983 recommendations of the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking recommended that only Australian citizenship should be used as a guide to who should be granted an Australian passport. In line with that worthy recommendation, Australian passports issued before 22 November 1984 were no longer accepted as evidence of Australian citizenship and to acquire an Australian passport either a birth certificate or citizenship papers were necessary.

In the same year the Australian Citizenship Act had inserted a new section 10B. At the time section 10B appeared sensible and harmless. It limited the registration of Australian citizenship by descent to persons under the age of 18. It was intended to tighten the Act to ensure that citizenship was available only to those with close and genuine ties to Australia.

The logic appeared to be that, if someone reached adulthood, age 18, without claiming ties and applying for citizenship, their ties to Australia could hardly be described as close. However, the amendment caught and disadvantaged many people over the age of 18 who truly believed they were Australian, including children born overseas to Australian parents and issued with Australian passports overseas when young.

There have been some well publicised, quite traumatic cases revealed in the media as a result of the problems that section 10B has created. It left genuine Australians because of age out in the cold, unable to claim the prize—Australian citizenship—which they believed was rightfully theirs. This Bill now provides that persons who are over the age of 18 and who could have applied for registration as an Australian citizen by descent, provided they have an acceptable reason for not having so registered, can apply for registration.

The Bill also includes an amendment to section 10B which makes it clear that a person cannot acquire citizenship by descent through registration if their parent also acquired citizenship by the same process unless that parent has lived in Australia for two years. That appears to be a reasonable method of ensuring that there are no ongoing entitlements for citizenship to pass through families to their descendants if each generation is not to live in Australia. The legislation therefore has the support of the Opposition.

The third Bill to be taken through its remaining stages is the Migration (Health Services) Charge Bill 1991. This Bill and the Migration Amendment Bill (No.3) 1991 are part of the Government's legislative program to introduce new charges for certain groups of applicants, or more correctly their sponsors, for granting them a visa or entry permit into Australia. We will not oppose the Migration (Health Services) Charge Bill. The Bill is designed to raise a charge of $822. It arose from the Budget and therefore it has been applied to those in certain categories who have sought a visa or entry permit from 21 August 1991.

The Migration Amendment Bill (No. 3) will give effect to the provisions of the Migration (Health Services) Charge Bill. It will therefore commence on the same day. It amends section 24 and section 34 of the Migration Act which relate to the granting and the refusal of visas or entry permits respectively. In the case of each section, the Bill introduces a requirement for the Minister to provide a notice in writing to an applicant seeking to enter or remain in Australia. This states that the grant of the class of visa or entry permit applied for cannot occur unless the charge payable under the Migration (Health Services) Charge Act 1991 has been paid. The Bill contains a prohibition on the Minister granting a visa or entry permit until the charge is paid.

In addition, the regulation-making power under the Migration Act is amended to provide for the refund of charges paid under the Migration (Health Services) Charge Act under exceptional circumstances. This Bill gives effect to the health services levy and will not be opposed. However, I need to make clear the reason why we do not oppose the Bills. It is basically because receiving at least some percentage of migrant costs up-front is better than the existing system which is severely flawed and open to widespread abuse. It costs the Australian taxpayer millions in unpaid debts when a sponsor family cannot honour the agreements of the support scheme into which they entered to achieve the entry of their relatives to Australia.

I take the opportunity at this point to say that the coalition's Fightback package has shown the courage to tackle the issue of health and social welfare benefits to migrants in a far more pertinent way. Until a change of government occurs, we will no doubt continue to limp forward applying a procession of tiny bandaids to the terminally ill Migration Act and its confused regulations. If the Government were not so concerned about the views of pressure groups, it would admit that radical surgery was the only way to effect recovery.

Essentially, the two Bills we are dealing with today are small bandaids attempting to cover a much larger sore. These bandaid measures are aimed at catching cheques for $822 because at the other end of the system, in the assurance of support scheme as it applies at present, some $20m was lost this year in benefits not recovered. These are benefits which should have been reclaimed from families who had undertaken to sponsor migrants or visa holders, thereby supporting their costs.

Senator Richardson told the Senate that some $32m had been spent on Jobsearch allowances, Newstart and special benefits for newly arrived migrants under the support system, yet only $1.77m had been recovered. In other words, the immigration program is in its usual chaos, with the Australian taxpayer paying the price. In line with that usual muddle, confusion and inappropriate organisation in the migration legislation area, this level of unrecoverable debt under the present assurance of support scheme is to be quite expected while certainly not condoned. The Auditor-General was most scathing in his efficiency audit of the Department and this is borne out by the present government methodology of tack-on-another-bandaid legislation.

In an attempt to lower the debt level the Government has arrived at this new bonding arrangement. It requires someone to put money up-front for a levy on health and associated costs for the individuals they sponsor into Australia. We are informed that the new medical levy is expected to recoup some $9.9m in a full financial year. It affects certain groups: for example, those entitled to a parent visa in which the balance of family test has been met. It also applies to visa class 104: those who come within the special preferred class of family in respect of minor orphans, special need relatives, remaining relatives—that is, those left behind because of the migration of all other family members—and certain aged dependants.

The $822 is indexed against the all-group consumer price index and is therefore subject to an increase where the indexation in any relevant year calculated from 21 August 1992 is greater than one, and that charge cannot fall below its highest previously determined level. It has been calculated that the charge represents an estimated 50 per cent of the contribution towards the cost of the Commonwealth in providing access to medical, hospital and pharmaceutical benefits to assured persons during their first two years in Australia. It does not, however, apply to the cost that might be generated either through the private sector or by State governments—which I believe is a matter of some concern to the States. Neither is it intended to recover any further health related costs, such as payment of sickness benefits, in the first two years of settlement.

The Bills we are dealing with today and the regulations to be shortly introduced are components of a much more limited assurance of support scheme than the one which fails at present. The new scheme shortens the duration of support to two years instead of five and does not cover the same range of benefits as were previously covered. As well as the up-front health levy of $822, the existing assurance of support scheme will now be supplemented by the payment of a refundable bond by some applicants in the preferential family reunion program.

The bond—$3500 for principal applicants and $1500 for others in the family over the age of 18—will be used as the first avenue of recovery of debts incurred by assured migrants in relation to special benefits, Jobsearch and Newstart allowance paid by the Commonwealth. The bond must be paid before the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs will issue a visa authorising entry for those who apply to enter Australia on or after 21 August 1991. However, the liability of the scheme no longer extends to accommodation, surgical and dental treatment and any other allowance of support for the assured migrant. In addition, debts incurred by the State, public or charitable organisations will no longer be recoverable.

As I have said, the Coalition supports the Migration (Health Services) Charge Bill 1991 and the Migration Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991. It is simply to be regretted that this chamber has to deal with a steady procession of bandaid legislation because of sloppy administration and poor legislation being introduced in the first place.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank Senator Olsen for his comments. I note the view which he has expressed about the intention to monitor closely this legislation. I think that is an appropriate response in this situation where there is some disagreement but where the disagreement is not of a nature at this stage to mean that those opposite will not support the legislation. I thank Senator Olsen for that. He would know, and the chamber would know, that this is not a matter with which I usually deal. If there are some questions which he has raised which I do not respond to as comprehensively as he might have wished, and he wants to follow them up, he is welcome to do so.

PARA.TAB: I understand the concern which was raised most seriously by him—I came in during the point—about legal practitioners and legal professional privilege, which I am advised is a reference to proposed new subsection 83J(3) of the Bill relating to gaining further information which may be required from lawyers as well as from others. Concern has been expressed—not just by Senator Olsen, I acknowledge, but by the Law Institute and others—about whether this is the appropriate course of action for the Government to be taking and whether it is undermining some broader principles.

I do not want here today to pose as an expert in this complex area. It is a question of balance, I know. In areas which I deal with more closely there is often a question of balance, not just for lawyers but for accountants and others, about issues of confidentiality of client information and the rights of clients to get free and fair advice and to provide a full and comprehensive briefing to their legal representatives against the rights of society as reflected through its elected government to administer the law and gain information that is necessary to protect the broader interests. It is always a difficult balance to strike. It is one where I think the Government would welcome continuing close scrutiny by not only the Opposition but also the Law Institute and others who have expressed concern.

My advice is that the balance has been struck fairly between two difficult and conflicting demands that are often put upon the Government and the Parliament. At this stage I note that there is no proposal to amend the Bill. I welcome the scrutiny and the comments that have been made, and I thank the chamber for its support for the legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
The Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to the matter I raised in my speech during the second reading debate and the response of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), I want to establish on record the view of the Government specifically as it relates to the interpretation of the common law rule that legal privilege cannot be overridden by statute unless it is specifically stated in the legislation that we override that common law statute.

PARA.TAB: I have a copy of a letter written by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) to Mr Philip Ruddock, the shadow Minister, wherein a corporate law case is cited. My understanding is that the corporate law legislation specifically indicates that legal privilege can be overridden. However, in the Migration Act 1958 that we are dealing with today there is no such reference, amendment or clause which specifically overrides the common law rule of legal privilege. Therefore, as the legislation that we have before us is silent, and the principal Act is silent, is it not a fact that the common law rule stands, unlike the case cited by the Minister in his correspondence of 4 December to Mr Ruddock? Under this principal Act, under the amendments put before us, will the common law rule that legal privilege cannot be overridden stand?

TALK.START.PARA: —I chose not to speak in the debate on the second reading, but I want to raise a couple of issues in the committee stage just to assure myself on several points which have been raised by the Law Institute of Victoria. The first of those points has been raised by Senator Olsen. I understand that, with respect to legal privilege, under these circumstances a court or a magistrate has to be satisfied that a solicitor-client relationship does exist for privilege to apply; and, further to that, the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, in looking at this situation, considered that this legislation did not necessarily run counter to the application of legal privilege. Like Senator Olsen, I would like to be assured on that very matter—that in no way will this Bill interfere when it is established that there is a proper professional client-solicitor relationship, and that legal privilege will not be in any way interfered with.

—I have to apologise to Senator Coulter in that, as I was getting a briefing from the officers, I did not pick up everything that he said. I was trying to listen with one ear while being briefed with the other. Should I miss something he has raised, I will be happy to come back to it. I am principally responding to Senator Olsen's point. If I do not go to all those things that Senator Coulter raised, I am quite sure he will raise them again, so that I can do so.

PARA.TAB: At the moment, notwithstanding the force of Senator Olsen's point, which was well argued, my advice is that the Government's understanding is that the law as it is drafted will potentially override the question of legal professional privilege, but that is a matter that will be determined ultimately by the courts. If the courts rule otherwise, we will accept that. More importantly, my advice is that the objectives of the Government with regard to seeking information about illegals is sufficiently limited—that is, it is in pursuit of information about matters such as identity and location rather than confidential information provided, and that we may well be able to achieve the Government's objectives without in any way coming into the conflict that would lead us into the courts and to challenges as to whether the legal professional privilege question is being impeded.

Senator Olsen asked me the explicit question: is it the Government's view—I think I am interpreting his question fairly—that, if the case arises, this legislation will override the common law? My advice is that the answer to that question is yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —From whom did the Government receive advice that that would be the case? Was it the Attorney-General's Department or some other source? Would the Parliamentary Secretary also comment on the point that I raised about the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand) citing a corporate law case as an example of overriding legal privilege? The legislation specifically indicates that legal privilege can be overridden. I again draw the Parliamentary Secretary's attention to the fact that these amendments and the Migration Act are silent on the matter; therefore common law, legal privilege being maintained, ought not to be able to be overridden.

—Without wanting to pass the burden of responsibility for decision to advisers, my understanding is that the advice did come from the Attorney-General's Department. I do not want to pursue that any further, because ultimately it is not the Department's responsibility. It comes into the Senate and it is our responsibility.

PARA.TAB: We do not advance the cause of human knowledge very far beyond Senator Olsen's articulation of a sensible alternative view, which I acknowledge it to be. The Government is advised that the legislation will have the effect that I have outlined. The courts may share Senator Olsen's view and interpretation; if that is the case, that will be the law as interpreted by the courts and it will be applied accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Am I to understand that, when the Scrutiny of Bills Committee said that legal privilege was not removed by this Bill, it was actually incorrect? That seems to be the effect of what the Parliamentary Secretary has told us. It is a bit disturbing that we have had that advice.

PARA.TAB: Continuing along the line that Senator Olsen was pursuing, I understand that in a situation such as this, in which one is left with a common law, it would be left for a magistrate or a judge to be satisfied as to whether a client-solicitor relationship existed and then to judge whether there had been any breach of that professional legal privilege. That seems to be somewhat different from the interpretation that I am hearing from the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that the wording of this legislation is more directly comparable with the relevant section of the corporations Acts than would be implied by Senator Olsen's comment. I personally am not sufficiently familiar with the Acts to give a definitive view on the wording of each of them, but my advice is that there is more comparability than Senator Olsen's expression would convey. That may change the balance, and that is one of the factors that ultimately the courts will take into account.

PARA.TAB: With regard to Senator Coulter's point that the advice I am conveying, perhaps inadequately, is not consistent with other advice that has been given, all I can say here and now is that I will check with the relevant Ministers to ensure that the definitive view of the Government is set down. I hope there will not be a need for further information; but, should I find that I have not communicated the information clearly and that there is some inconsistency, I will table the information in the Senate so that people understand the basis upon which we are operating. Hopefully that will be the comprehensive opinion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put on the record exactly what the Parliamentary Secretary is saying. Is he saying that his best advice at the moment is that in some respects legal privilege, in the general sense of the term, is infringed by this legislation, and that if anything differs from that he will bring the alternative advice back to the Senate?
—I am not sure that `infringed' is the word I want to use; but, without getting into a semantic argument, broadly the answers are yes and yes.

—There are several other points that I wish to raise briefly. I think the Parliamentary Secretary has covered part of the area of privacy, section 22K, and he has said that a great deal of information is made available to State and Federal agencies, but at no time was it ever contemplated that the information would be made available for the purposes of assisting the Minister in investigations. I hope I am not going over ground the Parliamentary Secretary has already covered, but concerns have been expressed in relation to the use of that information which has been collected for other purposes. Will he assure us that in the area of privacy that matter is not infringed upon—and, if it is, that it is not overly infringed upon?

—My understanding is that the limitation that will apply to the information received by the Department is simply that it will be used for the narrow and constrained purposes of identifying and locating illegals. I am advised that the Department will not be authorised to pass on to other agencies the information that it gathers, and the information from other agencies will be used only for those two limited purposes.

—The reversal of onus of proof under section 83D arises in connection with a person having to prove that there was a belief that the marriage would result in a genuine and continuing relationship, to the extent that that involves a reversal of the normal onus of proof. Will the Parliamentary Secretary comment on that? I suspect he will comment in terms rather similar to those he used when answering my last question.

—I have some information. I understand that this question was raised by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. The new section to which we refer—83D and, in particular, 83D(3)—was inserted because the Government recognises that there are persons in the community who enter into arranged marriages as a matter of custom. This section, therefore, gives the parties to a traditional but genuine arranged marriage a defence to what would otherwise be an offence if the marriage were entered into to obtain residence in Australia. The view is that, therefore, it is not actually a reversal of the onus of proof but provides a defence for people who otherwise would be considered to have committed an offence. The Government's view is that 83D(3) does not, in fact, reverse the onus of proof.

PARA.TAB: Bills agreed to.
Bills reported without amendment; report adopted.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That these Bills be now read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to put on the record the Opposition's view that it is somewhat concerned with the response of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) in relation to legal privilege. We take the view that client-legal adviser privilege and confidentiality ought to be maintained. We note that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee had advice that legal privilege would not be interfered with by virtue of the passage of this legislation. I fully expected the Parliamentary Secretary to confirm that view here today. The Parliamentary Secretary's response has been somewhat—
—Equivocal.
—Yes—equivocal in relation to that matter. The alternative is to seek to amend specifically the legislation to reinforce that view.

PARA.TAB: We take the view that, where the amendments are silent and where the principal Act is silent, common law ought to stand. Our view firmly is that, in this instance, the common law view ought stand, legal privilege ought be maintained in these circumstances and legal privilege ought be maintained for client confidentiality. We trust that in due course, if this matter is, as the Parliamentary Secretary says, to be determined by the courts, that will be the view that is upheld by the courts.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a third time.
Debate resumed from 12 November, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is indeed my pleasure to be leading for the coalition in this debate on the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991. I do so at a most significant time—a time of high drama, where Australians are clamouring for a new deal in taxation. The timing of this debate is indeed perhaps a little unfortunate for the Government as it coincides with the overwhelming support from the Australian community for a change to our tax structure and an endorsement of the coalition's policy of reform—a policy of reform that will enable Australia to fight back against declining living standards and give hope to the future aspirations of all Australians.

PARA.TAB: The coalition's tax reform proposals under the appropriate title `fighting back' give Australia a clear signal that the Liberal and the National parties are leading the tax debate in Australia. The legislation before us this morning is nothing more than an attempt to catch up and patch up a job that certainly does not match up to the coalition's goods and services tax.

The changes in today's amendments are an acknowledgment by the Government that the problems of collection of sales tax in the 1990s have moved well away from the goals set by the original drafters of sales tax legislation in the 1930s. While some people might say that sales tax is an economically cheap tax to collect, the actual numbers of collectors is extremely high in relation to the number of registered taxpayers. Such messages indicate a skewing effect, ensuring that certain goods and certain taxpayers bear a burden unrelated to that borne by the rest of the community. Such a situation does not demonstrate a fair and equitable tax system.

The coalition's answer is to eliminate seven taxes and replace them with one goods and services tax. The coalition's proposal contains a strong bias to business which will reap $20 billion of benefits while, at the same time, corporations will surrender less than $1 billion of tax for the adjustment of income tax rates in the corporate sector from 39 per cent to 42 per cent. In fact, the raising of this tax is necessary for equity reasons to correspond after 1996 with the top personal marginal tax rate. Regrettably, the Labor Party has not been astute enough to perceive this gap as being conducive to the creation of tax avoidance schemes and has done nothing about it.

The Bill now before the Senate has been put forward by this Government to give effect to one of three taxation reforms the Government proposed in its 12 March industry statement. Madam Acting Deputy President, permit me to refresh your memory as to why the industry statement was made. This was the economic statement to address what Australia must `do together to meet the economic challenges facing this country'. Perhaps it is because we are still waiting for the majority of the statement's recommendations to be enacted that we have unemployment exceeding 10 per cent, record foreign debt and record current account deficits. However, even after the recommendations are enacted, obviously the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself does not believe that the country's economic challenges will be fully met. Why else did he need to make a further employment statement only last month?

As mentioned before, there are three matters which were given the title of taxation reforms in the 12 March industry statement. The first matter is tax exemptions for inputs to goods production, which we will obviously be dealing with in legislation that will be before us later today. The second matter is the revised depreciation arrangements, which has been the topic of a fair amount of debate in this chamber, even though legislation has not been introduced. The Government's proposed revised depreciation arrangements did not meet industry agreement and we are still awaiting the objections to be dealt with before the Government makes a legislative move in this area. I remind the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) of all of the businesses that will be balancing up on 31 December and 30 June. With no legislative base, how are they going to be dealt with? This Government has placed such corporations in quite an impossible and unfair situation.

The third matter is the tax treatment of environmental impact studies. This matter has been addressed to some extent in Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991, which was debated earlier this week. However, because of Government priorities, the second reading debate has not been completed. So this reform still has no statutory basis because it has yet to receive final approval from the Senate. If amendments are made, the Bill will have to go back to the other House before royal assent can be given.

The objective of the Sales Tax Amendment Bill (No. 3) is to extend the exemptions that currently exist in sales tax legislation to cover more comprehensively business input costs. It is interesting to reflect on why the Government wants to extend wholesale sales tax exemptions in respect of business input costs, particularly in the light of the current debate in Australia about the introduction of a goods and services tax. The Government has responded in this way because it has realised the weakness inherent in the sales tax system compared with our goods and services tax proposals.
When we look at the March statement we learn why the Government wants to introduce these additional exemptions to the wholesale sales tax. The industry statement says:

SPEECH.PARA: The measures reduce the cost burden of wholesale sales tax on inputs of goods producers (and sub-contractors performing eligible activities) and thereby reduce the cascading of the cost through the production chain.
Those words echo the ones we have been using about the need for a GST. The statement continues:

Production costs will therefore be reduced by significantly more than the revenue cost of the measures. In particular, the competitiveness of Australia's export and import-competing industries will be enhanced by the new WST exemptions.

Is it not interesting that, from time to time, we hear from the Labor Party that the wholesale sales tax does not add to the cost of exports? Yet in the industry statement of 12 March we have in print the admission that the competitiveness of Australia's export- and import-competing industries will be enhanced by the new wholesale sales tax exemption. This statement contradicts the Labor Party's earlier stand. I will quote further from the industry statement, which goes on to say:

Many inputs to goods production are already exempt from WST. The existing exemptions include the aids to manufacture provisions, exemptions for goods used in mining activities and for agricultural and fishing equipment. The extensions announced in this statement will significantly—
note the word `significantly'—
reduce the remaining elements of input taxation facing goods producers.

I again remind the Senate that the statement says `significantly reduce' not eliminate, as the Opposition's goods and services tax will do. So, in the first place, we have a clear recognition by the Government that the wholesale sales tax regime is one that imposes costs on the business community.

PARA.TAB: It is contestable then, on the basis of the words used in the industry statement, the second reading speech and this legislation, that the wholesale sales tax imposes costs on the Australian business community, the mining sector and the farming community which result in a reduced capacity to compete. It is also interesting to note that, by providing $445m worth of exemptions in this Bill, the Government claims that the business community will benefit in the vicinity of $1 billion. There is a problem with arithmetic there.

The point that the compounding effect on the business community of the wholesale sales tax, where exemptions will now be provided, is about double the actual impact of the taxes is quite clear. It is also very important to understand this when looking at the workings of the wholesale sales tax system.

This legislation concedes philosophically that there is an overwhelming case for the introduction of a goods and services tax in Australia. As I proceed to address specific aspects of this legislation, honourable senators will see why a goods and services tax would not only address the issues that this legislation addresses, but also would do so in a comprehensive way which, effectively, would ensure that at the end of the day no business inputs are subject to sales tax, the price of exports actually declines, and there is no compounding effect from the tax.

This Bill will alter the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1935 and the sales tax regulations. In so doing, it will extend the existing wholesale sales tax exemption to cover a wide range of business inputs for use by goods producers and certain other categories of persons. Thirteen eligible business goods categories to which exemption applies are created, including: eligible primary production goods; eligible mineral production goods; eligible manufacturing goods; eligible transport goods; eligible engineering and technical design goods; eligible storage, handling and dispatch goods; eligible computer equipment; eligible research and development goods; eligible sea cargo handling goods; eligible international air cargo handling goods; mixed-use eligible business goods; mixed-use eligible road vehicles; and parts for goods covered by any of the above categories.

The proposed sales tax amendments will also extend exemptions to the following goods when used—and here is a problem word—mainly in eligible activities. The word `mainly' will create a whole raft of litigation. These goods will include lubricants, office furniture, equipment and consumables, road vehicles when used exclusively within the production premises, and goods such as hand tools when used in agricultural activities or fishing.

By way of an overall comment on this Bill, I say that if this is an example of the new simplified method of taxation legislation then, despite some earlier good starts, I am afraid we have slipped back woefully. It is not only difficult to read, but also difficult to comprehend and thus difficult to administer and difficult for those who practise in this area. Complex legislation leads to only one outcome: confused application. People will endeavour to claim exemption where no exemption exists, and those who are entitled to an exemption will be too baffled by the legislation to learn of their entitlement and thus they will miss out. There is an obligation on government to publicise and distribute widely to the diffused users outlined in the 13 categories, which I mentioned earlier, the exact meaning and intent of the legislation. One thing is certain: following the passage of this Bill, there will be no shortage of work for accountants or lawyers working in the sales tax area.

The other problem associated with the complex nature of the writing of this Bill is that items which the Government intended to have exempted by this legislation have unfortunately been lost in the complexity of this Bill. For example, I believe it was the Government's intention, when listing eligible sea cargo handling goods for exemption, to exempt all goods used to handle cargo or containers on a wharf. However, it appears that the Government may have overlooked the fact that all the machinery used on wharves has to be lubricated because, despite exempting lubricants from sales tax for aids to manufacture, it appears that the Bill does not allow for lubricants used on eligible sea cargo handling goods to be exempt. I think that should be clarified.

I note that in schedule 1 the definition of `mainly' is to the extent of more than 50 per cent. This varies from, and replaces, the definition of `main' which was inserted only last year and which had the meaning of not less than 50 per cent. I would be interested to hear from the Government why there has been this change and how the Government will attempt to argue its way out of the need for simplicity in the confusion that has been created. It is all very well to give this definition, but how can the vendor, the purchaser, or the Tax Office for that matter, prove what the main use of the engineering and technical design goods is in my case?

I raised the same question when debating the exemption of sales tax on computer equipment, and we received a very unsatisfactory answer. I hope the Government can do better on this occasion. How does the vendor know that the purchaser is buying the good as an eligible exempt good? Does the vendor ask the purchaser to sign a document to this effect? Alternatively, does the purchaser need to keep a log book of his or her use of the equipment in order to justify to the Tax Office that the good is used 50 per cent of the time in its capacity as an eligible sales tax exempt item? I certainly hope not.

This legislation does not address the fundamental matter of the administration of the sales tax law. I believe Senator McMullan will jump to his feet and tell me that there are tax rulings which address this problem. Of course, Senator McMullan would be right—sales tax ruling ST(NS)3 issued on 11 July 1991, and effective from that date, covers such matters as understanding the term `use' in the sales tax legislation, how `use' affects exemption, and principles for determining exemption according to use. We are told in ruling ST(NS)3 paragraph 1.7 that ruling ST(NS)4 sets out the practical steps one should take in approaching the question of classifying; that is, determining the rate of tax on goods. When read in conjunction, these two rulings provide a comprehensive guide to the Taxation Office view of how to determine the rate of sales tax on a particular good. The only problem I have with this is that I do not think ST(NS)4 has been released yet.

I will illustrate this point further by looking again at the question of lubricants. The last time we had a change to the sales tax exemptions on lubricants was in 1985 approximately. The reason given for the change was the administrative difficulty in policing how the exemption was to apply.

This Bill still has not solved this administration problem. If a person were to buy oil in bulk, say a 200-litre drum, and use at least 50 per cent on aids to manufacture, then the exemption would apply. However, if the oil were used to lubricate a salesman's car, the tax would have to be paid on it. How the tax is to be payable or how the tax exemption is to be administered is anybody's guess. No administrative process is outlined.

There is also a problem in administering an exemption when a good is sold by retail. Consider the example of an electrical contractor who buys what he needs from a retailer to install into factory premises. The goods have passed the taxable point, so how does the person know whether they will be tax exempt? Under the wholesale sales tax arrangements this is a complicated situation, and the electrical contractor probably would have to apply to the Commissioner to get an exemption. Under a goods and services tax regime the tax would just have to be paid and then written off when the contractor put in his return at the end of the month or the quarter. In other words, if one is in business, effectively one will get a credit the following month.

Before leaving this topic surrounding the word `mainly', which will cause an awful amount of confusion, I would like to comment that it would appear, given the direction that this sales tax legislation has taken, that the Government is moving towards requiring more than 50 per cent use of goods for the goods to qualify for sales tax exemption. Here is further confusion. There are a number of exemptions in the Act for the mining and farming communities where the 50 per cent qualification does not currently apply. I ask the Government's representative in this matter, Senator McMullan, to either confirm or deny that this is the Government's intention.

Another point I wish to raise with regard to wholesale sales tax exemptions is discrimination between particular types of industries. For example, major publishers are manufacturers and they are accepted as such by the Taxation Office. However, if they use a computer to make a design which is printed on paper, that computer is not sales tax exempt. Yet the same computer, when used to make a design which is put onto a metal plaque, is sales tax exempt.

Whilst looking at the flaws in the wholesale sales tax exemptions system I would like to give the Senate a further example. A specialist agency has an opportunity to win a contract to cut metal for a manufacturer of whitegoods. The special computerised metal cutting machine he buys to do the job qualifies for wholesale sales tax exemption. The businessman needs to run the machine only two days a week to produce the output needed by the whitegoods manufacturer, so the owner of the computerised metal cutting machine approaches the building industry with an offer to cut steel to length. If the machine is used three days a week cutting steel for the building industry and only two days for the whitegoods manufacturer, the machine no longer qualifies for wholesale sales tax exemption.
We have a hotchpotch regime of sales tax exemptions; it is doing enormous harm to industry and it is discouraging the effective use of up to date plant.

A similar tale of woe can be told about computer equipment. If a business uses its computer for tasks other than administration, then the computer qualifies for wholesale sales tax exemption. However, if too many administrative programs are loaded onto the computer, and it is used for these purposes, it no longer qualifies for exemption. There is a gaping hole in the logic. Once we make one exemption, a Pandora's box of exemptions is opened up, with inconsistencies and anomalies abounding. I have given only a few examples to demonstrate the problems arising from this legislation.

Another interesting point about this Bill is the timing of its application. The fact that the changes which this Bill will enact are effective only from the date of royal assent, as opposed to the date of announcement of the changes, means that businesses are avoiding buying equipment or using equipment purchased. The reason for doing this is that a refund can be obtained if the goods are not used before the date of royal assent. As well as deferring purchasing decisions, businesses are stockpiling lubricants and computer paper which will become exempt when the Bill receives royal assent. It is a ridiculous situation.

Sales tax changes are usually dated from the time of initial announcement, but the industry has lobbied hard against that practice, partly because previous announcements have always resulted in an increase in sales tax. Ironically, now, when the Bill will result in a decrease in sales tax, the Tax Office has agreed with industry and made the date of application the date of royal assent. But it will cause problems of enforcement and substantiation.

On the matter of eligible research and development goods, there are a couple of matters I wish to raise. Firstly, the term `eligible research and development goods' does not extend to software created goods. It appears that the Government has not come to grips with the fact that most research and development programs now, if they are related to a product process, would also involve software. Take, for example, the situation of a major research project into developing a new production process for which a new program is written after a number of man years have been spent working on it. The outcome is a new production schedule which cuts costs in half. This has actually occurred. It would appear that the equipment used to generate that new program is not sales tax exempt.
I would be pleased to have Senator McMullan clarify this for the Senate, particularly as I may have misunderstood the situation. I certainly hope I have, for the sake of industry.

Secondly, I am concerned that as a result of this amendment there may be some confusion with regard to the roles of the Taxation Commissioner and the Industry Research and Development Board. When section 73B was introduced into the Income Tax Assessment Act, the Government made it very clear that the Commissioner would never have the power to determine what qualified as research and development but that this would be the sole responsibility of the Industry Research and Development Board.

Now, under the definition of `eligible research and development goods', one of the conditions which has to be satisfied is that the goods are for use by a person being either a goods producer or an eligible research and development entity. The Industry Research and Development Board is responsible for determining what constitutes an eligible research and development entity, but I imagine that the Commissioner is responsible for determining who is a goods producer.

I would suggest that for the original intent of section 73B to be upheld, it will be necessary for section 10(1)(a) of this Bill to be amended to include a goods producer and an eligible research and development entity. Once again I would be interested to have the Minister's advice on this matter; if he agrees, we could move an amendment. I think it could be easily facilitated.

The broad thrust of the March statement of the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, was that he was going to do something for goods producers and exporters in this country. The clearly stated intention of that statement and several others made around that time was that we had to be more competitive to overcome the problems inherent in our taxation system and in other matters. This Government has attempted to do this by providing exemptions under this Bill, but that system has not worked and will never satisfactorily work under the wholesale sales tax regime which the Government insists upon imposing upon this country.

Although this Bill is not opposed by the Opposition, my colleague Senator Short will move amendments to it when he addresses the legislation. However, that will only serve, I think, to complicate the Bill before us, which is already a very complex and complicated piece of legislation. The sales tax laws of this country are crying out for simplification, and this will not be realised until the current Hawke led Labor Government is replaced by a forward looking coalition government which can provide some direction to this country and the necessary taxation base to improve the lot of goods producers and exporters in the form of a goods and services tax. I thank the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating in the Senate Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991. This is path breaking legislation. It represents a major initiative by the Hawke Labor Government to exempt an increased range of inputs—items used in production by business—from the wholesale sales tax that we have in Australia. It is a major path breaking piece of legislation to help lower business costs. It is a direct result of the March industry statement brought down by the Government. I am pleased to say that I support this legislation wholly. It is vitally important, and it is a major initiative for Australian business.

PARA.TAB: The present sales tax is a wholesale tax levied at the wholesale level or on the last import point if products are brought in from overseas.
