Basically it is a system with three tax rates: a 10 per cent rate, a 20 per cent rate and a 30 per cent rate. Of course, there is a range of exempt goods under the sales tax arrangements. It is a tax which focuses essentially on physical products. It almost wholly exempts services, the intangible part of our economy, from sales tax.

One of the advantages of having a wholesale sales tax with varying rates is that it can be selective and can be used to target items. It can be used as a policy weapon to focus the tax at higher rates on luxury goods; for example, the present sales tax rate on luxury motor vehicles retailing for over $45,400 is 30 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —You hit $50,000 after a while, didn't you?

—Because it is a selective tax, one that can be targeted, it has the enormous social advantage of exempting the basic necessities of life from tax. The basic food items consumed in the Australian economy—clothing and footwear—are completely exempt from tax as a result of this tax having a range of rates and, therefore, making it possible for governments to say, `The basic staples of life, the basic necessities, can be tax exempt but the people with large incomes, who can afford to buy luxury goods, can afford to pay a higher rate so they are taxed at a 30 per cent rate'.

PARA.TAB: One of the interesting things about the wholesale sales tax is that its impact on final selling prices depends on profit and business mark-ups and margins in the commercial sector. One of the misconceptions around the place at the moment is that somehow a 20 per cent wholesale sales tax automatically leads to a higher price than a 15 per cent retail tax. I notice that some people opposite seem to believe that if the current 20 per cent wholesale sales tax on items is replaced with a 15 per cent value added tax or, in their sanitised language, a goods and services tax, prices in the Australian economy will fall. That is a nonsense. It depends on profit mark-up. It is very simple to show that the final selling price of a business with a 40 per cent mark-up will be higher with a 15 per cent goods and services tax—or, as I call it, a value added tax—than with a 20 per cent wholesale sales tax.

Anything above a 40 per cent margin will lead to higher prices and higher inflation as a result of the introduction of a value added tax. That is one of the reasons that errors and mistakes have been made in the Opposition's calculations of the inflationary impact of this so-called tax swap, the proposal to substitute $27 billion value added tax for $9 billion wholesale sales tax. In fact, one error the Opposition has made is to assume that a 20 per cent sales tax has a larger effect on selling prices than does a 15 per cent value added tax. Of course, that is a nonsense; it depends totally on the profit margins. In many sections of the Australian economy, where there is less competition and firms and producers have less market power, there are much larger margins. In a number of sectors of the economy, 100 per cent mark-ups are very common. A goods and services tax rate of 15 per cent would lead to a massively higher level of selling prices than would a 20 per cent wholesale sales tax.

One of the great advantages of the present wholesale sales tax is that it is a very simple tax. Administratively it is a very cheap, very simple and very efficient tax; in fact, it is incredibly efficient compared with taxes such as value added taxes. It is interesting to note that there are about 75,000 collection points for the wholesale sales tax in Australia at present. Because it is a wholesale sales tax, it is collected only from wholesalers or importers, of which there is a relatively small number in Australia, compared with the number of businesses. It may well be that we have over one million businesses in the Australian economy.

The Opposition's plan to replace this tax with a value added tax means that virtually every one of those one million-plus businesses would be a collection point for the tax and there would be paperwork and red tape involved as a result of the proposed tax. One of the important things to notice about the wholesale sales tax is how focused it is as a tax. For example, figures that I have seen quoted by a large accounting practice in

SPEECH.PARA: Australia suggest that a mere 284 taxpaying units contribute about 48 per cent of the entire revenue collected by the wholesale sales tax. These are not my figures, they are figures from one of the five big accounting companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —It still doesn't make it any fairer.

—It is a very efficient tax. I would have thought that Senator Panizza, as a farmer, would understand that if taxes are collected from a small number of taxpaying units in large amounts of money, the overhead costs and the costs of transactions are very low in relation to collections.

PARA.TAB: I will just go through it. If we look at the last annual report of the Australian Taxation Office, we see just how efficient and cheap the wholesale sales tax is to collect. The last figures show that it costs only 49c to collect every $100 of revenue. It is a very efficient tax. The yardstick in Australia for years has been personal income tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has a skewing effect across the economy.

—I will deal with that in a moment and I will make it very clear that it has a minimal effect on the economy—one that has been overstated in the Opposition's rhetoric to the point where the Opposition believes that it has a major effect on the Australian economy, but that is just not true.

PARA.TAB: Getting back to the efficiency of the wholesale sales tax, it costs only 49c to collect every $100 of revenue. As I have pointed out, the yardstick has always been personal income tax. I understand that the costs of collection are about $1 for every $100 of revenue collected. Let us look overseas at the conservative Government in the United Kingdom, which those opposite worship. It has operated a value added tax for many years at increasingly escalating rates. One point that comes through about the United Kingdom's value added tax—the one that the Liberals here want to copy—is that it costs $2 to collect every $100 of revenue. On the one hand we have a very efficient and simple wholesale sales tax which at present costs 49c to collect $100; on the other hand, the value added tax—the one that the Liberals want to copy—costs $2 to collect every $100 of revenue. So there is a lot more red tape and paperwork involved in that tax.

I was very interested to read a major statement on tax reform made by John Howard, the last Liberal Treasurer in Australia, to the House of Representatives on 12 March 1981. I was particularly interested to read page 766. He got onto the subject of value added tax—the tax the Liberals call a GST, but basically it is a VAT levied at multistages, all stages, of production right through the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know the difference? You don't even know the difference.
—I am afraid that Senator Knowles does not know the difference. I would like to quote Mr John Howard's words—
—Are you saying it is not a value added tax?
—I am saying that this galah does not know the difference.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Order! Senator Maguire has the floor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I quote Mr Howard, I refer to the fact that Senator Knowles made the most inane comment that I have heard in this place for a long time. We had an urgency debate on this subject last Wednesday. Senator Knowles said to the assembled gathering in the Senate that we had to have a VAT, we had to have a tax on food, because that is how people would have personal income tax cuts. That is just the most tortuous, inane logic. Senator Knowles is going around Australia saying that we must have a tax on food so that people can have income tax cuts. What a crazy proposition. Think of the administration costs of doing those two things.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I will probably make a personal explanation after this outrageous contribution by Senator Maguire. I ask you to at least request him to tell the truth and not misrepresent what I said last week.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Any interested senator can easily pick up a copy of Hansard of last Wednesday and read the debate on the urgency motion. I read it avidly yesterday. It is a great read. I recommend Senator Knowles's speech to anybody. It is the most tortuous logic I have ever seen in the tax field. She said that the Australian people had to have a tax on food, in the form of a value added tax—the so-called sanitised GST—so that they can have income tax cuts. That is what she said. That is what she told the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: However, I have been a bit distracted and I move on to what the last Liberal Treasurer, John Howard, said about VAT. It is very illuminating to see what he said on page 766 of Hansard of 12 March 1981. He was referring to the multi-stage VAT that the Liberals wanted to bring into Australia. Mr Howard said this in his speech after looking at the various tax reforms options:

SPEECH.PARA: A multi-stage VAT was rejected fairly quickly because it would have imposed an enormous paper work burden on both taxpayers and collecting authorities.

That was John Howard, the last Liberal Treasurer in Australia. This was his official statement as Treasurer in the Fraser Liberal Government canvassing every one of the options for tax reform in Australia. I recommend this speech to everybody as a wonderful read. Mr Howard rejected the VAT proposal, which the Liberals are now embracing, on the grounds of an enormous paperwork burden on both taxpayers and collecting authorities. The present wholesale sales tax is an extraordinarily simple tax. It costs 49c to collect $100 and 284 taxpayers contribute 48 per cent of the revenue. What an efficient tax.

PARA.TAB: I would like to go on, because at the moment I am just getting warmed up to my task. This very illuminating speech from Mr Howard went on to talk about the options for tax reform. He also said this, as recorded on page 766:

SPEECH.PARA: We concluded that therefore, if we were to broaden the indirect tax base—
that is what the Liberals are talking about now with this new goods and services tax—
the simplest method would be to extend the existing wholesale sales tax to some goods now exempt and to impose a tax on selected services.

It was not Bob Hawke saying this; it was not John Kerin or anybody in the Government. This was John Howard, the last Liberal Treasurer in Australia, rejecting outright, conclusively and unconditionally in one paragraph the concepts of a value added tax. (Quorum formed) Before I was interrupted by that quorum call, which is basically a procedural device to try to stop me from making my points, I was dissecting speeches made by Liberals. I started with Senator Knowles and dispensed with her very quickly. I then moved on to the last Liberal Treasurer of Australia, John Howard. I was actually using his words to show how he pre-emptively rejected the whole idea of a goods and services tax on both administrative and collection costs grounds.

PARA.TAB: I now move on to Senator Watson, who was the last speaker in this debate. Senator Watson claimed that somehow sales tax has a significant impact on the Australian economy; that it has a big impact on business costs and so forth.

TALK.START.PARA: —The word you were using was `cascading'.

—I will use the word `cascading' later on. I know that it is a Tasmanian word, but I will get on to that in a while. I regularly read Taxpayer, the journal of Mr Eric Risstrom, the principal of the Australian Taxpayers Association. In a recent issue, Mr Risstrom made the point that the present sales tax has a very minimal effect on the Australian economy. He looked at various categories of Australian households, looked at their income categories, and pointed out that only 25 to 30 per cent of the expenditure of average Australian households is actually subject to the current sales tax.
—It has a cascading effect on business.

—But when one actually looks at the expenditure of Australian households, the average people in our community, one sees that only 25 to 30 per cent of what they spend is actually affected by sales tax. Eric Risstrom is really saying that only $1 in every $4 of the expenditure of the average Australian household actually goes on sales tax goods. That is one way of looking at the low effects on the Australian economy of this particular tax.

PARA.TAB: The legislation before us today gives effect to the measures in the March industry statement. It exempts from sales tax a wider range of inputs into business production. It will help lower business costs and farm costs by taking out a range of inputs from the sales tax system.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about transport? What about mentioning all the sales taxes on transport?

—Senator Walters will probably be next. I have just demolished three of her colleagues and there is more on the list yet. This particular legislation will cost the revenue $200m this financial year, which is very significant, rising to $375m next year. That is forgone sales tax revenue from the Budget.

PARA.TAB: Senator Watson used the term `cascading'. That is important: by taking these sales taxes off inputs we have a magnified effect in lowering business costs. The impact on business costs is not the loss of revenue to the Budget and it is not the $200m this financial year and the $375m next financial year; the figures which come out of the business cost structure are magnified because of the impact of profit mark-ups and margins on the base, including the tax. If we remove the tax, we lower the base on which the mark-ups are made. This financial year we will see an impact with lower business costs of about $400m, rising to some $700m next financial year.

I was delighted to see recently an article written by a prominent Brisbane tax expert, Mr Darryl Somerville, from the Coopers and Lybrand partnership in Brisbane. In the Courier-Mail on 25 November this year, in an article entitled `Changes to sales tax could save up to $454m', Mr Somerville was in fine form. He pointed out that this legislation brought in by the Hawke Labor Government in fact represented `the greatest changes to business inputs since 1945'.

He has really identified this tax as having the greatest impact on business costs since 1945 in reducing costs by removing the sales tax. That is how he views the legislation. He went on to say that the tax changes `should make Australian mining, manufacturing and primary industries more competitive'. Here we have an independent observer of this reform making a clear and concise statement about his view of how it will affect business. I notice that clause 8 of the legislation provides for a refund of sales tax collected since the industry statement, so basically any purchases since that time will not be subject to the sales tax.

One of the important things about this measure is that it will improve net returns for a number of Australian producers and a number of businesses. For example, as a result of this proposal the farm sector will see a lower cost structure and its net returns will be greater. Similarly, those firms in the traded goods sector of the Australian economy—those firms competing with imports—will see a lower cost structure as the sales taxes are taken off the inputs into their production, and that will help their competition with imported products. Those are some of the items in the Bill.

A range of items of production will be exempted. Goods used in activities such as the storage, handling and dispatch of products will be sales tax exempt. The Bill provides for this by bringing in a definition of eligible business goods. A range of products such as lubricants, office equipment, stationery and hand tools will be exempt from sales tax as a result of this legislation. Road vehicles used wholly within production premises will also be exempt from the tax.

I must say that I am delighted to see that this legislation does not exempt luxury cars from sales tax. This is the great difference between this legislation of the Hawke Labor Government and the proposal from those opposite. They would take the 30 per cent sales tax off luxury motor vehicles and replace it with a 15 per cent goods and services tax—or, as I have pointed out, a 15 per cent value added tax. I think that is totally unjustifiable.

We refuse to go down that road of making luxury motor vehicles vastly cheaper in the Australian economy. It is just ridiculous for the Liberals to say that their proposal to bring in a 15 per cent value added tax would somehow benefit Australia's overseas balance of payments. The mind boggles as to how the balance of payments would be helped by making luxury motor vehicles cheaper by bringing in a 15 per cent value added tax, instead of having a 30 per cent wholesale sales tax on them. It would simply make a range of models of luxury motor vehicles vastly cheaper and, therefore, would lead to a kick-start in imports to Australia.

I would like to turn very briefly to the Treasury analysis of the impact of sales tax on the Australian economy. Again, Senator Watson was going on earlier that somehow the sales tax had a major, significant or draconian effect on the Australian economy. We have to put it in context. The sales tax collects only $9,000m in an economy of nearly $400 billion. That gives some idea in broad terms, on the back of an envelope, of just how insignificant the sales tax is in terms of the total economy.

The Treasury has done an econometric analysis, looking at sales tax and its impact on business costs. It has come up with the conclusion that the impact is minimal. Despite the rhetoric, the hype and the noise from those opposite that somehow the sales tax is an intrusive, wide, costly tax, the Treasury econometric model points out that it has a very minimal impact on business inputs, it has a minimal impact on exports and it certainly does not lead to significant distortions between sectors of the Australian economy.

The Treasury model looked at 109 different industry categories in Australia and, overall, it identified that the present sales tax added less than 2 per cent to the cost of business inputs. So it added less than one-fiftieth to the cost of business inputs. Very few sectors were above the 2 per cent average. Certainly, all parts of manufacturing that were looked at in the Treasury model had an extra impact on costs of below 2 per cent. With regard to exports, despite the rhetoric of the Liberals and the claims that somehow sales tax punishes exports, the Treasury model showed very clearly that the sales tax added only about 1 1/4 per cent to input costs into export products. So it is not a draconian tax; sales tax adds in only a minor way to the cost of business inputs.

I believe that the best way to help Australian business compete is to reform the existing Australian tax system—to review the system regularly, to examine it and to reform the existing system where necessary. That is the simplest way to go. We do not need a new tax in Australia, we do not need a new tax to help the export sector and we do not need a value added tax. The best way to reform taxes in Australia is to reform the existing tax system. Again I refer the Senate to that very interesting quote from Mr John Howard, the last Liberal Treasurer, in 1981, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We concluded that therefore, if we were to broaden the indirect tax base, the simplest method would be to extend the existing wholesale sales tax to some goods now exempt and to impose a tax on selected services.

That was the last Liberal Treasurer of Australia; it was not a Labor Treasurer who said that. That is the way to go. We do not need a massive increase in red tape in Australia. The last thing Australian business needs is an upsurge in paperwork.

TALK.START.PARA: —The business community supports it.

—I can tell Senator Patterson that the proposal put forward by the Opposition for a value added tax will involve two pieces of paperwork for every transaction. Australian business is going to be strangled by red tape if the Liberals ever get into government to implement this loony campaign for a value added tax. The reality is that those opposite are trying to bring in a very complex tax to administer—a tax which will be costly to collect. As I have pointed out, the evidence from the United Kingdom is that under the conservatives over there—whom the Opposition worships—the value added tax costs about $2 for every $100 collected; the wholesale sales tax, which we are reforming today as a result of this legislation, costs only 49c to collect every $100.
—To whom, though?

—It is a very simple tax. As a farmer, Senator Panizza should understand that this is a very efficient tax. It is no surprise that Mr John Howard in 1981, in his major tax statement to the Australian Parliament, rejected outright the whole idea of VAT—a goods and services tax or, as it is commonly known, a consumption tax—because of the massive collection costs to both the taxpayers themselves and the taxpaying authorities.

PARA.TAB: A new tax is hardly a top 10 issue in Australia at the present time. The last thing Australia needs is a new tax. A new tax is not a national priority. We do not need a new tax: we do not need a new tax to help Australian business; and we do not need a new tax to help Australian exports. The simplest way to go, as Mr John Howard said so eloquently in Parliament on 12 March 1981, is to reform the existing tax system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose it is not unexpected to find a list of 10 Opposition speakers on the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). It was meant to be a simple sales tax amendment Bill but, obviously, in the present political context, it is not unexpected that we will have 10 Opposition speakers extolling the value of the GST and talking about the—
—If you look at the list you will see—

—We did have a debate yesterday. We have Question Times to talk about these subjects; we have censure motions; we have MPIs; and we have second reading amendments to every piece of legislation that comes before this House. While it would have been good just to talk about this Bill, quite obviously we are going to have a wide ranging debate on the drawbacks of the wholesale sales tax and the virtues of a goods and services tax. Of course, I will want to make a few general points in that debate as well.

PARA.TAB: The Bill before us today arises from the March industry statement. It has taken nine months for the Senate to see this legislation, which is backdated to 12 March. The Bill has two purposes: firstly, to broaden considerably the existing sales tax exemptions which are enjoyed by manufacturing, mining and primary production businesses in respect of business inputs; and, secondly, it substantially addresses the legitimate criticism that the wholesale sales tax imposes an uncompetitive cost burden on businesses relative to imports from countries which levy a goods and services tax which zero rates exports from those countries.

This is not to say that we have to demolish the whole wholesale sales tax regime to deal with that legitimate criticism. There are a number of aspects about a wholesale sales tax which, in fact, are appealing. Senator Maguire has pointed to some of them. The collection of wholesale sales tax is very efficient because there are only 70,000 registered taxpayers. This means that the great majority of small businesses do not have to register—

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot believe this. She said she was going to speak on the Bill.

—I said that I am going to speak on the philosophy and on the Bill—which, I suspect, is more than Senator Panizza will do. The majority of small businesses do not have to register with the Commissioner of Taxation and, thus, are not burdened by the large compliance load which a universal goods and services tax would impose. In addition to the compliance costs which a GST would impose on the business sector, the administrative load on the Tax Office will increase enormously. This will simply mean more of those dreaded public servants. This is acknowledged in the Fightback document.

PARA.TAB: The question of the uniformity and breadth of the tax base seems to have consumed the Opposition. It is saying that even the necessities of life must be taxed so as to keep the GST system simple. Simplicity is everything. At the same time, the Opposition is proposing an incredibly complex set of supposedly compensatory taxation measures. The Democrats say that if a GST is to be implemented, equity requires compensatory arrangements. We have the usual trade-off between equity and, in the Opposition's case, simplicity. For the Democrats, equity should prevail. This is exactly the position we have taken with regard to taxing the necessities of life. The zero rating of food will make a GST more complex than it otherwise would be. However, the Democrats argue that the costs of such a change are more than outweighed by the obvious fairness.

The Opposition has already said that it will zero rate health and education services. Therefore, to be consistent, I think it could agree to the exemption of the necessities of life. This should be more important to a caring government than the fear of opening up a Pandora's box of inconsistencies and anomalies. The model is more important to the Opposition than are human needs.

The final measures before us today are broader than those which were originally announced by Mr Keating. Exemption will be extended to goods used in production related to activities such as research and development or engineering and technical design of goods or production processes. I presume that this will cover the design and installation of energy efficiency measures. I ask Senator McMullan to confirm this for the Senate. Other production related activities to benefit from exemption will be mine site rehabilitation; the transport of goods by rail, pipeline or conveyor between production premises; certain storage facilities and ports; and other ancillary activities which affect the efficiency of the production process, such as the training of production staff, accident prevention, pollution control, lighting or cleaning of production premises and the scheduling or costing of production.

The Bill also grants an exemption to research and development entities, such as cooperative research centres, where they are involved in researching or developing new or improved Australian goods or production processes. What is wrong with that? It is a good idea. Sea cargo and international air cargo handlers will also receive exemption for goods used in cargo handling and for ancillary and supporting activities. Subcontractors will be entitled to an exemption for equipment where the goods producer would have been entitled had it purchased the equipment, thereby expanding and clarifying the exemption regime which applies to subcontractors. This will simplify the substitution of subcontractors into the production process, where the producer wishes to do that, by removing the sales tax penalty which would otherwise have applied in some circumstances. This is what the Opposition wants, but it says that it will arrive at this point by another means. This will thereby assist some firms to maximise efficiency. The Democrats support this.

In addition, certain other items are to be made exempt from sales tax by removing the current restriction on their being exempt, even though they are used in qualifying circumstances. There are three categories of these goods: lubricants, motor vehicles when used within or between contiguous production premises, and general office equipment and consumables.

This last category of items brings me to a disagreement which the Democrats have with the proposal contained within the legislation. In general, the allowance of an exemption in respect of consumables used in mining, manufacturing and primary production is supported. However, we have to put these exemptions in the context of sustainable development. The Democrats maintain that certain products which are environmentally superior should be assisted via the tax system. The granting of preferential tax treatment to sustainable products—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is going to define that?

—There is not one word about sustainability in the package. The granting of preferential tax treatment to sustainable products or punitive tax treatment to undesirable products is an important yet under-utilised aspect of the wholesale sales tax which the Democrats support. The classic example in this regard is recycled paper. Because the Government finally picked up a Democrat initiative and used discriminatory tax policy to promote the use of recycled paper products, Australia now has a thriving recycled paper industry and a more environmentally conscious community. Senator McMullan obviously agrees with this principle, judging from the article in his name which appeared in the Sunday edition of the Canberra Times.
—A very good article, too.

—Yes, but there is an inconsistency. The article, quite correctly, points out the public policy benefits of a selective differential rate system of taxing consumption. Indeed, the Opposition's decision to increase the rate of excise on tobacco products recognises this fact anyway. Senator McMullan stated in his column:

PARA.TAB: I have mentioned in previous articles that one of the positive aspects of the current sales-tax system is its ability to discriminate between items.
Environmentally friendly products such as recycled paper and solar panels are now sales-tax exempt. This gives them a price advantage over other less environmentally friendly products.

SPEECH.PARA: That is, sustainable development is enhanced by this form of assistance and it should continue. I do not have the faith that it will continue under a goods and services tax regime. The proposed exemption in this Bill for consumables includes paper and stationery. If this proposal is enacted, it will mean that that relative price differential which applies to paper and stationery made from recycled pulp as opposed to virgin pulp will be eliminated for the very large mining, manufacturing and primary production sectors. Obviously, this will tend to reduce the demand for recycled paper products in these sectors, which is surely an unintended consequence of this legislation. If it is not, Senator McMullan is today defending legislation which eliminates the price differential he enthusiastically supported a couple of days ago in the Canberra Times.

PARA.TAB: One of the problems with a universal single rate taxation regime, such as the Opposition's proposed GST, is that no public policy considerations are reflected in the pricing of goods. No doubt the Government will be stressing this important point in future debate on the package. But, at the same time, today the Government is inadvertently undermining this important principle with respect to recycled paper in this Bill. I think it is important that this flaw is brought to the attention of the Senate.

The Democrats wish to see an expanded use of this principle in other areas. We have moved amendments in this place to exempt other desirable products such as electric motor cars, wind generators, recycled plastic products and certain aids and appliances for disabled people. Further items which should be preferentially treated include road safety equipment, such as protective airbags and child restraints in motor vehicles, and certain items of waste disposal equipment.

In past sales tax debates we have seen the Labor Party voting with the Opposition to defeat these worthwhile proposals, but now it claims to have some credibility on this issue. The Government voted against our original proposal to exempt recycled paper and then announced it in a subsequent statement. The same principle is relevant in our recently announced decision to oppose the imposition of any tax, whether it be a sales tax or a goods and services tax, on the essentials of life—that is, food, clothing and some residential building materials. We apply to any tax regime the twin tests of fairness and sustainability. We have been consistent in this regard for more than a decade.

Treasury has estimated that the changes in this Bill will have a positive effect on the competitiveness of Australian firms and that this will translate into an increase in exports of $113m per annum. Whilst the exact effect will only be seen over time, I do not think there is any doubt that the moves will be positive. The cost of the Bill is estimated to be $240m in the current year and $445m in 1992-93. The overall benefit to Australian business is estimated by the Treasury at over $1 billion when the flow-on of reduced costs at the various stages of the production process are taken into account.

Hopefully, these measures will lead to some job generation to alleviate some of the misery caused by the Government's deliberately engineered recession. The Democrats know that placing sole reliance on private investment to produce sustainable jobs is a policy doomed to failure, especially during a period of very low consumer and business confidence. The Opposition's answer to create these desperately needed jobs is to introduce a new tax on everything and then `incentivation' will do the rest.

Tim Colebatch recently pointed out in the Age that the Opposition's conviction that lowering income tax leads people to working harder has been proved to be sheer nonsense in both the United States—that great paragon—and Australia. He asks: `Hands up all of those who have worked harder because of the 1985 income tax cuts'. What about, `Hands up all those who have worked harder because of the $5 billion worth of personal tax cuts provided by this Government in 1989'?

Under the Opposition's neo-classical economic reasoning, we should have seen a massive outbreak in productivity and extra work effort because of those tax cuts, but at the same time the Opposition has complained in this place about what it describes as Australia's poor productivity performance during the last decade. The tax cuts have been there; it has not followed necessarily that everyone works harder because of that.

The world is not a simple economic model where human beings react on cue as programmed. I think this is one of the fundamental flaws of the Fightback package. The wholesale sales tax is not perfect. However, this Bill does address a legitimate criticism of the structure of the tax and it will lead to a more efficient system for Australia's business community, impending goods and services tax or not.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). We have been waiting for this Bill since 12 March—a long time—when the Government's industry statement was brought down. The Government received a lot of kudos for proposing to extend the exemption on sales tax to a lot of goods. Unfortunately, nine months down the track, we are still in the throes of putting the legislation through to be able to put those measures into place. We do not know when we will get royal assent on the Bill. If that is not forthcoming until next year, quite easily 12 months will have passed since the Government's statement was delivered last March.

PARA.TAB: The emphasis of the Bill is to exempt some of the production goods that used to attract wholesale sales tax. Sales tax was imposed generally in the final production stages whereas it will now be moved into the pre-production stages to include most of the pre-production costs. As the Bill says, that includes research, development, engineering or technical design which have not been there before. It also includes the production related phases—ordering of goods, controlling of the cost production process and maintaining the environment around new activities. The Australian Democrats have made a big play about the environment. Damage to the environment has come from expanded mining activities. Now that we have a corporate tax on gold production, it is only right that these sorts of measures be extended to the goldmining industry in order to rehabilitate sites. Incidentally, the mining industry is doing it much better than the Democrats in this place or any other place might think.

There have been quite a few changes in the post-production stage, including storage, handling and dispatch. Transport is mentioned as one of the measures. An important change is the sales tax exemption on transport of goods by rail, pipeline or conveyor between production premises, but not on the transport that leaves the premises, which in the present situation is only right.

The biggest step forward on primary industry is to reverse the decision imposed by Senator Peter Walsh in his capacity as the Minister for Finance some years ago. There was a sales tax put on lubricants used in the rural industry. That tax was put in place only recently, in 1985. I saw no rationale for it at the time because some lubricants were included and some were not. If one had a loader, a tractor or something similar, the lubricant in the engine was not exempt whereas the lubricant in the transmission—about 10 centimetres to the rear of the engine—was exempt. There were stupid anomalies like that all over the place. It is time the Government got rid of them.

Senator Walsh's rationale at the time was that that lubricant—diesel or engine oil—could be used in another vehicle. In my experience, if one uses that sort of oil left, right and centre in an ordinary petrol engine car, not only will the vehicle start burning oil but also it will smoke the streets out. This exemption has also been extended to consumables, office furniture and road vehicles used only on site. Road vehicles that are used on a farming site have been exempt for quite a long time. The four-wheel drive version with table top carriers have been there a long time. But it is certainly time it was extended to mining sites.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the comments made by former Prime Minister Whitlam about the Hawke Government's foreign policy that Prime Minister Hawke is `a media and poll driven politician' whose `performances for domestic consumption have made it impossible for him to visit China, Malaysia and Fiji' and that, despite his speed on the phone to President Bush, he is unable to directly contact the President of a neighbouring country. I ask: would Australia have had more influence in relation to Indonesia if Mr Hawke had taken time off from his grandstanding on such issues as I have mentioned—and South Africa—to visit Indonesia at least once in the last eight years?

—It is a matter of fact that Gough Whitlam himself established a very good relationship with the Indonesian Government and had a strong personal relationship with President Suharto. That was of general benefit to Australia and to Gough Whitlam's credit. However, it has also to be acknowledged that there are limits to the extent to which that kind of personal relationship can produce results.

PARA.TAB: Mr Whitlam, after all, has told us constantly that his own attitude towards the East Timorese question was one of very strong support for an act of self-determination and very strong resistance—a very strong opposition—to any use of force by Indonesia in East Timor. Manifestly, all the personal relationships in the world that might have existed between Mr Whitlam and President Suharto did not stop the annexation of East Timor by Indonesia occurring without any act of self-determination and with the use of force. I think that is a healthy corrective to any suggestion that personal relationships by themselves can achieve miracles when other dynamics are at work.

Prime Minister Hawke himself has shown very strong, very close, very substantial and a very continuing personal interest in the development of the bilateral relationship. His very first overseas visit as Prime Minister included a visit to Indonesia. There have been many instances since when he has tried to find holes in his program to take forward that personal relationship and, of course, he does have another visit planned there for early next year.

We have made a very substantial and vigorous series of attempts to build a broad-ranging relationship between the two countries in a variety of ways that I have often spelt out on the record before. The nature and character of that relationship is indicated by the fact, I guess, that notwithstanding the tension which presently exists over the East Timorese question, the Indonesian Government has been very willing and receptive to receive me visiting there next week—as I will be doing—when there will be ample opportunity to canvass these issues in detail.

Meanwhile, the Indonesian Government can be in no doubt at all about where Mr Hawke and the Australian Government generally stand on this issue as a result of a number of quite specific and quite substantial contributions that have been made to the debate on this subject and also, of course, the personal communication that the Prime Minister has had with the Indonesian Ambassador to Australia, Sabam Siagian.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and also relates to Australian relations with Indonesia. Has the Minister seen the article in the Bulletin of 10 December entitled `Uranium Sales to Indonesia Proposed'? Is it the case that the Australian Government has taken steps to facilitate the sale of Australian uranium to Indonesia? Is the article based on correct assumptions?

—I have seen the article to which Senator Loosley refers. The information which the Bulletin's investigation purports to reveal has been on the public record for some time, not least as a result of answers which I gave to questions in the Senate in June of this year. There have been discussions since late 1990 between Australian and Indonesian officials on a nuclear science and technology cooperation agreement. The objective of such an agreement would be to enhance existing and mutually beneficial scientific and technological cooperation in the peaceful nuclear field, including such areas as nuclear safety, nuclear medicine and radiation protection.

PARA.TAB: Indonesia is a party to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and, pursuant to its NPT obligations, has a full scope safeguards agreement with the International Atomic Energy Agency covering its existing and future nuclear activities. The agreement in question would not, if it were to be negotiated to fruition—as I have said before and as, indeed, the article itself notes, despite the misleading title —provide for commercial transfers of Australian uranium to Indonesia.

The possibility of future commercial transfers is foreshadowed in the draft agreement, but if such sales were proposed a bilateral safeguards agreement which meets all Australia's safeguards policy requirements would need to be in place, and there have been no negotiations with Indonesia on any such agreement. In any event, Indonesia would not be operating a nuclear power plant before the early years of the next century at the earliest, and I am not aware of any current Indonesian plans for the importation of uranium for power generation in that context. Discussions on the nuclear cooperation agreement are continuing and an agreement has not yet been finalised.

As I have also said before, the Government will give consideration to the steps it might take to review aspects of the bilateral relationship and bilateral contacts in the light of the outcome of the Indonesian inquiry into the killings in East Timor, but, as I have also said, it would be quite inappropriate for us to assume at this stage that that inquiry will not be a credible one. It is in that context that this proposed agreement could be looked at, like everything else, but at this stage there is no reason whatsoever to assume that it will be.

Finally, the article makes a series of allegations about the environmental and other risks of Indonesia's nuclear power program, in respect of which I think the following comments need to be made. Indonesia, which is facing diminishing oil reserves, has made decisions about the energy mix it needs to meet its future requirements on the basis of careful study. Australia respects Indonesia's sovereign right to make such decisions, just as we have the sovereign right to make similar decisions. I do not see such risks, as alleged, from the tightly regulated nuclear power program using the latest Western technology which Indonesia is planning, as anything like as severe or as substantial as those which were identified in the article, although there is of course no room for complacency about nuclear developments anywhere.

Finally, Australia, together with Indonesia and others, is working through the International Atomic Energy Agency to achieve the highest safety and non-proliferation standards for peaceful nuclear activities wherever those activities take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate.
—Acting.

—Acting Leader. The Minister would be aware that Mr Ralph Willis was sacked from his position of shadow Treasurer on 14 January 1983 by the Leader of the Opposition at that time, the then Mr Bill Hayden, because Mr Willis had `poor communication skills'. As a consequence, can the Minister inform the Senate why the new Treasurer, the same Mr Ralph Willis, MP, is better qualified than his predecessor, Mr Kerin, who was sacked by the Prime Minister last Friday for exactly the same reason—poor communication skills? Does this appointment indicate that the previous boast by the Prime Minister about the terrific depth of talent in the Government is nothing other than hollow rhetoric and that the only option open to the Government is to recycle yesterday's failures?

—Most of us in this life are capable of improving on the job, of lifting our game, of learning from our experience and of building upon our weaknesses. The only people to whom that generalisation does not apply, in my long experience in this place, are the members of the Opposition, and Senator Walters in particular.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of delegates to the Asia-Pacific Parliamentary Forum which is meeting in Parliament House today. The delegation is led by the Chairman of the Steering Committee and former Prime Minister of Japan, Mr Nakasone. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome the delegates to the Senate and to Australia. I trust that their deliberations today will serve to enhance relations among all countries of our region.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of any hidden strings in the Opposition's policies as contained in the consumption tax proposal, particularly as it relates to industrial issues, which would have detrimental implications for the living standards of working people? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether the Federal Government should consider the implementation of proposals with a similar effect and, if not, why not?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question that has been asked by Senator Burns is entirely about the Opposition's policies. I suggest that if the honourable senator wants to know what the Opposition intends to do, he should address the question to the Leader of the Opposition and not to the Minister, who does not know what the Opposition's policies are. I have yet to meet one Minister who has even read the document.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—What we do know about the consumption tax proposition of the Opposition is that it imposes a 15 per cent goods and services tax on everything that we buy. It gives tax cuts which favour the rich and penalise middle and low income Australians. The hidden nasty in this package is that it drives down real wages in this country.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Already the Minister is seeking to debate the Opposition's package, rather than answer questions which relate to his own portfolio. That is contrary to the Standing Orders. We have raised this matter with you every day for the last two weeks. I raise it again. You require us to comply with the Standing Orders and I ask that you require Government members to comply with them as well.
—Order! I have not yet heard enough of Senator Cook's answer to decide whether he is in breach of the Standing Orders.

—This Government will not accept this package because it contains the thinly disguised nasty that sets out to create in Australia a low wage, low income society. It proposes to drive us down the New Zealand road, to make Australia the Taiwan of the South Pacific. That is what it proposes to do. It is a document of deceit. In its opening pages it complains that real wages in Australia have fallen when in fact real household disposable income per capita in recent years has risen by over 10 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The fine print in the document deliberately plans to seriously cut real wages in this country. How does the Opposition propose to do it? What are the reasons why this Government will not accept this package? The Opposition proposes to bypass the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and to scrap the award system in Australia. Therefore, the umpire is taken out. That means that the minimum protections that workers in this country enjoy are to be removed. The Government will not accept this system because it removes the checks and balances necessary in a democratic society. Under the Opposition's package there will be no role for the Industrial Relations Commission, the umpire in this country, to review individual work contracts that are struck to guarantee that those work contracts are fair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Previously you said that you had not heard enough of Senator Cook's answer. Have you now heard enough to make a decision on whether he is debating the subject?

—Order! I do not think that the Minister is yet debating the subject of the question. He was asked about the implications for Government policy and whether the Government would adopt certain policies. I believe that at this stage he is in order.
—What do they do in Japan? Come on; tell us.
—`What do they do in Japan?' is the interjection.
—Order! I suggest that the Minister not answer the interjections.

—As you direct, Mr President, I will not answer the interjections. There is nothing in this package to stop unscrupulous employers from sacking workers on the grounds that they ought to accept a pay cut and then inviting them back at much lower wages. In fact, there is a positive proposition in this package that encourages employers to sack workers and employ unemployed people at 80 per cent of the minimum rate of the award.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order.
—Sit down, you clown.
—Order!

— In the answer the Minister has insulted both the New Zealand members of the delegation here and the Taiwanese members of the delegation. He now refers to the screwing down of people in the workplace, which is a direct reflection on our guests, and I ask that you instruct him to apologise.
—On the point of order, Mr President: it was only yesterday that we were discussing bogus, argumentative points of order not related to procedures.
—That is a very valid one.

—In taking a point of order one cannot take an argumentative point on the substance; one can only raise a point of procedure. What Senator Crane has done—and I do not single him out—is again a total abuse of this chamber.
—There is no point of order. It was a completely frivolous point of order.

—One of the other reasons why the Government will not accept this package is that it positively encourages employers to sack workers and then re-hire them at 80 per cent of the minimum rate. That is called Austrain. The Opposition justifies it on the alleged basis that this is a training program, when no training at all is required under this program. So this is unique in the world, a so-called training package that does not require training.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I put it to you that on no stretch of the imagination can you say that the Minister is answering a question relating to the administration of his portfolio. He is not doing that. He is debating Opposition policy at a time when that is inappropriate. His task now is to answer questions relating to his portfolio and the administration thereof. I ask you to bring him back within the Standing Orders, in the same way that you require us to ask questions within the Standing Orders.

—Mr President, on the point of order: it is a well accepted practice in this place—as you well know because you have so ruled on many previous occasions—that, provided a question asks whether a particular policy, strategy or program will be picked up and adopted and applied by the Government, then it is absolutely in order for a Minister to reply, in whatever detail he thinks appropriate, stating why that particular policy should not be picked up and adopted by the Government. That is the practice of this place. Senator Hill knows that. Senator Hill is advancing yet another spurious point of order, of which we have had a legion in this place recently. I urge you, Mr President, to exercise the authority of your Chair to rule out these spurious points of order in the future.
—Order! I have listened to the Minister's answer.
—Mr President, on the point of order—
—Order! I am replying to Senator Hill's point of order.

—It is on the point of order, Mr President. The point that Senator Evans just made in arguing on the point of order raised by Senator Hill is quite wrong. I simply refer you to your own ruling of 19 February 1987 when you ruled—and I will again quote it—that you would allow a question on Opposition policy only on the basis that the Minister answers that part of the question which is dealt with in his portfolio and the Government's policy. We have been listening in vain to hear anything about the Government's policy. We would be most enlightened if we could hear something about it.

—Mr President, the point of order raised by Senator Hill is an interesting one because it has now been spoken to by two members of the Opposition. Of course, it is their Question Time in terms of the time that they wish to waste. Mr President, I indicate to you quite clearly that those of us who were listening very closely to the question heard it to read something like this: `Can the Minister advise the Senate whether the Federal Government should consider the implementation of proposals with a similar effect and, if not, why not?' So far, the Minister has looked at the situation. He is describing what he would do and what the Government might do. We have not yet heard the rest of the story. I suggest that at this stage the Minister is very much in order to express his views about the rest of the question.

—Order! In reply to the points of order, I thought that the Minister was in order. I must admit that the answer was becoming long, but it was not helped by the continuous points of order that were being taken. It is very difficult to decide when an answer is going past a certain time and is becoming a debate. When the first point of order was taken, I did not think that that point had been reached. I now call Senator Cook.

—I conclude my answer by saying that the Opposition's package—it is the reason why the Government will not adopt it—exploits the undefended in this community. It seeks to remove the umpire, to remove the element of fairness in the determination of wages and working conditions. It seeks to remove the award system so that the minimum protections—the safety nets necessary—are removed as well.

PARA.TAB: I was asked by way of interjection what happens in Japan. Let me tell those opposite that there are guaranteed rights in the Japanese Constitution that protect the interests of individual workers. Those guarantees are in its Constitution. It is a low disputation country because it recognises the fundamental rights of individuals. It would be a big advance in this country if we could achieve that. We will not accept this package because it is one of more taxes and less pay for Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I refer to the statement made by the ACT Attorney-General in today's Canberra Times in which he says of the security operation for President Bush's visit, `If they expect us to pay, they have got another thing coming'. First, why has the ACT Attorney-General been informed by the Minister's office that security for the Bush visit is his responsibility and should be paid for by the ACT when this event is clearly a Federal Government initiative? Secondly, what plans are there to provide the ACT with additional funding to meet the huge cost of the security operation? Thirdly, can the Minister tell the Senate how much this whole event will be costing the Australian taxpayer during a time of deep recession?

—As to Senator Sowada's last question, it is not within my portfolio responsibility to be able to respond as to the total costs involved in the provision of security for President Bush and his entourage. Quite clearly, when we have the President of the United States visiting this nation, it will be essential to ensure his personal security. We know that there have been attempted assassinations—and a successful assassination—in our own lifetime of United States Presidents. It would be an absolute tragedy if that were to occur on our soil. I can assure Senator Sowada, all other senators and the public of Australia that every measure will be taken that is required to ensure that no security threat is effective against the President of the United States.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, I believe that any security operation mounted in the Australian Capital Territory when President Bush visits this Parliament in particular, and other associated events, will incur expenditure. I believe the national government, and the national component of the Australian Federal Police, has a responsibility to fund the provision of security for President Bush in that regard. Certainly, a national visit—a visit to the national capital, particularly to this Australian Parliament—by President Bush as a guest of the Australian Government implies that the Australian Government rather than the ACT Government should pick up the costs of security associated with his presence in the Australian Capital Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs seen media reports that the High Court has confirmed that State legislation outlawing rape in marriage is valid? Can he comment on how this ruling will protect Australian women from sexual assault and generally increase recognition of Australian women's right to equality in fully consenting relationships?

—Senator Reynolds does raise a very important matter. The High Court, by unanimous decision earlier this month, confirmed the validity of State laws which make it clear that a crime of rape can be committed by a husband in marriage. The suggested principle that a husband cannot be guilty of rape of his wife has been completely thrown out by the highest judicial tribunal in this nation.

PARA.TAB: The purported principle that a husband could not rape his wife apparently has its origins back in the seventeenth century when Sir Matthew Hale asserted, in his History of Pleas of the Crown, the existence of what he called `an irrebuttable presumption that a wife, by her marriage, irrevocably consents to sexual intercourse with her husband'. Quite clearly, that simply reduces the wife to either an object of the sexual gratification of the husband or just a vehicle for the production of descendants—preferably male descendants—in that sort of society. I believe that is a totally anachronistic way of regarding the marriage partnership in our Australian society. It is very appropriate that the highest court in our country has now unequivocally rejected that particular proposition.

I believe that the consensual nature of marriage in this respect has been reinforced by the High Court, and I am sure that it will lead to a further change of our culture so that the use of force within the domestic setting can be regarded properly as criminal violence. The euphemism `domestic violence' should not be used. We are talking about criminal violence within the household and within the home. Women are entitled to be protected by all the institutions of society, including the criminal law, when they are battered, assaulted or subjected to sexual assault within marriage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Can the Minister explain why after nearly nine years of Labor Government there is still no way that women in the unpaid work force at home or women in casual or temporary work can have access to any continuing and meaningful superannuation?

—It is a complex and difficult policy issue which is an enormously expensive option for any government to introduce. The whole question of superannuation policy, the way in which it should be applied and the taxation regime that is appropriate to it is the subject of further review by the Government. If there is anything I can usefully add to that answer I will be happy to do so.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question following that most unsatisfactory answer. Can the Minister also explain why, in all that time—nine years, nearly—no policies have been developed which recognise the special retirement needs of women who have broken work patterns? In light of the Government's policy failure, why is the Government boasting that it will destroy the coalition's Fightback package, which will meet the needs of these women?

—What we have done in our 8 1/2 years of office, in the course of creating 1.43 million jobs at an average rate of 168,000 per year, is to create many more opportunities for women to participate in the paid work force than was ever previously the case. We have also wrought a remarkable change in the participation rate, which of course very largely reflects the involvement of women in the workplace, from a rate, as I said yesterday, of just over 60 per cent at the beginning of this decade to something in excess of 63 per cent at the moment. That is a dramatic increase in the participation rate, reflecting very directly and very immediately the role of the extra employment opportunities for women.

PARA.TAB: Along with that, of course, we have done an enormous amount to improve access to superannuation for people in the work force generally. There has been a dramatic increase in the availability of occupational superannuation to all members of the work force. That has been achieved in the context of Government policies generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —She is asking about non-occupational.

—I know Senator Newman is asking about non-occupational superannuation, but I have already answered that question. I am making the point that the need for non-occupational family support or mechanisms by way of superannuation or any other support is reduced to the extent that we have got an increase in occupational opportunities and occupational superannuation opportunities. Those opportunities have been increased on a dramatic scale in the course of the last decade of this Government. The Government makes no apology for any aspect of its policy in this respect. The improvements have been dramatic and have been appreciated as such by Australian women.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister aware of remarks made on Australia's manufacturing export performance by the eminent economist Professor Ross Garnaut to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on 25 November? Can he comment on Professor Garnaut's positive prognosis for exports of manufactured goods from Australia in the 1990s?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Maguire for this question because it deals with trade, which is an important part of our economic performance. I have had Professor Garnaut's comments to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade drawn to my attention. I think it is probably worth while to quote some of the things that Professor Garnaut said on manufactured exports. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: I see a continuation of the trends we have seen in recent years. We have now had about six years of very real growth in manufactured exports—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Should not trade questions be directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans?
—On the point of order: can I just say that I am acting as the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, and it is in that capacity.

—Mr President, on the point of order: trade has a number of different dimensions and one of them involves the production of goods and services that are put into trade. Traditionally, that has been the area of DITAC rather than DFAT. I would be quite happy to take over that responsibility, but it has never been part of the allocation of portfolio responsibilities in this place. The question is perfectly appropriately directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce.
—It is directed to Senator Cook.
—Dr Garnaut said to the Senate Standing Committee:

ANSWER.PARA: I see a continuation of the trends we have seen in recent years. We have now had about six years of very real growth in manufactured exports from a tiny base. But if you have a tiny base you have to start from a tiny base. It is now starting to add up to something worth while. This year, for the first time since 1788, our elaborately transformed manufactures, excluding all metals, will exceed food exports. Manufactured exports, including metals, will exceed total rural exports.

Professor Garnaut goes on to say that this increased performance has occurred against a background of very tough domestic and international trading conditions, so there is every reason to be confident that this export improvement will continue into the 1990s. I am confident that this will occur. I point to the export growth rate that Senator Button gave in the Senate last week and the net exports performance in the recently released September quarter national accounts—the fourth consecutive quarter of positive contribution to growth.

PARA.TAB: The beginning of this trend improvement in exports of manufactured goods predates by a good number of years the onset of the current recession, so the Opposition cannot claim that these exports are all recession driven. This Government is on track to meet its Budget-time forecast of having the current account deficit come in at 3.5 per cent of GDP, a ratio not matched, I might point out, since the 1970s. Part of that resurgence in our export performance is because of the manufacturing sector.

Since the large currency depreciations of 1985 and 1986, manufactured exports have grown, on average, by 14.5 per cent a year in real terms. Manufactured exports, as Professor Garnaut notes, exceeded rural exports in 1990-91 for the first time in history. Exporting for the manufacturing sector is about confidence and on the ground effort in growing markets.

The Opposition's GST package, with all its threatened impacts on inflation, the exchange rate, interest rates and productivity, will undermine this improvement. No wonder the foreign debt to GDP ratio is forecast to rise to 54 per cent by the year 2000—that is the high road scenario which is in the Opposition's package. Such a situation can only arise out of the anti-export thrust of the Opposition's package, with its attendant high inflation-low productivity scenarios.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. I refer to the Government's failed attempt to find an arithmetic hole in the coalition's Fightback expenditure proposals. Is it true that in the Budget Papers the introduction of co-payment was calculated to lead to a 7 per cent reduction in medical services to non-card holders? Is it also true that the coalition's health policy involves higher co-payments but in Mr Willis's flawed document the Government has calculated a 3 per cent reduction in medical services? Is it also true that the Government miscalculated the difference in savings in hospital costs by equating public hospitals at $350 a day with private hospitals at $180 a day? Is it also true that the attack on the coalition's health policy is like a slap on the wrist with a condom?

—As a radical celibate, I have no way of answering Senator Herron's final question. As to the other parts of Senator Herron's question, any assessment that is being made in regard to the alternative package put forward by the Opposition for the provision of health services to the Australian community cannot escape from the fact that what is at the essence and heart of the Opposition's proposals is a deal between the AMA and the private health insurance funds to ensure that there is a transfer of money from the pockets of patients, particularly GP patients presenting for primary health care, to the pockets of the doctors via private health insurance premiums to the tune of hundreds and hundreds of millions of dollars. There is no way the honourable senator can get away from that; it is the fundamental factor in the Opposition's proposals.

PARA.TAB: In regard to the question of hospitals, honourable senators would realise that one way in which States help to fund their public hospitals is by providing funding with assistance from Commonwealth specific purpose grants. In addition, the States derive some revenue for their public hospitals by treating and charging private patients in public hospitals. The amount of revenue the States derive is effectively limited by the Commonwealth's control over the maximum bed day payment made by private health insurers. Senator Herron will know that that is held at $180 per day in order to keep down premiums. The Opposition's alternative proposal has Mr Reith using a figure of $350 a day to reduce the grants to public hospitals, compared with the $180 that we have factored in.
Senator Short interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short is listening to this. He knows that there is a fatal flaw in the Opposition's proposals in this regard. Either we allow premiums to be raised in order to fund payments to hospitals of $350 a day—the bed day limit being raised from $180—in which case the premiums skyrocket, or else we keep the bed day limit of $180 a day. With the grant to the State being reduced by $350, each hospital for each bed day will lose $170 per bed day. That will create chaos and destroy the public hospital system in Australia.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition's policies in this regard will lead either to a huge increase in the premiums paid for hospital care in public hospitals or to the destruction of the public hospital system because hospitals will not be able to generate enough revenue to sustain their services. That is the result of the proposals put forward by the Opposition and that is why the Government certainly gives them no credence.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport. I understand that the Minister for Land Transport recently launched a Christmas road safety campaign that promoted the purchase of road safety goods such as baby capsules, child restraints and bicycle helmets for Christmas. Will the purchase of these products have an impact on our road safety performance?

—The Minister for Land Transport did indeed do that, and he has provided me with the following advice in answer to Senator Zakharov's question. I am sure that all honourable senators would have noted recent press reports of a young cyclist who was involved in an accident. This person, who had been forced by his parents to wear a helmet, came off his bike and shattered his safety helmet into 18 or 20 pieces. Without question, he would have died had he not been wearing the helmet.

PARA.TAB: Throughout the 1980s, every year around 3,000 Australians were killed and another 3,000 seriously injured. The current cost of these accidents to the Australian community exceeds $6 billion per year. In 1990, the road toll fell to 2,330 deaths, and this year the Government expects a further reduction to fewer than 2,200.

As a government and a community, we must endeavour to minimise the level of road trauma on Australian roads. And what better time is there than Christmas for us to take steps with our own families to improve safety? Around 1,600 bicycle riders are killed or seriously injured on Australian roads every year. Of those killed, over half are under 16 years of age. Around 74 per cent of those killed in 1990 were not wearing bicycle helmets and yet, sadly, the majority of those deaths were caused by head injuries.

The Government recognises the importance of bicycle helmets and, as part of the Prime Minister's package of road safety measures earlier this year, called for the introduction of compulsory helmet wearing. Most Australians are now protected by this legislation. It is the responsibility of parents and carers to ensure the safety of those who are unable to ensure it for themselves. The purchase of properly fitting bicycle helmets is one way that children can be protected. Correctly worn seat belts and restraints is the other major way we can all work to reduce the road toll.

Mr President, I think that encapsulates the main response to Senator Zakharov's question. There is a considerable amount of additional technical material contained in this answer, and I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate the remainder of this answer in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
It is absolutely essential that everyone who travels by car should be properly restrained.
Right from the new baby coming home from hospital in a baby capsule to our more senior citizens.

Each year nearly 2,000 children are seriously injured and about 100 are killed as passengers in cars on Australian roads. More than half the children killed in cars are unrestrained at the time of the crash.
Baby capsules and child restraints, harnesses, booster seats and so on are designed to protect young travellers. They are not cheap but how do you put a price on a child's life?
The three point seat belt is acknowledged world wide by road safety experts as being the simplest, yet most cost effective, means of protecting drivers and passengers.
We have high seat belt wearing rates in Australia—over 94 per cent in front seats and 90 per cent in rear seats.
Despite the fact that only about six per cent of drivers and passengers do not wear seat belts, around 40 per cent of people killed in Australia have not been wearing a seat belt.
Unbelievably 80 per cent of motorists and passengers killed in the Northern Territory this year were not wearing a seat belt.
In both cases had those victims taken this one single simple precaution, most of them would probably have been alive today.
It's as simple as that.
And yet, how often do we see young children and young men, especially in the bush, without their seat belts.
It only takes a moment; but it saves a life.

With the Christmas holiday period nearly upon us, we must all take greater care on the roads and we must make sure we do everything possible to ensure the safety of our children and others by using seat belts and restraints, by wearing helmets when we ride and by driving sensibly and safely at all times.
The 1991 Christmas road safety campaign encourages the giving of safety gifts which may save the life of a dear one.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Evans, representing the Minister for Finance in this chamber. I refer to the Government's failed attempt to find an arithmetic hole in the coalition's Fightback expenditure proposals. Will the Minister explain to the Senate the reasons for the Government's error yesterday in asserting that the compensation arrangements outlined in the Fightback package were underestimated by $317m? Was the error due to a genuine misunderstanding by the Government or was it due to deliberate misrepresentation?

—Yesterday, Ralph Willis blew a $2.6 billion hole in the coalition's Fightback package. Nothing could demonstrate more clearly the size of that hole and the debilitation, intellectual and otherwise, of the Opposition at the moment than Mr Reith's press release issued this morning which claims that mistakes were made in the calculation of the value of the compensation package. Not only was no mistake made by Mr Willis or by Finance; the very nature of Mr Reith's reply and the very nature of this question indicate clearly, beyond doubt, that honourable senators opposite do not understand the arithmetical basis of their own package.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, let me explain why, because it is a very interesting and a very instructive little tale. Opposition members simply do not understand the arithmetical basis of the calculations that lie behind their own package. Let me tell honourable senators why. Let me tell them in a little bit of detail, because it is necessary to explain it. The package as a whole has two sides to it. One is the outlay side; the other, which the Government has not addressed at all at this stage, is the revenue side. The outlay side has a couple of components.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections on my left.
—It is a pity that you cannot—
—Order! Senator Short!

—There are two components in the Opposition's outlays calculation. One component is the savings that the Opposition pretends will be made as a result of Budget cuts, and the Opposition assesses those savings as worth $10 billion in 1991-92 dollars. That they are 1991-92 dollars appears very clearly, for example, on page 228 of the documentation.

PARA.TAB: The other component of the outlays calculations is the expenditure that Opposition members will be making in order, as they say, to put together some kind of a compensation package—and that includes the social security compensation package to which Senator Short refers and to which Mr Reith referred in his press release today. That benefit compensation package is estimated at $2.5 billion in 1991-92 dollars if honourable senators look at page 290 of their own documentation.

The total expenditure that the Opposition is incurring, including that $2.5 billion, adds up to something like $5.5 billion, which means that the net savings that Opposition members calculate on the outlay side are $4.5 billion. By the Opposition's own calculations, there would be $10 billion worth of gross savings, less $5.5 billion of gross expenditure, leaving net savings on the outlays side of $4.5 billion in 1991-92 dollars.

Finance, taking the outlays side of the proposed budget, worked through each one of those figures in 1991-92 dollars.
