It worked through the figures systematically, elaborately, in detail, for page after page on which all the assumptions are explained and all the figures are tabulated. Instead of a figure of $10 billion worth of savings, Finance produced a figure of $7.5 billion on all the bases that were spelt out yesterday by Mr Willis and in respect of which those opposite have not struck one single counterblow.

On the expenditure side, instead of having a figure of $5.5 billion worth of expenditure, Finance has come up with a figure of $5.6 billion. On the expenditure side there is not much disagreement with the coalition's figures; there is not much disagreement at all on the calculation of the figures on the benefit compensation package or anything else. But the net figure when we deduct $5.6 billion worth of gross expenditure from $7.5 billion of gross savings represents net savings, in 1991-92 dollars, of $1.9 billion. That is $1.9 billion worth of net savings as compared with the coalition's figure of $4.5 billion, both of them in 1991-92 dollars—in other words, a difference, a shortfall, of $2.6 billion, exactly what Mr Willis said yesterday, exactly what is on the record.

Opposition members have become totally confused with their own figures because, when it comes to the revenue side of the whole exercise, when they tried to work out what the ultimate impact would be on the Budget deficit or surplus, year by year or in the whole period to 1999, they were not able to use 1991-92 figures. They had to use 1990-91 figures. That was not an unreasonable thing for them to do because there was more detail in the published 1990-91 figures on the record.

In doing all the revenue calculations, which do not bear in any way on any of the figures I have been using so far, members of the Opposition did use 1990-91 figures and, when they had brought the two lots together at the end of the process—their outlays side, with the savings, the expenditure and the net savings thus involved—and they married them with the revenue side of their budget, they put them both in 1990-91 dollars, a perfectly reasonable thing to do. They discounted—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, listen to this because it is obviously an education that you need, because you do not understand what you have done in your own figuring. You simply do not understand it. We have seen that with Peter Reith today in a more random collection of puffery and rubbish than it would be possible to compile, and that demonstrates that absolutely.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Surely Senator Evans should be directing his comments through the chair and not across the chamber; I respectfully suggest to you that you direct him to do so.
—There is no point of order. I would point out to the Minister that this is becoming a very long answer.

—It is in response to an Opposition question. On the outlays side of the Budget, all the figuring—our figuring, the Opposition's figuring—was done in 1991-92 dollars; oranges were compared with oranges. On the revenue side, the figuring of Opposition members is in 1990-91 dollars. We have not contested that. It is perfectly appropriate for them to use that and it is perfectly appropriate for them to discount down the figures when doing a final calculation.

PARA.TAB: The final point is simply this: if those opposite are going to stay remotely credible in this business of being an alternative government, if they are going to stay remotely credible in putting together some kind of alternative package, they have to know how to count—and in counting, they have to know how to compare apples with apples or oranges with oranges. In our counting, we have compared oranges with oranges and apples with apples all the way down. Opposition members, in the knockout blow that Mr Reith has offered today, the knockout blow that Senator Short seeks to reinforce, have compared oranges with apples and come up with a lemon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Evans has demonstrated yet again the dangers of having too big a mouth. He obviously has no idea of the answer to that question and he obviously has not read the documents. How is it possible that the Government made such an elementary error—which was the basis of my question—by using the false assumption that the Fightback compensation estimates were based on 1991-92 dollars, when a whole chapter of the Fightback document, namely chapter 10, is devoted to explaining that these costings were in 1990-91 dollars? That chapter also explains, in chapter and verse, why this is so. Will the Government now go back and have another try at getting its sums right? Read chapter 10.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the reasons we made the particular judgment we did—that the $2.5 billion worth of costings for the benefit compensation package was in 1991-92 dollars—is that at page 290 of the Opposition's document it says:

ANSWER.PARA: The cost of the compensation measures (with the exception of the Family Allowance) is $2515 million (in 1991-92 dollars)

Those opposite have said it themselves in their own paper; it is their own figure in their own document. The honourable senator can huff and he can puff and he can blow the house down, but it is in his own document. He has made a donkey of himself. He has made a goose of himself because it is there in his own document—it says `1991-92 dollars'. He is a goose.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Closure of Offices

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer the Minister to a recent article in the Sydney Morning Herald, which reported:

QUESTION.PARA: In the midst of a recession and record unemployment the Department of Social Security is planning to close up to eight of its inner-Sydney offices.

I ask the Minister: firstly, are the leaked departmental documents upon which the story is based accurate; secondly, has a final decision been made as to when the Darlinghurst, Petersham, Newtown, Randwick, Crows Nest and Maroubra social security offices will be closed; and, thirdly, will office closures be confined to these offices, or will they occur in other States or in other parts of New South Wales? Finally, I ask whether the Minister agrees with the New South Wales Public Sector Union, which has stated:
Closing down inner-city offices where there is high unemployment and a large number of clients who quite frankly don't have the resources to go to other locations just seems like lunacy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Were it the case that such closures were to take place in isolation—that is, in isolation from the opening of other offices to replace them—then the answer to that part of the question would be yes. But that is not the case. In fact, the documents which have been used in the article are being floated around the Department for opinions; that is why they have been released. There has already been a demonstration by quite a few people outside the Darlinghurst office to protest against its closure. I understand that the recommendation for closure of the Darlinghurst office, along with the documents to go with it, will be put to me tonight at a meeting which will begin at 8.30.

PARA.TAB: However, during discussions at that meeting I understand a number of proposals for the replacement of the offices which are being closed will also be put to me. In fact, the net result will be an increase in the number of social security offices. There will be an addition to that number in the next 12 months. Obviously, during a recession, when a lot more people are coming into the offices, one has to look at office accommodation. One of the big complaints we get from clients is that many of the offices—particularly those which we have occupied in years gone by—are now inadequate to deal with the number of people coming through them. That is the problem we are trying to address.

So I understand there will be a recommendation for the closure of the Darlinghurst office, although I have not yet seen the justification for it. My understanding is that there will also be a proposal to open a new office very close to that in better premises. We are not intending to reduce the service in inner-city areas, or in any other areas; the intention is to make the service more efficient and better for clients. I will have that meeting with the Department tonight. I will make some decisions about the closure of offices and I will inform the honourable senator as soon as those decisions have been finalised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister representing the Minister for Finance agree with the Department of Finance that the coalition's privatisation initiatives are `generally considered to be feasible'? If so, will the Minister confirm that the large difference between the Government's and the coalitions's estimated savings is solely the result of the Government having cold feet in relation to privatisation because of opposition from its union bosses?

—As I recall, one of the reasons why some of our exercises in privatisation have not been able to proceed so far is that there has been opposition from the honourable senator's side. There is the Moomba to Sydney gas pipeline for a start, which blew a $700m hole in our Budget last year as a result of the irresponsibility of those opposite on that particular issue. That is the kind of opposition we have faced in the past whenever we have sought to go down the track of any sensible initiatives in this area.

PARA.TAB: I am not in a position to respond in any more detail to the other aspect of the question at the moment, but I will see what information I can get and respond accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. In view of the achievements of higher productivity being reported by stevedoring companies, can the Minister provide an update on progress being made under the Government's reform program?

—The Government is pleased by the very significant boosts in productivity that are being reported by the stevedores themselves. Some very encouraging statistics are being delivered at the moment, particularly in the area of ship days lost in port. For example, in one Sydney terminal very substantial reductions have been made: an average of 47 ship days lost per month has been cut down to three days, with productivity increases around the mid-60 per cent mark.

PARA.TAB: As a result of these improvements, which have exceeded the targets that were predicted by the Inter-State Commission recommendations, this morning Cabinet made a decision—which is a very welcome one, I must say—to increase the impetus and the pace of the reform process. This is something I canvassed earlier in the Senate which arose out of recent negotiations with employers in Sydney. The Government will be providing supplementary redundancy funding of up to $20m per year.

TALK.START.PARA: —There you are!

—The honourable senator could hardly act surprised because I told him all about it a month ago. This will be provided on a dollar for dollar basis with industry in order to increase the pace and extent of the restructuring program. The reform program has been so highly successful that the number of people being removed from the industry is now exceeding substantially the recommendations in the Inter-State Commission report.

PARA.TAB: Originally, it was proposed that 3,000 people would exit under these redundancy arrangements. With the Cabinet decision this morning—which, I might add, received an enthusiastic degree of support from employers, with matching funding—this package will remove a further 400 workers in excess of the original Government targets. This will encourage the industry to accelerate the completion of the restructuring and bring forward the winding up of the industry-wide employment program.

It is anticipated that by the end of the reform program late next year, the total stevedoring work force in Australia will have been cut in half. I have previously advised the Senate that about 2,400 older and less skilled employees have already left the industry, following the implementation of new enterprise agreements at our major ports. This is in addition to the 800 employees that have left over the same period of time through natural attrition.

The next few months will see reforms in regional ports adding a further 1,300 employees to the number leaving the industry. Key stevedoring companies have now achieved work force reductions of between 30 and 60 per cent. They are reporting productivity improvements of up to 80 per cent, resulting in significantly better ship turnaround times—and I have already indicated just how good they are. Shore-side truck handling rates and turnaround times have been reduced to as low as 10 to 20 minutes within terminals at our major ports.

The Opposition's continual howling down of the industry's significant achievements is only undermining this country's reputation overseas. I particularly condemn the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, for the disgusting statements he made on radio in the last 48 hours. One could fit his total knowledge of waterfront reform on the head of a very small pin. He has a responsibility to visit the waterfront. I am absolutely serious about this because John Sharp has just done so. Some employers were so concerned about the continuing negative comments that have been made, which have ignored the substantial reforms, that they invited the shadow Minister for shipping and waterfront reform to come down and have a look. To his credit, he did.

If Dr Hewson, in the extremely responsible position that he holds in Australian public life, wants to continue to make such factually erroneous statements as he has done in the last 48 hours, I seriously invite him to accept the same invitation, to have a look for himself, and not to continually undermine this important Australian industry in the public statements that he makes about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Mr President, yesterday in an answer to a question from Senator Tierney concerning the abolition of the coal export duty, I quite correctly stated that this matter had been under consideration for months and that it was not in any way a response to the Fightback package but was something that the Government and the relevant Minister had quite independently decided to do. I also said, however, that as I understood it, it was the subject of a Cabinet submission which was lodged, debated and decided before that Fightback package was released.

PARA.TAB: I have since checked that statement, as I always do when I qualify them in any way and I am not quite sure, and found that the relevant Cabinet decision was not in fact taken until 2 December on the basis of a Cabinet submission that had been circulated only a few days earlier. So to that extent I was inaccurate in that answer.

The basic point remains, however, that the formal decision on 2 December was the end product of a really quite lengthy process involving negotiations between the Commonwealth and the company involved, BHP Utah. The Minister had been involved in those discussions for some five months and, clearly, long before 2 December had formed an intention to get rid of the levy. It had nothing whatsoever to do with the Opposition's announced intention. So the substance of my answer remains exactly right but, having respect as I do for the dignity of the Senate, I did wish to correct any possible mistake that I might have made.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on 5 December Senator Harradine asked me a question in this place about human rights in China. I have a substantial answer for him. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

Senator Harradine has raised two issues: one concerns alleged shortcomings in the briefing provided to the Human Rights Delegation to China; and the other to certain statements made in the Delegation's published report.

As I advised Senator Harradine in my letter to him of 9 November 1991, following the Senate Estimates Committee debates where the issue of Chinese birth control policies and practices was extensively debated, the Sichuan People's Congress Family Planning Regulations comprise a booklet of over 150 pages, which has not been fully translated into English and in any event, due to its size, could not have been attached as a whole to the Delegation's report. Annex 8 of the report provided a translation of those sections of the regulations which deal with reasons for allowing exceptions to the "one-child" policy—this is clearly stated in paragraph 44 of the report.

In my opinion, the Delegation was very fully briefed on a wide range of areas relevant to its mission prior to its visit by leading academics and recognised experts on China. Indeed, the Delegation included several of Australia's foremost China experts.

I am advised that the full text, in Chinese, of the Sichuan Family Planning Regulations was provided to the Delegation by the Chinese authorities during the Delegation's visit. As is made clear in its report, the Delegation was assured by the Chinese authorities that while abortion is recommended if contraceptive methods fail, it is never mandatory. It should also be clear from the report that the Delegation was not in a position to check the accuracy of this assurance, although the Chinese acknowledged that abuses had taken place in earlier years.
Senator Harradine mentioned four specific articles of the Sichuan Family Planning Regulations which he alleges make abortions and sterilisations mandatory, namely Articles 13, 14, 23 and 27

I am advised that articles 23 and 27 respectively, set out financial penalties which apply to couples who give birth to "unplanned" children; and impose penalties on those who threaten or attack family planning workers. These articles do not authorise compulsory abortion or sterilisation.

Article 14 states that comprehensive methods of birth-control should be adopted, with pregnancy prevention being the main one. It advocates, but does not make mandatory, sterilisation of one member if a couple has two children.

Article 13 states that couples who have inherited mental illness, mental deficiency, deformity or serious inherited diseases are forbidden to have children. If pregnant, according to the regulation, the pregnancy should be terminated.
I am advised that the Chinese wording of this regulation is open to different interpretations, one of which could imply that abortion is mandatory in these circumstances.

The Government's position on the question of coercive abortion or sterilisation is clear, and has been conveyed to the Chinese Government—we will not support coercive practices in any circumstances. As detailed in its report, the Human Rights Delegation also raised allegations of compulsory abortion and sterilisation with the Chinese authorities during its visit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer by Senator Evans to a question without notice asked this day by Senator Short relating to the Fightback package.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's claim, which Senator Evans echoed during Question Time, that compensation will cost $317m more than the estimate of compensation in the coalition's Fightback proposals rests, as I said in Question Time, on the false assumption that the Fightback estimate is for 1991-92. That is an elementary error because it overlooks the fact that chapter 10 of the Fightback! document proposals dealing with compensation is written in terms of 1990-91 dollars. The reason for that is that it relates to the consequential aspects of the GST and other tax changes.

PARA.TAB: Because the GST and related tax changes were all estimated in 1990-91 dollar terms, the coalition therefore took a very conscious and deliberate decision, which is spelled out very carefully in chapter 10 of the Fightback! documents to also cost the compensation figures in 1990-91 dollars. It hardly requires the Department of Finance to point out that the cost of compensation would be higher—of course it would—in 1991-92 than in 1990-91 because of inflation and the blow-out in unemployment caused by the failure of the Government's economic policies. If one were to adopt that approach, then revenue from the GST will also be higher in 1991-92 than in 1990-91. It makes no sense at all—this is why we did not do it—to cost one component of the package in a later year than other components of the package.

The point that Senator Evans has missed is that the Fightback tax and compensation costings are all in terms of 1990-91 magnitudes and 1991-92 dollars. And 1990-91 was chosen because it was the last full financial year for which all the relevant data is available. The Fightback costings, therefore, are fully consistent.

It is quite fanciful to suggest that there is a hole of $317m if just one part of the Fightback package is re-estimated, as the Government did yesterday, on a 1991-92 basis. If the Government would like the Fightback package to be re-estimated in the dollars of the day for 1993-94, 1994-95 and 1995-96, then let it produce economic forecasts on which such estimates should be based. The reason we never did that was that we would have had to rely, basically, on the Government's forward Estimates, and everyone knows how dreadfully rubbery they are; indeed, the estimates for 1991-92 are dreadfully rubbery.

In the first four months of this financial year we have had a blow-out in the Budget deficit to a figure 50 per cent higher than the Government is budgeting for the year as a whole. Who on earth in his right mind would use forward Estimates as a basis for these proposals? That is precisely what the Government is claiming we did in relation to the compensation figures, and that is precisely what we did not do for the reasons I have just spelled out.

I repeat that Senator Evans, the Government, the Department of Finance—whoever has been involved in this—have made a elementary error, and it is about time they acknowledged that error. It is about time they went back and had a proper look at the Fightback proposals. This is not the only error by any means in the figures produced yesterday by the Government. There are a large number of errors. But when it comes to an elementary error and a complete misunderstanding of the documentation and the concepts behind what we are doing, then I think this really takes the cake.

It is an example of what the coalition said in its release following the comments, the statement and the documentation from the Treasurer (Mr Willis) that the Government has got it wrong in a very big way indeed; in fact, it has got every element in its response wrong. If the responses are not technically wrong, as many of them are, then they are wrong because the Government has brought forward a set of wild assumptions to counter the assumptions that are behind the coalition's proposals. Virtually none of the alternative assumptions the Government has brought forward have been given any justification at all. Far from there being a $2.6 billion arithmetical hole in the coalition's proposals, there is not a one dollar hole in the coalition's proposals.

The coalition stands full square and will not resile one iota from one dollar of those very carefully costed proposals that are part of the basis for giving Australia the opportunity to get onto a new course, giving a bit of vision and hope to people, and providing some jobs for the 1 1/2 million people out there who cannot get them at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I resile from absolutely nothing I said in Question Time on this subject. The truth of the matter remains—and I seek leave to incorporate the relevant paragraph 16.27.17 in Hansard—

—Those opposite can put in as much of chapter 10 as they want to; I am putting this particular paragraph into Hansard.
—If you get permission.
—Is leave granted? Leave is not granted.
—That is fine. I will read the relevant paragraph on page 290 and I will come to chapter 10 in a minute. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Pensioners, welfare beneficiaries, those receiving income support for education and recipients of the Family Allowance Supplement will be fully compensated for the 4.4 per cent price effect due to the introduction of the Goods and Services Tax.

Age, wives, sole parent's, widow's, service, war widows, disability support and carer's pensions will be increased by 8 per cent per fortnight and all other social security payment rates will be increased by 6 per cent. The Family Allowance would also be increased (see Section 16.14 above).
The cost of the compensation measures (with the exception of the Family Allowance) is $2515 million (in 1991-92 dollars) which is added to the social security budget.
Net Cost: $2515 million.

All the individual calculations throughout this document are done basically in 1991-92 dollars. Chapter 10 is certainly a discussion of quite separate issues about the particular compensatory elements in the GST package. Those opposite may well have used 1990-91 dollars for the purposes of that discussion. I have not had a chance to check that. However, in all those tabulations—the aggregates that are used, the figuring that is used, the tabulation that appears on page 230 in a little more detail—1991-92 dollars are used. It is those 1991-92 dollars for all components on the outlay side that we have meticulously and religiously compared with the true figures—the 1991-92 dollar figures that the Opposition has put and those which we have identified. When we do that exercise we come up with the bottom line figure that I have just indicated, which is $2.6 billion. According to the Opposition, it is gross savings of $10 billion and gross expenditure of $5.5 billion, giving net savings of $4.5 billion.

PARA.TAB: There may be a further argument about the $4.5 billion because the relevant net savings on page 230 are identified as being $4 billion in round figures. I put on the record that the explanation for that difference is the treatment of a tax credit of about $500m, which we have treated as negative revenue in our accounts and which the Opposition has treated as being on the expenditure side. We regarded the tax credit, on proper accounting principles, as being more appropriately recorded on the revenue side. That is the only point where there could be any possible room for confusion. The figures as I have described them are those aggregates.

Our figures—Department of Finance figures—by meticulous line by line comparisons down the page, are gross savings of $7.5 billion, gross expenditure of $5.6 billion and net savings of $1.9 billion. Compare our net savings of $1.9 billion with the Opposition's net savings of $4.5 billion and we get a $2.6 billion hole.

Even if all those figures, or any component of them, were to change, we would only have a 3 per cent difference because that is the sole impact of the difference between 1990-91 and 1991-92 figures anyway. To the extent that the Opposition had done 1991-92 figurings and brought them back to 1990-91 figures for legitimate purposes, it used a 3 per cent GDP non-farm deflator.

TALK.START.PARA: —Compensation is treated differently.

—I do not know whether the Opposition thought it was treating it differently. What it has said on page 290, and what the Department of Finance fully understands, having looked in detail at all the individual components, is that the Opposition is talking in 1991-92 terms. The Opposition does not understand the basic figuring of its own document. When those opposite go away and ponder very carefully what I have said and look very carefully at what I have said, they will appreciate that they have a very large bucket of eggs all over their faces.

—I want to support the remarks made by Senator Short earlier so that Senator Gareth Evans might be able to understand. He usually spends his time overseas gallivanting around and, consequently, he does not have much time to pay to economics. One of the things that we made sure of in working out our figures is that we were working with figures that were concrete figures, not the guesstimates which the Government's Estimates have become. One of the reasons why it took a full 15 months before the package was brought out was that we had to wait for the 1991-92 Budget, which would give us the actuals for 1990-91.

PARA.TAB: The difficulty Senator Evans has is in understanding that we would not rely on the rubbery Estimates figures. In the draft annual reports of the Department of Finance and the Treasury, their own officers had to apologise in rather distorted language for getting their own calculations wrong. Looking at the blow-out in the last Budget of in excess of $7.7 billion, one wonders why anybody would place any reliance on the Estimates that the Government works out for its forecasted year.

Furthermore, as we looked at the claims against the Advance to the Minister for Finance, we saw again and again how individual government departments got their own estimates wrong. Time and again, the whole of the Government forecasting mechanism is seen to be in error. Therefore, when the Government comes back to us and is using taxpayers' dollars to pay public servants to try to work out errors in a package which is worked on factual base figures, it not only leaves a lot to be desired in terms of the ethics of doing that, but it also leaves that great gaping hole in credibility.

The Government cannot even estimate its own figures accurately, let alone try to estimate the Opposition's figures. So that we understand very specifically: the Government is using taxpayers' money to get public servants, quite against any ethical procedure, to do paid party political work, to try to find errors on the estimated figures, when we have used actual figures and we have done that at our own expense.

As the Government comes up again and again trying in a pitiful way to find some answer to our planned policies—because it simply has none of its own and, therefore, cannot argue a case saying that its strategy is better than our strategy—it is important for everybody to remember that if the Government cannot get its own Estimates right, why on earth should anyone believe what it says about somebody else's estimates?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Gareth Evans and, unfortunately, the Department of Finance have projected certain expenditure figures for the future. Yet, by their own admission in this Senate today, they have not analysed the revenue side and done comparable projections and comparable figures on the other side. Such a lack of balance in applying a common base does the Government and its advisers no credit. The conservative basis of the Liberal-National Party coalition gives credibility to tax reform, in contrast to this lack of credibility in the way in which the Government has produced its one-sided analysis of the calculations. I trust the Government will not blame the Department of Finance unduly for this error which, I believe, is inexcusable.

—I agree with my colleagues who have spoken before me and emphasise that there is a $6 billion hole in the Government's Budget. The advice that the Government seems to be getting in producing its figures for the Budget is very poor. In four months of this year the deficit has blown out by $6 billion. This Government and Senator Gareth Evans have the hide to come along and suggest that there are inaccuracies in our figures.

PARA.TAB: Having mentioned that, I say again for the benefit of the Senate that it sickens me that the ALP is drawing upon the advice of taxpayer funded officials to respond to a document in a political way. It is a political matter. The Government is reeling from its inability to counter in any way Dr Hewson's program and vision for the future. It has, in a quite scandalous way, abused the system of government by having public servants, at the taxpayer's expense, doing the work for the Labor Party.

That to me is an inexcusable waste and misuse of government money. In the State I come from, people have ended up in gaol for that sort of thing. That to me is unforgivable. The Liberal and the National parties have produced a document from their own funds, but all this Government does is get taxpayer funded officials to attempt to answer that document. I think that is scandalous. It is something that the Government, if it has any morals or any credibility at all, really should stop straightaway; or at least the Australian Labor Party should pick up the tab and pay the Department back the money for which it has dipped into the public purse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Last night I undertook to consider remarks made by Senator Campbell in debate concerning my statement on the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Bill. Earlier in the evening I required Senator Campbell to withdraw a remark he made about the Australian Democrats, which is on page 4418 of Hansard. PARA.TAB: Having looked at the Hansard, I find that Senator Campbell did use the expression again of the Australian Democrats. Senator Campbell made some remarks to the effect that he thought that his use of the expression was acceptable on the second occasion because he referred to a political party rather than any particular senator. There was no material difference, however, between the two occasions. His first use of the expression referred to `all Australian Democrats'. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Water quality in Australia, particularly in the eastern States, is a matter of major concern. In fact, the Darling system has been declared a disaster area because of the algae problem. Unfortunately, problems are developing in the Snowy Mountains that have received little or no publicity, to my knowledge, but which are revealed in the 1990-91 annual report of the Snowy Mountains Council. Page 16 of the report states:

To maintain the water quality of the Scheme's storages, baseline measurements began of the nutrient, bacterial, and turbidity parameters of the major storages. Of particular concern is Lake Jindabyne where the catchment is coming under increasing pressure from subdivision and development with the associated water supply and sewage disposal problems.
In conjunction with the NSW Department of Water Resources the Council has completed two years of a three year water quality survey of Lake Jindabyne.
This next part is a matter of some concern:
Results from the first year of sampling provide further evidence that Lake Jindabyne is on the verge of becoming eutrophic.
`Eutrophic' means being rich in nutrients and hence having excessive plant growth which kills animal life by deprivation of oxygen. The report continues:
The study will assess the nutrient balance within the lake and indicate nutrient loadings from tributary inflows.

There is no doubt that the development of Jindabyne is very important for tourists and holiday purposes, but if Lake Jindabyne is on the verge of becoming eutrophic there is no doubt that serious action will have to be taken because it is a major water system. Lake Jindabyne is important particularly for irrigation and is one of the major storages in the Snowy Mountains scheme.

PARA.TAB: I hope that the New South Wales Government in its expressions of quite proper concern about the western waterways will also take heed of this major problem. As I say, the New South Wales Department of Water Resources is involved in this water quality survey. I also hope that this problem will not lead to any further restraint on the development of the snowfields in Australia and will not be used as an excuse for blocking that development. There is no doubt that the Australian snowfields provide an enormous amenity for many thousands of Australians and also visitors from overseas. Surely there are methods which can be properly applied to ensure that these problems, particularly of excessive nutrients, can be resolved without simply blocking development.

I also express some little concern about a statement in the Chairman's report on page 6. As a result of the fact that the arrangements of the scheme are under review by the Commonwealth and State governments, the Chairman said that he is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . well aware of the climate of uncertainty surrounding the Scheme as a result of the Review and hope that this vital issue will be resolved well before Council's 1991/92 Annual Report is due.

I hope that this matter is resolved, particularly as the scheme has been involved in very heavy capital expenditure. One would certainly expect its future to be assured in the context of this enormous capital expenditure, one of the results of which has been a continual decrease in the real cost of production of power over the past 20 or so years. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important to recognise in this 1990-91 annual report of the Snowy Mountains Council that the Council's mission states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Council is responsible for the direction and control of the operation and maintenance of the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Scheme.
Over the years we have all been very proud of this scheme. The mission continues:
Storing and releasing water and generating electricity to meet customer requirements;
Consistent with safety, asset maintenance, economic and environmental requirements.

Senator Michael Baume has already mentioned the problems of water quality; the measurements which have begun of the nutrient, bacterial and turbidity parameters of the major storages; and the fact that results from the first year of sampling have provided further evidence that Lake Jindabyne is on the verge of becoming eutrophic. That is a concern to all. I agree with Senator Baume: I hope that people do not jump to conclusions and stop development. A couple of other points within the report on the year's highlights are that the Snowy scheme generated a total of 5,797 gigawatt hours of mainly peak load electricity in 1991 and the unit cost of production was something like 2.9 cents per kilowatt hour.

PARA.TAB: It is well to remember the AUSELGRID recommendations in the coalition's policy of combining all the electricity grids on the eastern seaboard, and even combining them in the future with other Tasmanian electricity grids so that peak loads in different areas can be utilised in other areas and there can be much more cost efficient electricity storage and utilisation. The Council is to be commended on the report. It is a pity that we have not had more schemes like the Snowy Mountains scheme on the north coast of New South Wales. Perhaps with a little imagination and a little foresight we could have another scheme like it in Australia. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: It was not sensible to base estimates of net savings on the 1991/92 static base.

Anyone would know that of all the figures that could be used, they would be the safest. What that means is that he has ignored entirely the savings over the next three years in the major areas of Asset Services, Project Services, the Australian Property Group, plus AUSLIG and the Australian Valuation Office. Our figures and the Treasurer's figures for the non-commercial aspects of the Department of Administrative Services—that is, Comcar and the printing service—are pretty much the same. The Treasurer seems to be arguing that, with planned rationalisation of the major quasi-commercial operations of DAS, the savings outlined in the Fightback package would occur anyway and, therefore, should not be counted.

PARA.TAB: It is noted, for instance, that the business plan of Asset Services provides for reductions in excess of some 850 people over the next three years. TALK.START.PARA: —So will it.

—I thank Senator Bishop for her interjection. It has not done so and, therefore, its public analysis, as portrayed by Mr Willis yesterday, is fatally flawed. It is the view of the coalition that it is the role of government to acquire the essential goods and services it requires. It is not the role of government to provide those services. There is nothing wrong, in the main, with those who work in these quasi-commercial operations. PARA.TAB: Just to help the Government in this instance let me say that, on all empiricals, the coalition's plan is to rationalise the quasi-commercial units in the first year.
