DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I will comment briefly on the annual report of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training. Firstly, I believe that all honourable senators should have a close look at the report as it is an excellent report. It is a report on a key area of our workplace operation that we tend to neglect and forget about.

PARA.TAB: In this era of an international economy, it is very necessary for us to improve our international competitiveness and improve workplace skills, particularly in the area of education and training of our work force. I have mentioned that we tend to neglect to focus on the education and training of our management, particularly middle management and supervisory levels. The report which has been commissioned by the Employment and Skills Council, which is a subsidiary council of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training—a board, as I understand it, that the Opposition has pledged to abolish—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is quite right.

—I note the interjection that I am quite right. I thank Senator Tierney. Honourable senators would have noticed that it is a board that has produced a full range of very impressive reports over the last three or four years since its inception. The report on management training provision in Australia, which follows a benchmark survey that was undertaken in 1990—the outcome of which is detailed on pages 16 and 17—highlights a number of problems that management faces in the area of education and training in this country.

PARA.TAB: I note some of the key findings that are made. For example, there are 468,000 managers in Australian firms with more than 50 employees. Many of these managers have no formal training whatsoever. One of the rather startling findings in this report is that our managers, on average, attend only four days of training per year. I think it is a national disgrace that we have been unable to improve the education and training effort amongst our management work force.

In this country there has been a great deal of criticism, particularly from those opposite, about trade union and worker practices. A great deal of effort from this Government has gone into reshaping the attitudes of the work force and upgrading the employment, education and skills formation of our work force, but very little has been said or done in the area of management training. A consequence of the benchmark survey that was carried out was that there was an Australian mission on management skills, as outlined on pages 18 and 19. That overseas mission visited some six countries over 30 days, including Japan, Europe and North America. The recommendations from that overseas mission are contained on pages 21, 22 and 23 of the report. I would certainly heartily endorse those recommendations. As I mentioned earlier, it is an area that has been greatly neglected in the past.

A summary of the mission's recommendations is also listed on page 41. I will give a brief run-through of the sorts of recommendations that are made. Many problems are typical of the problems in education and training generally. There is the need for an integrated national approach; the need for a national awareness campaign; the need for national skills guidelines; and the need—I have already mentioned it as it is particularly important—for supervisor development. Supervisors in the work force form the linchpin between the worker, the employee and the general management level—a very important area. There is also the need for small to medium size employer fabric—unfortunately, there are a range of impediments to small and medium size business being able to participate successfully in management programs—and the need for managers as trainers and for a foundation on education, training and best practice.

In conclusion, I refer briefly to the Fightback package—the `Frightpack', or the doomsday document. I have looked through this document for some comment on management training. Where is it? There is none. Management training is one of the major problems facing this country and the Opposition has totally ignored it. That is the sort of importance that those opposite place on it. In comparison, this Government has policies and positive initiatives—the minimum training guarantee levy and reports such as this, which the Opposition would not release because it plans to abolish the National Board of Employment, Education and Training. The Government's positive initiatives stand in stark contrast to the ignorance and lack of policy detail in this area from those opposite.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tabled in the Senate today is a document produced by the National Board of Employment, Education and Training which looks at the need for management training in this country. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: It has been prepared because of growing evidence that the quality and effectiveness of management will be critical to the success of all enterprises in Australia.

The workshop that produced this paper has aired some very important points which relate to the supply, demand and quality of management training. The skills and expertise of enterprise management will be among the most important determinants of Australia's future. As a consequence, managers will need greater access to training and development. The report states that there is need for more accessible and relevant programs, delivered by properly qualified staff, and to increase the awareness of the desirability of these management skills.

PARA.TAB: These goals are very necessary. Unfortunately, the identification of the issue is as useful as the paper gets. It goes on to suggest that the way forward in this area is a higher level of government intervention. This is typical of the Hawke Government's centralist thinking, which is responsible for the economic and social disaster in which Australia finds itself today.

The paper discusses the issues of supply and demand of management training. Instead of letting capable market forces determine the provision of these services, NBEET immediately assumes that they will not work and it seeks to impose a bureaucratic national framework over the sector. The report completely misses the obvious way of achieving these goals; that is, giving teaching institutions the freedom to discover, and the resources to meet, the demand for management in this country.

There is no need for the repressive, self-sustaining policies proposed by NBEET. These proposals include the development of a national management training framework, collection of research data, and providing benchmarks by which programs can be measured. Yet again, the bureaucratic arms of government are intervening in the education sector without really knowing what they are doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where necessary.

—Is it necessary? Let us have a look at what the Government did with the university sector. We had free education in the 1970s. There is now a shortfall, and 30,000 students cannot get places because of government intervention and 100,000 will be turned away from TAFE. The interventionist policies of the Hawke Government in education have deprived the sector of the resources necessary to meet the demands of the community. Therefore, one can probably assume that by intervening in the management training area, it will impose restraints with similar devastating results.

PARA.TAB: Market forces should be allowed greater freedom. How this sector of education should be working is evidenced by programs currently being undertaken at the Northern Rivers campus of the University of New England. The stifling centralist policies of this Government are preventing this university from reaching its full income-generating potential, thereby meeting increased educational demands that are being placed upon it. This institution is working hand in hand with industry to produce a more highly skilled and better trained work force. The university has created training programs, tailor-made to client needs, ranging from associate diplomas through to MBAs covering all of the management levels of its clients.

The revenue received from these innovative programs meets approximately 15 per cent of the costs of the Northern Rivers campus. The problems exist because demand and supply have been stifled by the Labor Government. Through national profiling, a cap has been placed on the size of the courses. It is amazing that an example of a potentially efficient match of supply and demand for management training can so easily be overturned by NBEET, which wishes to continue the destructive misallocation of resources displayed in its policies when outside resources are blocked from coming into the sector.

This report can be recommended to the Senate for highlighting the need for continuing development of management training in Australia, but also for highlighting the need to dismantle NBEET and similar bodies which do more harm than good through the Government's centralist policies. Only by giving the education sector freedom, autonomy and proper access to additional resources can it expand to meet the needs of Australians who are looking to the future for a productive and more competitive Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I begin by drawing the attention of the Senate to the date of the signing of the AIDC accounts by the Auditor-General; namely, 12 September. That was also the date on which the accounts for the subsidiary company—AIDC Ltd—were signed. The report of AIDC Ltd, which has some private shareholders, has been a public document for some time. Despite the fact that AIDC's accounts were signed on 12 September and the fact that on 13 November AIDC Ltd announced that it had made a loss of $8.8m, it is interesting that we are seeing the accounts only today. Those dates are important because on 14 November the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his statement on the economy and employment, said:

The Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) has recorded a profit of $9.6m for 1990-91. The Corporation has asked to retain this profit as additional capital to help meet the demand for equity and new project development. We recognise that additional capital is needed particularly for new investments in resource processing. The Government has therefore agreed that the profit should be retained by the Corporation.

PARA.TAB: The Government has also decided to extend the Commonwealth guarantee on the Corporation's liabilities to 1998. This recognises the importance of the Corporation's role in industry development, by enabling it to minimise its borrowing costs.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, that profit figure is totally misleading. The consolidated accounts of AIDC and AIDC Ltd, including all of the subsidiaries, amounted to a net loss of $8.9m. The figure of $9.6m as a profit is contained in the accounts as being derived from a dividend of $8.8m being paid by AIDC Ltd, plus a service fee of $1m and other bits and pieces, less a tax payment of half a million dollars. When the accounts are consolidated, there was not a profit made but, in fact, a loss.

PARA.TAB: In further going through the various accounts that have been furnished in the document tabled today, I think it is important to look at some of the notes to the accounts. The liabilities are very much recorded off-budget. Why is no provision made for losses which may be incurred on contingent liabilities?

One of the dangers that we see with the practice that this Government has developed in continuing to push accountability away from the Parliament and to corporatise activities and push them off Budget is that the accountability process has broken down. The parent body AIDC does nothing. AIDC Ltd is its operating body. That is the body which has suffered the loss. Yet the Prime Minister tried to pretend that the AIDC was a highly successful government operation which had made a profit and that this profit would be ploughed back into assisting the Australian economy.

There are many other things that I want to say about these accounts but in this five-minute period that we are allowed we have to cut down the amount of information that we can deal with. I will continue these remarks later when we move to the adjournment debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 15 of 1991-92 entitled Department of Defence—Procedures for Dealing with Fraud on the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General's report No. 15 is an extremely important report. It is one which fills me with concern. The issue of fraud in the Department of Defence is one which I have followed for several years. I have never been entirely confident that I should be reassured by the answers I have been given by departmental officers and by Ministers in this Parliament. Sadly, in the efficiency audit which is before us today, one can see justification for my lack of confidence in those previous answers.

PARA.TAB: On page 23 of the report the Auditor-General says that the failure to update a Defence Instruction (General) relating to finance—12-1—also gives the impression that `the control of fraud is not given a high priority by Defence'. I could not have put it better myself. I have never felt confident that the control of fraud is given a high priority by Defence. I say that for a number of reasons.

I remember that in 1987 the Government, as Senator Tate will recall, undertook a major inquiry into the control of fraud in Federal departments. A number of recommendations came out of that, one of which was that every department should produce a fraud control plan. It took the Department of Defence—which has 68,000 members of the Defence Force in uniform and 24,000 civilians in the Department—two years to acquire a fraud control plan. One wonders what all those people were doing if the control of fraud was a priority.

In the course of those years the Australian Federal Police offered to provide two police officers to the Department to investigate its fraud control measures and offer advice on fraud control. It took Minister Beazley—presumably acting on the advice of his Department—12 months before agreement could be reached to allow those AFP officers into the Department.

The Department has supposedly been operating on a Defence Instruction (General) Finance since 1982. That Instruction (General) has come in for some pretty strenuous criticism in this report. It is true that the Defence Department has not been implementing that Defence Instruction (General). It has been saying, `That is not very relevant any more so we will just give you some administrative guidelines. Don't take any notice of the Defence Instruction (General)'. That is unsatisfactory, to say the least.

One wonders at the lack of urgency. The Federal report came out in 1987; the Department has taken until 1991 and still there has been no amendment to the Defence Instruction (General), which should be basic to any ability by that Department to control fraud. It is a department which is particularly vulnerable to fraud. After all, any department which spends something like $10 billion has to recognise that there are tremendous opportunities for dishonest people within the Department and among those dealing with the Department.

Over the years we have seen a number of cases where there have been allegations of fraud and where there have been prosecutions for fraud. They include relatively small matters—important, but small in terms of dollars—such as contract splitting and fraudulent tendering. There has been a case involving a uniformed officer at HMAS Harman in which a number of tenders were provided, only one of which was the real tender; the rest were fakes. That is not an unusual way of defrauding any organisation that wants tenders, but it seems to have flourished on that occasion. We are not confident that that system is not continuing in other circumstances today.

There have been investigations of the sonar contract being provided for the mine counter-measures program. There have been investigations of contracts for maintenance relating to submarines. One could—if one had the wish—go through many examples where there have been, at the very least, question marks, and, in some cases, prosecutions, resulting from alleged fraud. We should expect to see a Department of Defence that is very concerned about detection and prevention of fraud in its area of responsibilities. Yet this report from the Auditor-General is damning.

The Department of Defence has made some general comments which cover a couple of pages of the report. I find its comments most unconvincing. I wish to put on the record some of the key findings of the Auditor-General. I mentioned the Defence Instruction (General) where there had been a failure to update the major Defence Instruction relating to the handling of allegations of fraud. There has been a need for clarification of matters concerning the operation of the Defence Force Discipline Act and its relationship to civil laws. The Department seems to have been hiding behind the High Court and its decisions and using them as an excuse.

There was a fraud control plan, which comprised a brief overall plan containing a number of objectives and strategies. It also contained subsidiary plans which obviously were unsatisfactory in that they simply related to particular areas of the Department, said what was the status quo and did not either reflect corporate initiatives or provide timetables for improvement. I would not have thought that showed much sense of urgency. There is a series of criticisms about the adequacy of investigations. Cases were noted where investigations either were not undertaken at all or in various respects were inadequate, something which we in this Parliament should be very concerned about.

There was also a finding relating to the protection of whistle blowers. This is something that a number of honourable senators have been concerned about. I have had a number of examples relating to government departments brought to my attention over the years. The Auditor-General pointed out that although Defence policy provided for the protection of whistle blowers, there were several cases where it was not apparent that Defence had acted to protect the interests of specific whistle blowers who appeared to be acting in good faith. In a case which has been before the courts in the ACT for some time we are still awaiting judgment, which has been reserved. From the information that has been available to me, I would think it was a classic case where the whistle blower appeared to be acting in good faith. I have seen other cases. The treatment of these people by government departments generally, and by the Defence Department in particular, has been totally unsatisfactory. I am glad to see that the Auditor-General has highlighted that as one of his findings.

It is also interesting to note that the Auditor-General points out that Defence had not been seeking in all cases to obtain full reparation for defrauded moneys, particularly those cases dealt with under the Defence Force Discipline Act. That is unsatisfactory. Who makes the decisions as to when reparations are to be paid and in what circumstances? I know of occasions on which it is hard to say that an alleged offence was actually a fraudulent offence. In such cases it would appear that the problem lay more with a lack of strong and specific guidelines for the payment of money or allowances. They have not been precise enough. People have not been prosecuted and required to repay money paid to them because a case would not have been able to be made against them. I am very glad when I am able to direct the Auditor-General to issues like that. At least we are able to get the stables cleaned from inside and, hopefully, guidelines that are more specific and tougher will be introduced.

The Auditor-General also pointed out something which has worried me ever since I have had anything to do with Defence, and that is the terrible state of the Department's records. As I pointed out before, something like 92,000 people are employed in one way or another in the Department of Defence. Yet the Auditor-General says that Defence records are not adequate to provide reliable records of the estimated value of alleged or established frauds and that, additionally, even when a dollar value can be assigned to a fraud, this may not reflect the full cost to Defence. Of course, by that the Auditor-General is referring to implications that go beyond the actual value of the contract. This may have an impact on our defence capability, it may be that it has an impact on the progress of one of our major contracts and, more seriously than all of that, it may have an impact on the safety of our defence personnel.

If defective parts, or inadequate maintenance, are provided as a result of fraudulent contracts with the Department of Defence, peoples' lives may well be at risk. We have had too many accidents in the Department of Defence in the past 18 months not to wonder whether fraud was ever involved in any of them. I do not want to make that allegation but it does worry me. Of course, we still do not know what has caused most of the recent accidents.

The allegation of the inadequacy of the investigations is very serious. Both the Government and the Department have to give high priority to rectifying this matter. There are allegations that all aspects were not followed up, that assertions by suspects were not subject to reasonable checks, or that the matter was referred for investigation by an agency which could not be considered to be at arm's length from the matter under review. In-house investigations worry me and I have put this on the public record in the past. How can one be confident that an investigation is truly at arm's length when it is an internal investigation?

A fraud report that was given to the Government in 1987 recommended that smaller investigations should be dealt with in-house but those of any potentially serious nature should be farmed out to the respective agency. There is the suggestion in the Auditor-General's report that Defence has been undertaking far too many serious investigations in-house. Of course, that leads one to be concerned about whether those investigations have truly been at arm's length. And even if they have been, it is hard to be convinced when matters are discussed behind closed doors.

Another matter of concern is the practice of several different groups conducting the initial investigations within the Department of Defence before it is finally decided that a matter should go outside the Department for major investigation. We are often concerned whether evidence is destroyed in these preliminary investigations or whether a preliminary warning is given to offenders so that they can conceal their tracks. This is obviously a matter which is difficult to deal with but Defence must find a better way. As I say, this is really a damning report.

The fact that Defence did not have a consolidated record of fraud allegations and related actions does not surprise me. But I continue to be disappointed every time I turn around and find that in some area or another of the Department's administration it has not had adequate and satisfactory records.

The Auditor-General also said that the records held in various locations were not consistent in content and format, nor were they comprehensive in that some cases known to have been followed up were not recorded as such in the appropriate records. We can have no confidence in the record-keeping of the Department of Defence. This report by the Auditor-General is pretty typical of what we find constantly about Defence records.

The relationship between the Department and the Australian Federal Police is one which obviously has to be given more attention. On page 21 of the report, in chapter 3, the Auditor-General says that at the time of the audit, Defence had not reached an agreement with the AFP relating to the criteria and guidelines on the basis of references to the AFP. The review of fraud back in 1987 recommended that that be done. We are now five years down the track and Defence has not yet reached such an agreement with the AFP. There could be wrong on both sides. Maybe Senator Tate is prepared to take the blame for the AFP but he shakes his head and obviously does not accept it.

In view of its past dilatoriness and its lack of enthusiasm for putting proper fraud control measures in place, I would be inclined to suspect—uncharitable though I may be—that the delay had been on the Defence side. That is something which has to receive urgent attention. I cannot understand what justification the Department of Defence can have when so far down the track we still do not have guidelines for referral to the AFP.

It is pretty clear why we do not have major successful prosecutions. As I said before, when we are looking at a budget of something like $10 billion a year, the fact that we are not seeing prosecutions and successful prosecutions on a relatively regular basis is of great surprise, and I believe that this can only suggest that the appropriate measures for detecting fraud are not in place.

In answering this report, the Defence Department tried to suggest that the Auditor-General's report was compiled by officers without formal training in fraud investigations and that the report drew questionable conclusions regarding the quality of investigations. It is fair to say that Defence rejects that. It says that a case has not been made that its investigations are of such a quality that a major Commonwealth review is required by the AFP and the DPP. It goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: Defence is unaware of any serious concerns by these bodies regarding the quality of Defence investigations. There are, as acknowledged elsewhere in Defence comments, concerns regarding appropriate jurisdiction but that is an entirely different matter.

The Auditor-General does not really accept the response by the Department of Defence and rejects the fact that the foundation for the recommendation for the Commonwealth review is only the judgment of ANAO officers. Those officers have taken advice widely and believe that their judgment is correct. I would be inclined to believe them rather than accept the response from the Department of Defence.

PARA.TAB: Madam Acting Deputy President, I draw your attention to recommendation 18, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Defence arrange for appropriate specialists, such as the AFP and the DPP, to undertake a review of the quality of fraud investigations conducted by the Inspector-General Division and the Service police and to advise on the need for additional or revised training of investigators.

That is not an unreasonable recommendation, I would have thought. It seems to me that it could be very valuable to the Department of Defence, yet we find that it is not accepted. Defence believes that the Auditor-General's report has drawn questionable conclusions regarding the quality of its investigations. It says that there is no need for a major Commonwealth review or for assistance in the training of its investigators.

PARA.TAB: I suggest that that is standing like Canute, unwilling to recognise the reality that the rest of us are not satisfied with the priority which it has given to the control of fraud. It urgently needs to take more action. The very fact that it accepted 37 of 41 major recommendations from the Auditor-General shows that there were a lot of areas that did need attention and, because of the Auditor-General, at least those matters have been put on the public record.

As you know, Madam Acting Deputy President, it is very hard for honourable senators to get all the answers that they would like in the most straightforward manner when asking questions either in the chamber or, more particularly, in the Estimates committees, hearings. The Auditor-General has that fantastic facility of being able to go into the Department and scrutinise the records. So we who represent the people—the taxpayers of Australia—are very much in debt to the Auditor-General. The Auditor-General goes into a department like Defence which has such a massive annual expenditure, with so many people whom one would have thought could have been put on the job of controlling fraud and preventing fraud, yet the Auditor-General finds so many things wrong. We still find the Department of Defence refusing to recognise that it needs help and that it needs to develop a sense of urgency.

I commend this report to the Parliament and I urge the Government to put great pressure on the Department of Defence. I am glad that the Minister for Defence is a senator, Senator Robert Ray. I draw his attention to the need for this report to be scrutinised closely by the Government and the need for all its recommendations to be implemented speedily.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Auditor-General's report No. 15 of 1991-92 dealing with the Department of Defence once again highlights the key, indeed, the pivotal, role that the Auditor-General plays in the scrutiny of government expenditure. It further highlights the need for the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament—Reform of the Australian Audit Office to be implemented in full.

PARA.TAB: The resources that the Auditor-General is given determine how well or how badly he is able to carry out his responsibilities. The important point that was made in that report is that we believe it ought not to be the executive of government that determines the resources that the Auditor-General has; it ought to be a separate committee—which we recommended be chaired by the Presiding Officers, alternately—that determines the resourcing of this important office. We made many other recommendations, the most important one being the need for new legislation to replace the original Audit Act which the Government has said, through lack of wisdom, that it will not introduce for a considerable period of time.
There are several points that I would like to speak to, some of which have already been dealt with by my colleague Senator Newman. Recommendation 23, which concerns me a good deal, states:

SPEECH.PARA: where personnel have been found to have entered into inappropriate relationships with contactors, Defence promptly remove them from positions where they deal with the contractors, or take other appropriate action to protect the Commonwealth and to protect the personnel from the risk of being compromised by the contractors.
An example is cited in the body of the report at page 34 as follows:

In one particular case, at a secure establishment, an individual had accepted benefits from a contractor for a number of years. Although acceptance of these benefits was inappropriate it was never proven that any fraud had taken place. Despite the questionable nature of his relationship with the contractor, the individual was not moved from a position of influence. Subsequently, the head of the unit was transferred and the individual became the principal representative dealing with the contractor on the Commonwealth's behalf.

For a long time there has been the mythology that somehow there was not really room for corruption in the Federal area, and that it somehow belonged in the realm of State and local government. But in an area where there is a procurement bill of about $8m a year, one does not have to be very cynical, or indeed clairvoyant, to anticipate that things go on that ought not to, and this report cites one of them.

PARA.TAB: I was interested to read that there was no proven fraud, but what about a secret commission? There are many ways in which the DPP could look at those facts and determine whether or not a prosecution ought to lie. Yet in recommendation 18, where the Auditor-General recommends that appropriate specialists such as the Australian Federal Police and the DPP use their skills to look at the area of fraud and related offences, the Department of Defence simply says that it does not accept that a case has been made out to establish that this is required. I would have thought that the item that has prompted recommendation 23, alone, sets out the need for the involvement of the Federal Police and the DPP.
Further, recommendation 25 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Defence revives the procedures and documentation associated with the payment of allowances to eliminate or minimise the scope for fraudulent or incorrect claims.

Defence said it would review its documentation. I would have thought that the fact that it has to be recommended that the Department of Defence carry out such a review is an indictment of all the practices that it has developed hitherto. Recommendation 26 states that Defence should:
continue to develop, and encourage the use of, analytical techniques and audit tests designed to detect the existence of, or potential for, fraudulent transactions.
I would have thought this stuff was axiomatic. A department that has not implemented these things as part of its fraud program is sadly dilatory.

PARA.TAB: On page 73, recommendation 35 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Defence develop and maintain a centralised database containing relevant details of all fraud allegations, investigations and outcomes.

Again, I find it typical of practices that have developed not only in Defence, but also in other areas where there is no central database. We seem to have moved to a situation where there is no oversight of many of the transactions, particularly in the area of procurement where we have devolution of function. We now have people who are way down the chain of events who are not supervised in any way and yet we do not even maintain a record of where allegations and investigations are made. Recommendation 34 states:

Defence monitor all cases of fraud to ensure that full and prompt reparation, including interest on moneys, is obtained either as a result of an order for reparation or by other legal means which are available to it.

Where is the record of the number of the prosecutions that have been brought and the modus operandi that has been built up with the Department to ensure that allegations, and indeed, proven inappropriate—to use the report's own terminology—behaviour is dealt with, and is not allowed to recur? Recommendation 39 states:
Defence consult with the DPP with a view to finalising criteria and guidelines on the basis for the reference of matters to the DPP.

That is, indeed, an important recommendation. It sits comfortably with recommendation 40 by which Defence would be required to consult with the DPP to pursue possible criminal prosecution. All in all, this report does stand, as Senator Newman said, as a damnation of the Department of Defence.

PARA.TAB: At the beginning of the report, on page 6, the Auditor-General says:

SPEECH.PARA: A figure of $800 million relating to Defence frauds has been quoted in the media by various sources. . .

He goes on to say that he cannot establish a firm base for this figure. The Auditor-General understands that it is based on an approximation of 10 per cent of defence expenditure, but he says that there is no apparent basis for choosing that percentage. But the mere fact that out there, in general parlance, it is talked about that Defence is in fact ripping off or allowing the system to be ripped off to the tune of $800m a year I would have thought would have caused the Department itself to have implemented the sorts of recommendations—some of which are almost motherhood—which the Auditor-General is insisting are put into place.

PARA.TAB: One looks at the Inspector-General Division on page 5, where it says that there are actual cases that are being dealt with involving $2.5m and $8.3m. These figures are not petty cash; we are dealing with large sums of money. We are dealing with a very large department and, quite clearly, the method of management within the Department is totally lacking. I do not think the Department of Defence could really hold its head very high with the Auditor-General coming in with a report like this.

The report again highlights the point I made right at the beginning that the Auditor-General is pivotal to the question of scrutiny of expenditure in the public arena. It is time this Government got its act together and introduced the new legislation to replace the Audit Act of 1901 and implemented the recommendations of the Public Accounts Committee so that the Auditor-General can carry out his work. At the moment he finds he is very often fighting a rearguard action with the executive of government. That is quite unacceptable and quite inappropriate for a system of government which says, `We build in safeguards; we build in committees and offices of scrutiny to ensure that the bottom line is that the taxpayer gets value for taxpayers' dollars'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Auditor-General's Audit Report No. 15 entitled Efficiency Audit—Department of Defence—Procedures for Dealing with Fraud on the Commonwealth can leave a reader with very little confidence that adequate audit procedures are in place for the expenditure of what is slightly in excess of $9,000m a year by the Department of Defence. I say that it can leave a reader with very little confidence simply because the data is not there to know whether the expenditure for all that money has been properly accounted for—that fraud has not taken place.

PARA.TAB: As previous speakers have said, it is an indictment on the Department that has been spending relatively large amounts of money for decades now—somewhere around 8, 9, 10 per cent of all Federal outlays—not to have a system of checks and balances in place to be able to very accurately assure the Parliament and thereby the taxpayers that that money has all been properly spent.

In defence of the Department, certain things ought to be said. Firstly, it is a very big spending department with a very large number of accounts. It has a small number of quite huge expenditures in new capital equipment when new aircraft, new ships and things like that are bought. It has many thousands, probably tens of thousands, of accounts of a smaller nature where all the smaller items are bought in, getting down to foodstuffs for individual camps and departments.

The second difficulty it faces is in the administration of expenditure. There are roughly 150,000 civilians and uniformed people in the Department of Defence. The number who actually approve accounts is very much smaller than that and measurable in terms of thousands—certainly not hundreds of thousands. Expenditure is approved either by civilians or service personnel. Civilian personnel—public servants—rarely have the acumen and experience in the commercial world to be alert to all the sorts of things that can be put upon them by unprincipled people.

The difficulties are even worse in the case of the uniform services because they do have a very strong tradition of honour, and there has necessarily developed in the armed services a high degree of trust. That degree of trust extends not only to their behaviour on the battlefield but also to the general conduct of their daily lives in all of their activities. While I would say quite dogmatically that the level of honesty and probity within the armed services is higher than in any other large group within the community, the very fact that there is an environment where people do not suspect that somebody within their group might be engaging in fraud or fraudulent practices makes it that much safer for that fraction of one per cent that involves itself in fraud.

The point has been raised in the popular press and by a few sensation-seeking people that fraud is rife within the Department of Defence. The Auditor-General says that he can find no evidence at all that the popularly accepted figure of about 10 per cent of expenditures is lost fraudulently. We simply do not know. That is the difficulty with the whole matter. Even if only half that figure is correct, if $400m a year is lost in fraud, that would go an enormously long way to redressing many of the deficiencies, particularly in equipment, that the Army Reserve has at the present time. That expenditure over 2 years, if it was of the order of $400m, would certainly clean up the backlog we have on equipment for the Army Reserve and transform that ineffective body into a much more efficient and useful body in a whole variety of ways.

I do not propose to go through the points that the Auditor-General raises here, but one matter of concern to me is that the Defence Instruction (General) on purchasing and auditing has not been updated since 1982. In that period of nine years we have probably seen expenditure, at today's prices, of about $90 billion. It is a huge amount. We have embarked on some very big defence contracts in that time. At the end of 1981 we signed the FA18 contract which at that time was the biggest defence contract that had been signed. Since then we have signed the Collins submarine contract which was larger than the FA18 contract. Later we signed the Anzac ship contract. So the requirement to update procedures as incorporated in the Defence Instruction (General) has increased with the passing of the years.

The whole matter of investigative procedures is dealt with in the report. Again, it is disturbing that so little has been done on that matter. There is also the matter of liaison with the Australian Federal Police. They are only a few of the matters that have been raised in this report, but I think it is a matter of concern that so little in the way of the effective checks and balances of a modern accounting system are in place within one of the big and most important departments of State.

I emphasise that I cannot come to a conclusion as to the extent of fraud. I have a reasonable involvement in defence and it has never been brought to my knowledge in any conclusive way at all that there is fraud of the magnitude that would justify claims of $800m a year. I find that difficult to believe, but at the same time I simply do not know—no one knows—when the procedures are not in place and I am unable to make a judgment on that. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will summarise the points I made before the lunch break. The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill provides new exemptions for goods producers. It will extend sales tax exemptions to cover a wide range of goods used in production related activities, such as research and development or engineering and technical design of goods or production processes; mine site rehabilitation; the transport of goods by rail, pipeline or conveyor between production premises; eligible storage facilities or exempt ports; storage, handling or dispatch of finished goods and raw materials; work in progress or business inputs; and certain ancillary and supporting activities which ensure the efficiency of the production process—including training of staff, accident prevention, pollution control, lighting or cleaning of production premises, and scheduling or costing of production.

PARA.TAB: On the other side of the coin is the removal of existing exclusions. Under the current sales tax law, certain goods are specifically excluded from the various exemptions applicable to agriculturalists, miners and manufacturers. The Bill will remove many of these restrictions, thereby extending exemption to certain classes of goods when used in qualifying circumstances. Number one on the list is lubricants, which were exempt until about 1985. The Government thought there was too much of a rort going on—this was not a fact—so it applied sales tax to lubricants, but that has now been turned around. I am sure primary industry and the mining industry will welcome that move. The list also includes office furniture, equipment and consumables, and general purpose road vehicles when used exclusively—and I emphasise `exclusively'—within or between contiguous production premises. This morning Senator Maguire told us that the wholesale sales tax is complex, and the very small amendments we are making now will extend further the list of articles which are regarded as exempted consumables. It certainly is not a very efficient taxing system.

This Bill will bring some subcontractors into line with producers. Before, subcontractors, even though they were subcontracting for an agricultural producer, were not able to claim certain exemptions. That put them at a disadvantage in competition with general producers. A subcontractor will now be treated in the same way as an agricultural producer or mining producer doing exactly the same work. I agree with that move. There has been a tightening of the test on exclusivity of vehicles. People certainly cannot claim an exemption for luxury vehicles used on a mining site or farm; however, an exemption can be claimed for vehicles used exclusively on a mining site or farm—but it must be exclusively rather than primarily; and `primarily' means about 50 per cent of the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have a problem with the word `mainly'.
—Senator Watson is right; that is the problem. There is a new definition of `primary production operations'. Subclause 1(1) extends the definition to cover:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) agricultural operations; or
(b) operations involved in maintaining animals—
I always thought that was primary production, but this is how it has been spelt out, and it has also been subdivided—
reared for the production of food, fibres, skins, fur or feathers—
these days there are a lot of feathers flying around here on the Government side—
or for use in the farming of land, for the purpose of selling the animals or their bodily produce, including natural increase; or
(c) forest operations; or
(d) fishing operations; or
(e) pearling operations.

I welcome these extensions to the definition of primary production operations. There is also now a business test for eligibility of deductions in order to do away with hobby farms of 20 or 30 acres being set up and used as a rort to attain sales tax deduction eligibility. Over the years Senator Walsh has pointed out situations in which four-wheel drive vehicles were bought by professionals on the pretence that they were farming operators. They were often used on a 30-acre block, which to me is a very small hobby farm.

PARA.TAB: I do not understand—perhaps I will be told in the committee stage—why items such as telecommunications are not in the list of exclusions. I believe they should be, because these items are used in the running of a business and ought to be exempt if the industry is exempt. I know that telephones can be used for private calls, but who wants to make private calls from work?

Transitional arrangements were announced in the 12 March statement. Here we are in December and this legislation has not gone through; it certainly will not get royal assent for a while. Under this legislation, it may be possible to get a refund for certain goods which were bought after 12 March and which have not been used yet. I cannot see why that provision was put in. If those goods were bought after 12 March, unless the purchaser expected the Government to be much faster in getting the legislation through, they must have been bought with an expectation of using them. An example is lubricants. I think a 200-litre drum of lubricant cost the best part of $500 or $600 the last time I bought one, which was probably a couple of weeks ago, and it still had sales tax on it. Unfortunately, those things are bought to be used; but as soon as they are opened, a sales tax rebate cannot be claimed on them. The adviser for the Government is smiling at that, but can he tell me who would buy that sort of item, or any other sort of item, with the expectation of claiming a refund of sales tax after royal assent has been granted? The interest alone on a $500 item which was bought last March would hardly make up for sales tax that might be refunded. I think the transitional arrangements should not have been proceeded with.

The explanatory memorandum estimates that the forgoing of revenue in a full year will be $445m in 1992-93, and that in this part of 1991-92 it will be $240m. Perhaps the Government knew when it made the announcement on 12 March that the legislation would not be put through until now. How much of that $240m would have been lost if the legislation had been brought in last March? I have calculated that about $180m would have gone into the pockets of hard-pushed producers around Australia instead of into the Government's coffers.

The Government said there would have been a flow-on benefit from the $445m of revenue forgone to industries of $1 billion. From that we can say that roughly $360m of flow-on benefit to industries such as primary industry and the mining industry around Australia has been forgone, yet last March the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) took the kudos, the pats on the back, for it. Of course, that has been a mish-mash and all these things could have been served far better by the provisions in the Hewson package.

One of the biggest troubles with the wholesale sales tax system is the sorts of regulations and rulings—rulings which are more a splitting of hairs—on whether or not an item is exempt. I will give honourable senators one very small example: the ruling on a stock crate and transporting vehicle. These facts were given to the Taxation Office, and a ruling was made on 5 May 1988. These are the basics:

SPEECH.PARA: There are two methods of constructing articles that are commonly known as livestock carriers. The first is the manufacture of a complete unit from the wheels up including floor, sides, gates, etc. to form a single unit. This is normally referred to as a fully integrated unit. The second method involves the separate manufacture of a stock crate and a semi-trailer and the subsequent fixing together by bolting. The latter unit is sold as a semi-trailer and a stock crate and each has its own serial number. While they are normally joined together by bolting, distributors of these units consider them to be separate items.
I do not know whether the distributors of these units consider them to be separate items or whether that is the ruling of the Tax Office. I move on to the description of a dolly trailer:

A `dolly' trailer consists of a turntable mounted on a chassis having one or more axles with a draw bar incorporating a towing eye. It is used to attach one livestock carrier to another, e.g. in the case of road trains where a number of semi-trailers are attached to a prime mover. Where the dolly trailer is permanently affixed to the semi-trailer chassis the complete unit is known as a `dog' trailer.

A livestock carrier may have a road train. The front trailer, which has a stock crate on it, is hooked to the prime mover. The prime mover is not exempt. The stock crate on the front trailer is exempt, as I have read out. The trailer underneath the front crate is not exempt. But the dolly trailer, which makes a semitrailer into a four-wheel trailer, is exempt and the stock crate on it is exempt.

PARA.TAB: So we have five main items: a prime mover that is not exempt, a front trailer that is not exempt, a front crate that is exempt, a back trailer that is exempt, and a back stock crate that is exempt. Can any honourable senator tell me why there should be any difference in the categorisation of any of those components for wholesale sales tax? If anyone has an argument that there should be wholesale sales tax on the whole lot, I will listen to that—although I would argue, to the contrary, that there should not be any wholesale sales tax on any of those components. The Tax Office ruled:

Fully integrated livestock carriers are carriers designed for attachment to vehicles. They qualify for exemption under sub-item 1(28A), First Schedule, when purchased for use in the agricultural industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think I will go any further on that point. I have explained the mishmash operation of sales tax. The goods and services system which would be in force under the Hewson package would be far simpler—contrary to what Senator Maguire said this morning. As I said earlier on, at present we have different categories of uses and different rates. Under the goods and services tax, there would be only one flat rate. I quote from our goods and services package:

Multiple Rates. The wholesale sales tax applies multiple rates (0, 10, 20 and 30 per cent) to a range of goods, resulting in significant classification problems and costly administration and compliance.

Yet Senator Maguire said that the compliance costs only 49c per $100. But I ask him: is that 49c the cost to the Tax Office or does it include—and I am sure it does not—the cost to the primary producer, the manufacturer, the accountants or whatever?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will come to Senator Walsh in a minute. There is no rhyme or reason why wholesale sales tax is levied at different rates. For example, wholesale sales tax is levied at 10 per cent on dishwashers, 20 per cent on school exercise books and 30 per cent on wristwatches; cotton buds are taxed but cotton balls are not; toothpaste is taxed but toothbrushes are not; above-ground pools are taxed but in-ground pools are not; and free-standing wardrobes are taxed but built-in wardrobes are not. The reason for introducing different classifications within the wholesale sales tax may have been clear when it was introduced in 1930, but I am afraid it has not been very clear since.

PARA.TAB: Under the wholesale sales tax, there is a cascading effect down the line on different products. Some are listed on page 50 of the goods and services tax package, in case honourable senators have not read them. On housing there is a 7.4 per cent effect; fuel, 4 per cent; food, 3.3 per cent; clothing and footwear, 1.8 per cent—and the Government said that we did not have any wholesale sales tax on those goods; furnishings and appliances, 8.5 per cent; household equipment, 4.4 per cent; medical services, 1.3 per cent; transport, 8.1 per cent; recreation, 3.5 per cent; personal care, 5.9 per cent; miscellaneous, 4.7—an average effect of 5.4 per cent. We can see from that listing just what the problems are.

Senator Maguire also used one of my colleagues in the House of Representatives, Mr Howard, to try to knock the idea of a goods and services tax. He cited the number of the page from which he was quoting. I then thought I would read Mr Howard's speech, made on 12 March 1981, just to see for myself how much of it he was quoting and whether or not he was quoting it in full. But Senator Maguire's strongest supporter, who spoke straight after Mr Howard had resumed his seat, was none other than the honourable member for Gellibrand, Mr Willis—and he has been in the news lately. I will just quote from what he had to say after opening his remarks:

SPEECH.PARA: This statement must be seen as an attempt by the Treasurer to keep alive the prospect of the introduction at some future date of a broad-based indirect tax.

PARA.TAB: In the past two years, the Treasurer—

SPEECH.PARA: who at that time was Mr Howard—

has twice tried to get the Government to agree to the implementation of a broad-based indirect tax; that is, a tax which would apply to the general array of goods and services which are purchased by consumers in this country. Twice he has been unsuccessful—
okay, we will give him that—

in trying to get the Government to adopt his position. In this statement today we see him again spelling out the advantages, as he sees them, of such a scheme and quite clearly trying to keep alive the possibility of the introduction of such a tax at a future date.

We are now 10 years down the track. I am glad Senator Maguire quoted Mr Howard because that gave me the idea to look up for myself what Mr Howard did have to say. And there we have it—Mr Howard had for an ally in that debate none other than Mr Willis himself.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, though I welcome these measures that we have gained—especially for the primary and mining industries—as I have said, the wholesale sales tax system must be a mess when, with the simple sort of amendment we are dealing with now, we have to have an explanatory memorandum of the size we have to explain it all. The Hewson way is the way to go, because all that mishmash will be done away with and there will be a return to one single rate of tax. I will be supporting the amendment which will be moved later by my colleague Senator Short.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to participate in this debate on the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3). I support the remarks that my colleagues Senator Watson and Senator Panizza have already made and, in particular, I support the very pertinent points and examples which they have elucidated as to the fundamental difficulties with this Bill. I do agree that essentially no amount of tinkering with Bills like this is ever going to solve the basic problems we have with the wholesale sales tax presently in operation in Australia.

PARA.TAB: That is one of the basic reasons why the coalition has, as the centrepiece of its Fightback package, proposed a total abolition of the wholesale sales tax—a tax that takes from Australian taxpayers, including, most importantly, businesses, something like $9 1/2 billion per year. That amounts to a threefold increase in the eight years of the Hawke Government. We will replace that hidden consumption tax with a fairer, broadly based tax which we will apply equally and equitably to goods and services. I will come back to that later.

This Bill implements the industry statement proposals put forward by the Government in March this year. It is the Government's attempt to implement change for Australian business in order to reform that inequitable, confusing and discriminatory wholesale sales tax system to which I have just referred. But if we are looking at major reform, we would really have to call a Bill such as this a joke because it simply tinkers around the edges of the sales tax system. It is claimed to reduce tax on business inputs and to involve some simplification but, as my colleague Senator Watson points out, all it does is add to the confusion, complications and bureaucracy involved with the administration of the tax system. It does little or nothing to attack seriously the problem of the inclusion of indirect taxes in business inputs and, therefore, in costs of production in Australia—and that is a very important element in making Australia less competitive and less productive than we should be, both in the export markets and when it comes to the business of competing against imports in our own domestic market.

By making even more exemptions to the existing wholesale sales tax system to cover a wider range of business inputs for use by goods producers and certain other categories of persons, the Government is creating yet more confusion among business about what qualifies and what does not. Perhaps the best indication of that building confusion is the fact that the explanatory memorandum requires no fewer than 18 chapters and 160 pages to explain the changes that the Government is proposing.

The Bill only furthers the problems of the narrowly based wholesale sales tax system. It will require further costly litigation as businesses resolve with the Tax Office where the lines are drawn between business inputs which come under these proposed changes and those in the grey areas which may or may not. That great confusion that business is faced with in the interpretation of the law is the essence of the present problems in the sales tax area.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's the word `mainly'.
—As my friend Senator Watson again points out, the use of the word `mainly' in the Bill is just one very important example of the considerable confusion that the legislation will lead to.

PARA.TAB: Australian businesses will also need to undertake the costly and time-consuming process of working out whether their goods qualify for the main use test, to which Senator Watson has referred. Not only will they have to work that out, but also they will need to adjust their accounting records to show this in order to account for exemptions claimed from the Tax Office.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has to be substantiated.

—There are substantiation problems. Despite the mass of information available to the Government concerning the inefficiencies and inequities of the existing sales tax system, the Government still has not come to grips with the real problems in our tax system. Some of them were identified very well in the recent annual report of the Industry Commission. The Commission stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we must minimise the disincentives of taxes on business and individuals. Inefficiencies from taxing intermediate inputs to business and the lack of uniformity in sales taxes are but two of the issues the Commission has confronted in various inquiries. Although the sales tax system has been the target of reform, rates across goods vary from zero to 30 per cent and anomalies remain.

The Bill of course does nothing to reduce the overall level of taxation on Australian taxpayers. It fails to widen meaningfully the narrow, arbitrarily defined and grossly inefficient wholesale sales tax. In 1989-90, the total wholesale sales tax base represented less than 40 per cent of the value of private final consumption expenditure. Anomalies and inconsistencies abound, making the administration of the tax very unwieldy—as we are all aware. In 1990, the Centre of Policy Studies stated:

. . . the somewhat arbitrary pattern of exemptions, and ambiguity in definition of the point of and value of sale in assessing the tax liability, mean that the wholesale sales tax is complex, often uncertain and poorly defined.

The Bill still allows the wholesale sales tax to penalise actively manufacturing production and all exports. In that sense, it does not go within a bull's roar of hitting the target that it was supposed to hit, according to the Government in the March industry statement—namely, removing some of those imposts on business and to make it more competitive. The wholesale sales tax remains an administrative nightmare and it falls most heavily on the poorer sections of the community.

PARA.TAB: Also, by definition, services are still exempt from the wholesale sales tax and that omission is clearly highly regressive. Most services, particularly those which are not being zero rated under the coalition's Fightback proposals, are consumed disproportionately by the well-off. For example, restaurant meals, taxi fares, hair styling and all of those types of services are consumed to a higher degree by the better in our community. Therefore, their omission from the taxing base makes the existing base less progressive; it makes it a more regressive base than it should be.

Despite the changes made in the Bill, the sales tax will continue to fall heavily on manufacturing industries. Over half of the total wholesale sales tax collections come from taxes on transport equipment, household and office equipment and furniture. Many of those things would be going into the business area. Some of the other major items taxed include a broad range of printing and paper products and the like, all of which cascade through into business costs.

This Bill fails to change the multiple rates of 10, 20 and 30 per cent which apply to the wholesale sales tax and which result in significant classification problems and costly administration and compliance. The cascading effect of the tax, to which I just referred, means that all categories of goods and services bear some wholesale sales tax, either directly or indirectly.

For example, the statement that food does not bear sales tax is simply wrong. Most food is packaged nowadays and most of that packaging attracts sales tax. It has been calculated that the average indirect cost of the wholesale sales tax on food is probably—it varies from product to product—in the order of at least 3 to 4 per cent. So it is a myth to think that food and, for that matter, clothing and things that are ostensibly exempt from the wholesale sales tax or have a zero tax applying to them do not have a tax on them; that is not true.
The different rates of wholesale sales tax on business inputs distort the choice of production processes and the choice of products produced. In its 1990 study, the Centre of Policy Studies found:

SPEECH.PARA: These distortions mean that the allocation of scarce labour, capital and other resources is changed so that the value of national production is less than it would be under a tax system which either exempted all inputs or placed identical effective tax burdens on all business inputs.

We still have a system of taxation which favours imports and taxes exports. It saddles Australian manufacturers with a tax system which actively disadvantages them on world markets by taxing inputs which, under most other indirect tax systems, are tax free.

PARA.TAB: Finally, this Bill does nothing to make sales taxes more visible to consumers. The wholesale sales tax continues to be a hidden tax, a very secret tax so far as many products are concerned, for the sorts of reasons I have already mentioned. Because it is secret, because it is hidden, it has enabled the Government to increase it, as I say, threefold in nominal terms and by something like 60 per cent in real terms since it came to office in 1983. I bet that hardly a person in Australia really knows the extent of the rip-off because the tax is essentially hidden away.
A major change in the whole direction of our taxation system is needed. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in his 1984 election campaign policy speech, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The second major challenge for our next term of office is reform and a complete overhaul of our tax system. That will be of fundamental importance to the task of national reconstruction. A thorough going review and reform of the entire tax system will be central to all our tasks in our second term.

Of course, it was not long after that that the Government had its famous tax summit in 1985. The centrepiece of that tax summit was to be the obtaining of the approval of various interest groups in Australia for the introduction of a broadly based consumption tax. The Prime Minister and the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, stumped the country proclaiming the virtues of a broadly based consumption tax—the sort of tax that is now being proposed by the coalition: a fair and equitable tax on goods and services.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister and the then Treasurer went to the summit, and on day one of the summit their speeches were all about that tax. But then what happened? Bill Kelty got up and said, `The trade union movement won't have a bar of this'. So at the end of day one of the tax summit the Prime Minister called a press conference, as I understand it without even consulting the Treasurer, and announced that a goods and services tax or a broadly based consumption tax was no longer on the agenda because it did not have support. If ever there has been a cowardly wimping out of what had been a fundamental commitment by the Government—namely, a major overhaul of our tax system in the earlier—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about option A, every bit of which you opposed?

—The proposal was option C, as Senator Walsh well knows, which was a 12 1/2 per cent tax on goods and services. That was the tax that was proposed. That was the tax the Government went to the tax summit with. That was the tax on which the Government wimped out after about four hours of debate.

PARA.TAB: The Government knows, as we in the coalition know, that a major change is required in our taxation system if we are to bring our taxation system into the modern world. We are virtually the only country in the Western world that does not have a broadly based tax on goods and services. Most of the major developing countries of the world, the newly industrialising countries—the tigers of Asia: the Koreas, the Singapores and the Taiwans—and most other countries—

TALK.START.PARA: —And now the South Americans.

—And now, as Senator Watson said, the economic growth of the South Americans has suddenly taken off. All those countries have introduced or are in the process of introducing a broadly based tax on goods and services. People visiting us from those countries and listening to this debate at the moment really would not believe it. They would not believe that we could still be having a debate which is focused on the nineteenth century, or certainly the pre-war situation, in this country. The shibboleths that are being mounted about a goods and services tax in Australia are absolutely ridiculous. If we do not introduce a goods and services tax in Australia, we will go back even further in international standards in terms of modern practice, tax administration and economic policies.

PARA.TAB: We are proposing a major reform of the taxation system, not just the introduction of a goods and services tax. That is only one part of a very much wider package of reform which includes taxation reform, expenditure reform and a whole range of other reforms in the areas of health policy, education policy and transport—all things that we know are having fundamental problems because of present rigidities. The lack of prospects and opportunity for Australians, particularly for young Australians, is causing despair in this country today, not least for the million and a half Australians who are either underemployed or unemployed as a result of the policies of this Government. The Government has deliberately created a recession as a result of its economic incompetence and its failure to produce the fundamental reforms that we all know are required in this country.

This is why the coalition is proposing—through a reform of the taxation system as part of this overall package to fight back on Australia's behalf to rebuild and to reward Australia—the total abolition of the wholesale sales tax and the total abolition of payroll tax, which is a tax on employment. Senator Walsh will probably say a few words on that in his contribution, but payroll tax is a tax on employment. If Senator Walsh does not believe that, he can ask any of the State Premiers or any of the people whose jobs have been lost as a result of it.

We are also proposing the abolition of the excise on petroleum products. That brings in $6.5 billion each year, 55 per cent of which falls on business. We are proposing to offset those changes by the introduction of a goods and services tax at a single rate of 15 per cent with minimum exemptions but important exclusions from the tax. The whole areas of health and education, because they are so vitally important, will be zero rated and will, therefore, not pay any goods and services tax at all.

On the other side of the coin, to round off the circle, if you like, of tax reform, there will be a major reduction in personal income tax—a reduction in the total personal income tax bill of 30 per cent which will be met and fully funded by proper, reasonable and carefully costed expenditure reductions and the introduction of the GST.

The net result of all that will give us a modern tax system that will bring Australia into the 1990s. It will be a tax system which will enable Australia to compete with the rest of the world. Over many years we have had government imposed shackles on business—not just imposed by the present government but by successive governments—and this is the basic reason for the problems we have today. At this stage, on behalf of the coalition, and for those reasons, I formally move the amendment that has been circulated in the name of the Opposition to the second reading, namely:

At end of motion, add ",but the Senate is of the opinion that the proposed changes are inadequate, and that the most appropriate course of action is the abolition of all wholesale sales taxes and other taxes on business, and the introduction of a broad based goods and services tax as detailed in the Coalition's Fightback! package of economic measures to restore vision, hope and jobs for all Australians".

SPEECH.PARA: Before I conclude my remarks, I will say a couple of things about the debate that is occurring at the moment surrounding the coalition's Fightback proposals and the aspects that have been debated and raised in that context. The new Treasurer, Mr Willis, his predecessor, Mr Kerin, Senator Walsh and other so-called economic spokesmen for the Labor side have been asserting that the coalition's economic reform package, including the GST, will be inflationary.

PARA.TAB: Before I go into that, I will say this in relation to Mr Kerin: Mr Kerin got sacked last Friday because it was said that he could not communicate the Government's concern about this package. I think Mr Kerin had a communication problem for a couple of reasons. Basically he is a very honest fellow and he did not communicate the Government's criticism of the package in the way in which the Government would have liked. Deep in his heart Mr Kerin knew that the coalition's package is the right and only way to go for Australia if we want to give ourselves and future generations the prospect of improvement in our living standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has public sympathy, too.

—I agree with what Senator Watson has said. Coming back to the inflationary point: both economic theory and international experience show that a goods and services tax is not inflationary. The definition of inflation is `a consistent rise in the level of prices'; that is, we have inflation when the average level of prices is rising consistently. In other words, prices continue to rise. That is not the case that occurs when a tax such as the GST is introduced. It is a one-off price increase. That is a very different situation from a change in the rate of inflation.

PARA.TAB: The one-off price increase is not built into the inflationary picture of the country. There is more than adequate compensation for it. It is part of a package which includes cuts in income tax, major increases in family allowances, reductions in the price of petrol, and a range of other measures that will make the disposable income of the average wage earner considerably higher than at present. Most importantly, it will be the genesis for creating many more jobs throughout the community with the economic flow-on that produces. There is no basis at all for asserting that the union movement would push for higher wages.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!
—If the union movement does push for higher wages, Senator Cook is saying that the union movement—
—You would discipline them with a credit squeeze, 20 per cent interest and inflation.

—I think Senator Walsh is speaking next. The union movement would be double dipping. Every Australian will be more than fully compensated for any one-off price increase—as a pensioner through direct compensation; as a low income earner who cannot get the full offset benefits in taxation reductions through the institution of a tax credit system; and for all other people through major reductions in income tax, which will more than offset the one-off price increase.
—Fifteen per cent.

—It is not 15 per cent. Senator Cook and Senator Walsh know that perfectly well. The one-off price increase as a result of the introduction of the package—it includes a GST and also the abolition of major costs on business, such as payroll tax, wholesale sales tax, fuel excise and other taxes—is of the order of 4.4 per cent to 4.5 per cent. Every person in Australia will receive, in one form or another—be it in tax cuts, compensation or tax credits—a significantly higher percentage increase in income than that. It would be absolutely criminal for the union movement to push for an offset in wage increases on top of all that. If Senator Cook does not believe me, he should go back to the very correct 1985 statement of the then Treasurer—he is a Keating man, is he not?—when he was promoting a goods and services tax. He said precisely the same thing; that is, the union movement would have no reason at all to seek an increase in wages as a result.
—You haven't done what he was proposing then.

—We have done much more. On the basis of a 12.5 per cent tax—as there were no offsets it would have a 6.5 per cent inflation effect—he was saying that there would be no compensation under the 1985 package. There was no suggestion of compensation for the loss of the purchasing power of savings. All that and more is covered in this proposal. It is absolute nonsense to suggest that there is an inflationary impact as a result of this proposal that would not wash through the system within a matter of months.
—Syntec says it is. What do you say to Syntec?
—Senator Cook obviously has not read the statement that Syntec was forced to put out because Senator Cook and the Government used its initial report in a totally dishonest way the other day.
—Does Syntec say 9.5? It does, doesn't it?

—Madam Acting Deputy President, can I seek your protection? I have only a couple of minutes left. Senator Cook has been yabbering on for the whole half hour while I have been speaking. If he would sit and listen, he might learn something.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Certainly, Senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —Studies conducted by the International Monetary Fund and quoted, properly and rightly, by the Hawke Government in its 1985 White Paper, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The study covered 31 cases of the introduction of a Value Added Tax (VAT) concluding that only in four of them could the VAT have contributed to an increase in the rate of inflation; in each of those cases the changes were associated with expansionary wage and credit policies.

That would certainly not be the case in our situation. My time has expired. I support Senator Watson and my colleagues on this Bill. It is a matter of regret that the Government does not take the step that it knows in its heart to be correct; that is, to get rid of this whole sales tax shibboleth and to introduce a properly constructed tax system, an important aspect of which will be a proper goods and services tax. For that reason I have moved the amendment on behalf of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The present wholesale sales tax imposes a tax on some intermediate products. Therefore, in the first instance, it imposes a tax on some business inputs, although ultimately of course all taxation falls on individuals, be they wage earners, shareholders in companies, consumers or whoever. The impact on industry of the present wholesale sales tax varies somewhat from one industry to another but it averages about 1 1/2 per cent of total industry costs.
