PARA.TAB: The value added tax—called for cosmetic reasons a goods and services tax by the Opposition—proposed by the Opposition will exempt exports from any intermediate taxation and that, I freely concede, in isolation is a good and sensible thing to do. However, the magnitude of that change is very limited since the average tax on business is about 1 1/2 per cent from the wholesale sales tax. The effect of that for exports is a little bit more than a change of 1c in the exchange rate. Obviously, a lower exchange rate helps business and exports as well. But that is only the first round effect.

The second round effect is that this tax, on the Opposition's own admission, will push up inflation by 4.7 per cent. If everything was properly counted, it is more likely to be something above 5 per cent. But let us be very clear about this: the Opposition's proposal will push up inflation by 5 per cent. The Opposition has pledged to return all the additional revenue it gets from its value added tax to taxpayers either as income tax cuts or as compensation. So, it has closed off three years before time, three years before its assumed implementation date, the option of dealing with the inflationary impact of its value added tax by tightening monetary policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tighten which policy?

—The Opposition has closed off the option of tightening fiscal policy. Indeed, for reasons which I will detail in a minute, its proposition would in fact loosen fiscal policy. It has ruled out the option of tightening fiscal policy. This leaves only one option to deal with the inflationary impact of the tax which it proposes; that is, to tighten monetary policy.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Short himself said last Wednesday, that one-off increase will be fully accommodated by monetary policy. What he was referring to was what he calls a one-off increase in inflation which will be fully offset by monetary policy. That means another credit squeeze with interest rates pushed up to 15 or 20 per cent and the exchange rate pushed up with it. This will more than cancel the small benefit which exporters will get from the first round effects of the Opposition's tax. It means another credit squeeze. The Opposition has closed off the fiscal policy option; it only has monetary policy left.

We did that in 1989. The Government made that mistake when, in response to the haemorrhaging of the current account deficit, we closed off the option of tightening fiscal policy and relied entirely on monetary policy. That action lay the foundations of the present recession. And you mugs over there have not even learnt from it. What they plan to do is repeat the mistake that we made in 1989. Those opposite plan to deal with the inflationary consequences of their value added tax with another credit squeeze and another recession by relying entirely on monetary policy.

The only other alternative is that they are telling lies, but I will give them the benefit of the doubt about that. What the Opposition proposes to do is to rely entirely on monetary policy, on another credit squeeze, to repeat the mistake that this Government made in 1989.

Indeed, Opposition senators remind me of Ronald Reagan because, like Ronald Reagan, they appear to lack the capacity for trial and error learning which the higher anthropoids are believed to have. I will just explain the background to that. In 1987, Ronald Reagan was still preaching supply side economics and saying, `If you cut tax rates, revenue actually goes up'. That was what he was preaching in 1980. But, of course, in the seven years between 1980 and 1987 he turned the United States from being the biggest creditor nation in the world to being the biggest debtor nation. Like Ronald Reagan, members of the Opposition appear to lack the capacity for trial and error learning which higher anthropoids have.

The Opposition, of course, says that it will have a massive micro-reform policy to make the economy more efficient, to make everyone wealthier, to fix up the Budget problems and so on. There is no conceivable circumstance under which that is less likely to happen than in the monetary policy induced recession which those opposite obviously plan to resort to in order to deal with the inflationary impact of their value added tax, should they ever get the opportunity to put it in place.

Indeed, besides not only ruling out the option of tightening fiscal policy to deal with the inflationary impact, the Opposition has also produced an assembly of alleged expenditure cuts which are supposed to cut a net $4 billion off government outlays. A big hole has been punched in that already because—instead of $4 1/2 billion, it is $1.9 billion. So there is a $2.6 billion shortfall in that. So, actually, the Opposition proposes to loosen monetary policy to the extent of $2.6 billion, or something over 0.5 per cent of GDP.

I do not have time to go into all the details of that but I want to draw the Senate's attention to one of the more significant errors in the Opposition's mis-costing which displays either incompetence of almost unbelievable magnitude or a deliberate attempt to deceive. I refer, of course, to the Opposition counting as a saving the reductions in public debt interest flowing from a sell-off of assorted government business enterprises. That is quite a legitimate thing to do. I have no problem at all with that.

But then on the debit side, the Opposition did not deduct the dividends forgone from the enterprises that it had already sold off. In that alone, there is $350m in the third year of the Opposition's proposal. I actually expected there to be no errors which so clearly revealed gross incompetence as that error does. Either I was mistaken in my judgment that the Opposition was sufficiently incompetent to produce a document with that sort of error in it, or it set out to deceive.

A large number of people who make up the Opposition clearly still do not understand and have no conceptual grasp of the value added tax that they are proposing. I explained to Senator Boswell in the Senate a couple of weeks ago and also in the Australian Financial Review last week, when he was complaining that payroll tax added a tax of $7 to the slaughtering and boning of a cow in the Queensland abattoirs, that in fact the $100 abattoir cost he was talking about was the value added in the abattoirs which would be taxed not at the 6 per cent payroll tax rate he assumed but at the 15 per cent value added tax rate. So, instead of having $7 tax payable by the abattoirs, $18 would be payable by the abattoirs. In last Friday's Australian Financial Review Senator Boswell replied and said, `I had forgotten about the savings that would come from the package because I had forgotten about, for example, transporting the cattle to the abattoirs'.

Let us consider that: let us assume that it costs $10 a head to bring the cow into the abattoirs—it is not a particularly long trip; that the contractor who transported the cattle—it could have been the Queensland railways—charged $10 a head. On to that $10 they would then have to add the 15 per cent value added tax. It is true that there would be some cost reductions for the contractor if the Opposition's proposal was fully implemented. It is true that fuel would be cheaper. There would be some cost saving because some items which the contractor presently used to transport the cattle would be free from wholesale sales tax. But it is not likely to equal 15 per cent of the total charge levied by the contractor. Senator Boswell still does not understand. He still has no conceptual grasp of the Opposition's proposal and the impact it will have on business and on transactions.

I refer to the Opposition's document, which I have here. Let us clear this up. Where does the legal liability to pay the Opposition's proposed value added tax, or GST, rest? The document says, `They—' that is, businesses, `remit a tax to the Government'. Of course they do—Senator Parer knows that and Senator Watson knows it—but they can pass it on to consumers, just as they pass on wholesale sales tax, payroll tax and fuel excise. Every business passes on any tax which it has the legal liability to pay, providing it has the market power to do so. It does not make any difference what the tax is. The critical issue is the market power of the business to pass it on, not the type of tax which is levied, except that, if a payroll tax of 5 or 6 per cent is replaced with a value added tax of 15 per cent, that will impact much more severely on business. I will say more about that later on.

People such as Senator Boswell—and, of course, Senator Watson and Senator Parer are no better—have been conned with this slogan: business will not pay. It does not matter how we look at it; the Opposition's document says that businesses should remit a tax to the Government, so there is absolutely no doubt about who has the legal liability to pay the value added tax. Who pays it in the economic sense? If businesses can pass it on, it is paid by consumers ultimately, just as every other tax of this type is ultimately paid by consumers. If they cannot pass it on—if they do not have enough market power to pass it on—it is partially absorbed within the business.

More important than Senator Boswell's continuing failure to understand what the Opposition is proposing is a letter in today's Australian Financial Review from John Howard, who was, I understand, centrally involved in the development of this package. In his letter, he defends himself against the charge that I laid against him last week—that is, a charge of intellectual dishonesty, because he referred to the employment-destroying payroll tax while clearly implying that the value added tax proposed by the Opposition would have no such adverse consequences. He defended himself in a very limited way and to a very qualified extent. I do not have time to go into that. His letter states:
I do not deny that all taxes, with the exception of those on economic rent and inherited wealth, have some employment and economic growth effects.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two important things about that. It is very important to have a leading Liberal Party politician saying on the public record that taxes on economic rent and inherited wealth will have no adverse economic consequences. I invite all of the members of the Opposition to endorse Mr Howard's correct judgment about that, just as he endorsed mine.

PARA.TAB: However, that is not the subject under discussion today. The subject under discussion is Mr Howard's acknowledgment that all taxes, with those two exceptions, have adverse effects on economic growth and employment. In other words, all taxes—with the exception of the two mentioned—before it comes to spending the revenue raised by them, are adverse to both employment and economic growth.

Under the Opposition's policy, all businesses—except for the minuscule exception of, I think, businesses with a turnover of less than $10,000—will pay value added tax at the rate of 15 per cent on the value added to the product in that business. They will pass on most of it to consumers. Consumers will pay 15 per cent tax on all the value added within the business.

It is true that payroll tax will be abolished under the Opposition's proposal. It varies from State to State. Businesses with a payroll of $300,000, and up to $500,000 in some States, are totally exempt from payroll tax. It is skewed far more towards the $500,000 exemption than it is towards the $300,000 exemption. Indeed, 60 per cent of all businesses are currently exempt from State payroll taxes. That may or may not be a good thing. What is important is that the Opposition, which claims to be the champion of small business, proposes to impose on these not so small businesses—up to 20 employees—which now pay no payroll tax, a 15 per cent value added tax, which is almost a payroll tax equivalent. Now they pay nothing; under the Hewson proposal, they will pay a 15 per cent value added tax.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: — I have the document here. I just quoted from it. Shall I hold it up to the camera too? On Mr Howard's reasoning and on Mr Howard's admission, when these small businesses have the 15 per cent value added tax imposed on them in lieu of no payroll tax whatsoever, they will shed labour. Anybody who knows anything knows that that will happen. If a tax which previously did not apply to a particular class of business is applied, the business will shed labour. The tax will provide some advantage to big business relative to small business, because big business is presently penalised by payroll tax vis-a-vis small business. The Opposition can argue to level the playing field if it likes—that is a separate issue—but there is absolutely no doubt that its proposal will impose a significant penalty on small business relative to big business.

PARA.TAB: Turkeys such as the Australian Small Business Association claim to represent people in the small business world. When the people for whom ASBA claims to speak realise what the truth is, I think Peter Boyle will be picking up a blast in the air. Either Peter Boyle is too stupid to understand the Opposition's proposal or—and I suspect that this is very much closer to the truth—the Australian Small Business Association should not be regarded as an industry lobby for small business; it should be regarded as a right wing political organisation, and a fairly extreme right wing at that. The businesses will wake up to that sooner or later.

I will refer to a couple of other anomalies in the time I have left. The Opposition says that a compelling reason for introducing this proposed change is to get rid of high marginal tax rates. I will give the Senate one example. Because of the proposed withdrawal of the dependent spouse rebate, single income families with incomes of between $50,000 and $56,000 will face an effective marginal tax rate of 71 per cent in the first year under the Opposition's proposal. That is the sum of the 46c proposed acknowledged tax rate and the 25 per cent withdrawal for the dependent spouse allowance.

There are many other points throughout the income range at which the effective marginal tax rate reaches an astronomical level—if not hitting infinity—because of the sudden death cut-off points for family allowances and things such as that. It is true that the number of taxpayers actually affected by those will be quite small, because they will not know until the end of the year precisely what their taxable income is. When they realise that they are approaching the point at which this sudden death income test will halve the family allowance or cut it out completely, these people will be facing an astronomical effective marginal tax rate because of the cut-off of some of those benefits. And Senator Watson and the Opposition claim—I do not make this claim—that high marginal tax rates are a deterrent to effort! It will not be 100 per cent, not 200 per cent, not 1,000 per cent but close to infinity. That is the effective marginal tax rate that those people will be facing. They probably will not realise it in the first year, but they will find out the year after. If those opposite are in government, they will certainly hear about it.

Let me say a bit more about high marginal tax rates. It is a fact that at around the median, the mean or the mode, marginal tax rates in Australia are pretty high; they are 38c in the dollar. I do not accept that that is a significant deterrent.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is for low incomes.

—I do not know what `low income' is; I referred to the median, the mean or the mode. I do not accept that tax rates of that size are any significant deterrent to effort. But let us assume that they are and that, therefore, it is very important to get them down. We can get that tax rate down from 38c to 28c by rearranging the scale and having more steps in it.
—Why didn't you do it?

—Senator Watson asked why I did not do it. In 1975 a Labor government reduced the number of rates in the income tax scale, which I thought then was a mistake. It has since been reduced further by both Liberal and Labor governments. All of those moves were a mistake. There is nothing wrong with having 12 or 15 different rates and there is no particular virtue in having only three. I have published this. I am sure Senator Watson has seen it; it was in last week's Australian Financial Review.

PARA.TAB: If the objective is to reduce the marginal tax rate faced by people on or near the modal, the mean or the median income, we can do that on a revenue neutral basis with a modest rearrangement of other rates on the scale. If we can really cut $4 billion off outlays—not the largely fictitious $4 billion which the Opposition proposes to cut off—we can still maintain a 20 per cent lowest rate right up to an income of $22,000, which is a higher income than the cutting off point for the 28c rate now.

It is claimed by the Opposition—it is a totally fraudulent claim—that the company tax rate and the top personal tax rate must be aligned because otherwise there will be massive tax evasion through incorporation. Senator Watson knows quite a lot about taxation. He must know that there is no technical difficulty in totally avoiding that sort of tax evasion by taxing undistributed company profits at the top personal rate, whatever it is, and crediting the company's franking account commensurately. It does not make any difference to the cash flow of the company. It wipes out the potential for that sort of tax evasion in one simple swoop. There is absolutely no technical difficulty in doing that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell Mr Willis that.

—I will. I am sure he has been told it already by somebody else. The Opposition claim is a great fraud. It is an apologia for meeting the Opposition's real objective—that is, to bring down tax rates for very rich people. It is the same objective that Ronald Reagan had. That is something the Opposition has in common with Ronald Reagan—just as it lacks the capacity for trial and error learning that the higher anthropoids are supposed to have.

PARA.TAB: The last point I want to make relates to the taxation summit of 1985. It is fairly well known by now that I opposed the broad based consumption tax proposition which was contained in option C. I did not oppose any of the other propositions which were contained in option C. I supported all of them very strongly, including a couple that were subsequently dropped, such as the exemption of goldmining income from taxation, which a few years later we actually introduced. We backed off in 1985 because we were conned —at least, some people were conned; I was not—by Brian Burke in Western Australia. I do not think Brian Burke would have much chance of conning those same people now, but he did manage to do it in 1985.

I supported all of those things and all of option C, except the broad based consumption tax. I supported substantiation, the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the ending of the deductibility of the free lunch. What did the members of the Opposition do?

TALK.START.PARA: —Nothing.

—No, they did not do nothing. They opposed every one of those measures. They tried to vote them down in the House of Representatives and in the Senate. They were opposing them right up until the 1990 Federal election.

PARA.TAB: I will give John Hewson some credit. In this document there is a lucid, technically sound and absolutely honest argument for the taxing of capital gains. I never thought I would read that in a Liberal Party document. It says that no taxation system can be complete without a tax on capital gains. I acknowledge John Hewson's role in bringing the Liberal Party somewhat away from the narrow constituency of vested interest groups and rorters which it represented for so long, and for dragging the Liberal Party somewhere closer to the mainstream of Australian life.

It has been the case for some time that the various other components of option A, which was enacted by the Labor Government in 1986 and beyond, have been accepted by the Liberal Party. That is one bit of progress which has been made on a bilateral basis. Nobody disputes that the base-broadening measures of the income tax system should have been introduced. They have been introduced, and nobody talks about repealing them. The Liberals—as a bit of a sop to their National Party coalition partners—have thrown in a few things about the capital gains tax. The case for doing so was highly suspect and the proposals cost a significant amount of revenue. But, at long last, after all these years, after all the obfuscation, all the deceit and all the misrepresentation, the Liberal Party acknowledges that no taxation system is complete without a tax on capital gains.

This is my very last point. If Senator Panizza believes that there is a case for a broad based consumption tax to replace the wholesale sales tax and he really thinks there is a case for doing it, that can be done on a revenue and CPI neutral basis by applying the tax at a very much lower rate. He could roll in payroll tax as well if he wanted to, because payroll tax and value added tax are really the same sort of tax; they are almost indistinguishable in their economic effects, though collected by different governments.

The Opposition has decided not to do that. It has decided to take a huge gamble to apply the tax at a very much higher rate in a way which requires increases in Budget outlays in the first instance, a big boost to the CPI and a big boost to inflation and which would carry an enormous risk which would more than invalidate whatever case there may have been for doing it in the first place. It would more than put at risk some of the more worthy objectives that the Opposition has in the package for micro-economic reform. Through containing the inflationary consequences of the excessive increase in revenue and the increase in the CPI, there will be a recession. That recession will stymie the Oppositions's attempts to secure significant micro-economic reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech we have just heard from Senator Walsh did not talk about the tax reform package in any way. Senator Walsh spoke only about isolated areas of the package. This is a dishonest approach. He spoke about the 15 per cent goods and services tax and the payroll tax, but nothing else at all. Quite dishonestly, he claimed that small business would collect 15 per cent GST.

—I rise on a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. Senator Walters used the term `dishonest' to describe the viewpoints put forward in the speech by Senator Walsh. I believe it is unparliamentary to describe someone's approach as dishonest in this place. It is personally uncomplimentary and unparliamentary. I believe that Senator Walters should withdraw it. I am interested to hear what she has to say on this issue. She can do it without categorising someone's speech in those terms.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—My understanding and ruling—I think Senator Walters would know this—is that the term used in relation to the Government in general is not unparliamentary; if used specifically in relation to a person, it is. I am afraid, Senator Aulich, that I failed to hear how Senator Walters was applying the term. So it is over to you, Senator Walters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia is in such a mess, and I am sure Senator Walsh would agree with that.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I hate to take a point of order on Senator Walters, because she would never have taken one on me in all the time that I have been in this Parliament—I do not think! She has taken about nine on me at different stages in the last year or so. But I ask for your ruling on this, Madam Acting Deputy President. As I understand it, she described Senator Walsh's approach as dishonest. I believe that that is unparliamentary and that she ought to withdraw. She appears to have decided to ignore any questions you raised from the chair about her intentions in her description of Senator Walsh. So I just wonder whether Senator Walters, through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, could withdraw her description of Senator Walsh's approach as dishonest.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: you made a ruling on that. You stated that you did not hear precisely what was said and you invited Senator Walters to continue. That is precisely what she did. I think what Senator Aulich has done now is totally out of order. It is wasting the Senate's time, it is wasting Senator Walters's time, and you should hold your position.

—The Chair thanks senators for their contributions. To make it clear, once again, if Senator Walters spoke in general about the Government or the other side of the chamber, then she is in order; if she spoke about an individual, then she is disorderly or out of order. I did not hear what Senator Walters said. It is up to you, Senator Walters, to conclude how you spoke and withdraw or continue.
—I spoke about Senator Walsh dishonestly portraying our policy. I believe that is quite within Standing Orders.
—It is also a compliment, coming from you.
—Senator Walsh considers it a compliment because there are so many people who could put more eloquently the problems that Senator Walsh has than I can.
—I would rule that your dishonesty seems to apply to portrayal, not to the honourable senator—a very close-drawn thing.
—Thank you very much, Madam Acting Deputy President. As I was saying, Australia is in such a mess under this Government—
—Record exports, low inflation.

—Okay. Senator Maguire is saying, `Low inflation'. There are one million people unemployed and he says, `But we have low inflation'. According to the previous Treasurer, we have not a recession but the worst depression for 60 years, and we have honourable senators opposite saying, `But we have low inflation'. Senator Aulich might like to be reminded that in our State one in three of our youth are unemployed. One in three! But we have low inflation. There is no incentive for those who have jobs to work any harder. There is no incentive at all to save—
—Where is the proof?
—Because they are not working harder.
—Where is the proof?
—I will give Senator Sherry the proof.
—Madam Acting Deputy President—
—Order! Senator Sherry, I would ask you, if you wish to interject, to return to your seat. Was that your point of order, Senator Crane?
—Yes, it was.

—There is no incentive for people to work harder because if they do they quickly go into the next tax bracket and pay higher tax. There is no incentive for them to save because if they do and they get a bit of interest they will be taxed on it. The attitude is, `What will the Government do for me? What can I do? What can I hold up my hand and get a little more for?'. We have to change that attitude to, `Get off my back. Let me get on with my job and let me look after my own taxes. Let me pay the minimal taxes. Give me some incentive to save. Give me some incentive to work harder'. If that were to occur, productivity will go up.

PARA.TAB: The Government does not know best what to do with people's taxes. The Government collects the money and spends it on behalf of the people. Let the people pay less tax and let them spend the money the way they want to spend it, not the way the Government thinks it should spend the money on their behalf. If we do not pander to every lobby group around about and if we get off the employers' backs, under our package we will get two million jobs by the year 2000.

I have done an exercise on our package that picks up a single income family on $25,000 with three children. I would like to point out what that particular family gains. First of all, the family will be paying $1,185 a year less tax. It will be paying 30c in the dollar instead of the present 38c in the dollar that the Government rips off them. The petrol excise will be abolished, so they will be saving between 18c and 19c a litre on petrol. They can save $2,000, with no tax being paid on the money they would save as interest. When one of the interviewers said to the ANZ Bank, `But the pensioners and the poorer people can't use that saving credit', the spokesman for the ANZ Bank said, `It is not the wealthy people who save; they borrow and invest. It is the poorer people who save'. So they will be benefiting from this to a much greater degree.

The particular family I have chosen with children, with a dependent spouse rebate, will get an additional $300. An additional $200 will be given per family for health insurance, if those families wish to take out health insurance—and many of them do, as you know only too well, Madam Acting Deputy President. With us, they will get back $200. The family allowance for families with three children will go from $60 a fortnight to $120 a fortnight; it will be doubled by the Opposition. They will have great incentives to take out all sorts of superannuation. Incentives will be given to them. If they are young and under 35, buying their own first home, they can withdraw 75 per cent of their superannuation to buy their first home. Under the first home owners scheme, $2,000 will be given to them to compensate them for any GST on the home, and 50 per cent of the cost of building that home is excluded from the input tax. As I said, this will guarantee two million jobs by the year 2000 and at least give our children and our grandchildren some hope of being able to get a job when their times come.

We will be abolishing seven different taxes: payroll tax, the superannuation lump sum tax, sales tax, petrol excise, the training guarantee levy, customs duty, and the coal export duty. Now the Government has picked that up. Just recently the Government made an announcement that it was going to do that anyway. It had not even thought of it until we put down our goods and services package, and the Government knows it. The Government comes along and picks up the odd little bit of detail from our package. It will not be able to pick up the lot, because our figures are integrated. But as it picks up the odd little bit, we will be reminding it daily that it keeps on pinching bits from the package that it says is so wrong.

Where will we get our two million jobs from? As an example, I will refer to two of the biggest employers in my State, Tasmania. The EZ company pays $3.7m in payroll tax alone. If it is relieved of that $3.7m it will expand and more jobs will be created. Payroll tax is the largest component of our State revenue. Cascade Brewery pays $1.3m in payroll tax. Payroll tax for the whole of Tasmania amounts to $136m. Under the Opposition's policies, that amount will be returned to the employers so that they can employ more people.

In its time this Government has introduced many new taxes and it has increased taxes that it was already collecting. New taxes introduced by this Government include the Medicare levy, prescribed payments, resource rental tax, fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax and the training guarantee levy. Those are all brand new taxes which have raised $34,582m since this Government was elected. Increases in existing taxes mean that the superannuation tax has gone up by 3,860 per cent; the withholding tax, 324 per cent; wholesale sales tax, 164 per cent; company tax, 179 per cent; PAYE tax, 100 per cent; customs duty on imports, 53 per cent. Of course there is also the debits tax which goes straight to the States. In the 1990-91 year it increased by 540 per cent.

It is an absolute disgrace that taxes have increased so much and that the recession has been deliberately implemented because the Government believes it knows best how to spend the people's money. The Government has put out several furphies. We heard one today from Senator Walsh who said that a tax of 15 per cent would be placed on small business. If he has read the package—and I believe that he has—he will know as well as we do that, if small business pays 15 per cent for its inputs, it can get that back straight away. Small businesses will be able to claim that back immediately. They will charge the consumer 15 per cent and will then have to pay it back to the Government. There will be no tax increase at all for small business. There will be no increase at all for business of any description. Business will get its 15 per cent on every single input. It will get it back and it will get it back immediately.

Another furphy that has been put out by the Government is that there is presently no sales tax on food. There will be a goods and services tax on food, on what I think the Democrats call the necessities of life. They do not believe that many of the things that I am about to read out are included in the necessities of life. For instance, they do not believe that flavoured milk, biscuits, ice-cream, and fruit juices are in this category. Every single product in the supermarket is wrapped and the wrapping has a 20 per cent sales tax on it. This includes cling wrap, aluminium foil, sandwich bags and freezer bags. All those things have a 20 per cent sales tax on them. So do pet food, beer, soft drinks, and sparkling, spring and mineral water. Everything that ordinary people buy for their homes, including whitegoods, sheets, curtains, laundry powder, washing-up liquid and soap, are subject to a 20 per cent sales tax.

Under the Opposition's proposal, all of that will be wiped. Every single bit of sales tax will be wiped. In its place, there will be one tax of 15 per cent. It will not be a straight 15 per cent on bread and butter. The sales tax on the wrapping will have gone. The sales tax on transport will have gone at each level—in the case of butter, right back to the farmer, the manufacturer, the supermarkets, and through to the consumer. The tax on the petrol that is used to transport the goods will also be wiped.

We know that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) has already said that there is a 20 per cent tax on transport—on the truck, the spare parts, the tyres, the lot. Under our proposals, there will be a drop of 26c per litre in the price of petrol used for business purposes. There will not be a 15 per cent increase in the price of butter because all of the extra add on costs will be reduced. The furphy that there will be a 15 per cent tax put on everything one buys from the supermarket is totally untrue and unjust.

When we put this package out in the beginning, we believed that the Government would indulge in fear tactics. Now, because it cannot find any hole whatsoever, because it cannot find any mistake in the package, it has gone for the fear tactics. We have had the idiotic statement from the Ministers that it is all a class war. I want to quote Mr Keating who, on 5 June 1985 at the National Press Club, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: There are three main advantages of (consumption) tax:
First, it will allow a more rational indirect tax system than the current anomaly-ridden wholesale tax, which has multiple rates, numerous exemptions, and fails to tax the services sector.
Second, it will enable us to generate tax revenues to provide for a major reduction in the marginal rates of income tax. No other tax has the same potential for this purpose.
Third, it generates tax from those who will continue to evade or avoid income tax. That provides a useful "net dividend" for distribution to the rest of the community.

Since the present Government came to power, it has increased sales tax from $4 billion to $11 billion. It has not given anyone—pensioners or others—any compensation for this increase. It has not given one cent in compensation. It has supported the tax evaders and the black market economists by not introducing a GST. The Government knows it and we can only claim that it is a supporter of the black market. How many supporters must the Government have in the black market racket when it supports that industry so thoroughly?

PARA.TAB: Those opposite in this chamber object so thoroughly to the black market being picked up, including those indulging in the black market and tax avoidance and evasion, because they are frightened of the tax that we are going to bring in. It does not matter whether a gardener doing a bit of part time work is getting cash in hand because every time that person spends his cash he will be paying some tax at least. So a lot of the black market will be picked up: not all of it—we are not claiming all—but a lot. At least those who still indulge in the black market will be paying some tax.

This package has the fairest tax system that has ever been brought to this country. It gives vision in a time when people are desperately looking for a light on the hill. Dr Hewson has given that vision and the people of Australia have accepted it wholeheartedly.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991 has afforded many of us the opportunity to speak in favour of our proposed tax reform package—which indeed goes further than simple tax reform; it takes in other areas which are fundamental to how individual Australians live their lives. In looking at the Bill itself, I suppose there is no better illustration of why the wholesale sales tax needs to be abolished—as we will abolish it—than the size of the Bill and the size of the explanatory memorandum. It is about four times the thickness of the Bill itself, and that highlights the complexity, the irrelevance, the unfairness and the illogical characteristics of the wholesale sales tax system. One tenth of our revenue is raised by such complexities; one tenth of our revenue is raised by an illogical, inequitable tax.

PARA.TAB: We heard a little earlier in this debate from Senator Walsh, who is a well-known proponent of death duties, taxing the family home, maintaining payroll tax, and wealth taxes. He is a man who is about penalising ordinary Australian families. He is the man who had the audacity to stand up and try to talk about logic and equity. His entire speech had a theme that ranged from fear to envy. The Labor Party has been unable to counter in any way the Fightback package. It has no policies of its own; it has no strategies of its own. It can only react to the strategy we have introduced and, because it does that badly as well, it means it has to revert to those age-old discredited tactics of fear and envy.

As I said, this package that we will introduce when in government is based on logic and on equity. It is based on facing up to the fact that we need a fundamental shift in our tax mix. We need to move away from direct taxation to a more broad-based indirect tax system. Presently, the numbers are quite straightforward. Out of the $90 billion we raise in taxation revenue, $50 billion of it comes straight out of ordinary Australian taxpayers' pockets; that is, it is taxed at source. Then $41 billion of it comes directly from PAYE tax, with some $3 billion being made available in refunds. The remainder of that $50 billion comes from those who pay provisional tax.

By shifting the tax mix to having a greater reliance on indirect tax, we are giving Australians more freedom over the amount of tax they pay. That simply means that if people buy a more expensive item—usually they buy a more expensive item because they have more disposable cash—then they will pay more tax. If they choose, when they go to the supermarket, to buy a lower priced item, then they will pay lower tax on it.

That is not so with the present tax system. We raise $10 billion from wholesale sales tax, and this in turn has an effect on savings. The tax is hidden. As I have said often before, it is the Government's own GST, the Government's secret tax, because people did not know until this debate began that they were paying it.

The interesting result of some of the research into the wholesale sales tax that the Tax Office itself commissioned—it is well to remember that it chose to spend $750,000 of taxpayers' money to get reports and surveys on the wholesale sales tax, never having done it before—is that it said, `The whole system needs to go. It is not good enough to tinker with it. It is an unsatisfactory system'. Hopefully, the Government may at the end of the day finally listen to the advice that it got after spending three quarters of a million dollars of taxpayers' money, but I would not hold my breath because this Government is locked into lethargy; it is paralysed in terms of policy-making; it does not even know where its leadership is. It spends its entire time in meetings—as it did apparently this morning when we had only three members of the Government in the chamber because presumably the rest of them were off having some sort of factional meeting.

I would like to have a look in some detail at what Senator Walsh had to say about one or two issues. Firstly, he immediately tried to say that the inflationary impact, which we have calculated at 4.4 per cent—a conservative estimate and not applying the non-farm price deflator, simply leaving it as 4.4 per cent but discounting 0.3 per cent for tobacco excise—would be over 5 per cent. There was no rationale, no reasoning, no backup; just an assertion. He then went on to say that the experience we have seen in both New Zealand and Canada where the one-off inflationary effect has washed through the system in four quarters would somehow not apply in Australia: we were different. He said that we had locked out the opportunity to use fiscal policy and we would be tied to using monetary policy and, somehow, by some strange quirk of his imagination, making the same error that the Labor Party, by his admission, made in 1989 when it applied monetary policy in such a way that the economy was strangled while the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, kept talking to us about soft landings.

Senator Walsh and Mr Keating are very good, fanciful speakers. They do not rely too much on the facts but they do use the technique of repeating fallacious statements. We saw that again and again when Senator Walsh was the Minister for Finance. He would trot out an incorrect figure and repeat it so often that, in the end, some people would believe it was correct. But this time the boot is on the other foot. This time, when he tries to trot out fallacious figures, people see them for what they are. Those figures are not given any credit because people are fed up with being misled by this Government and led into hardship, bankruptcy and destroyed lives—one million Australians being unemployed.

Our Fightback package offers hope. It offers the proposition that says, `We are here where we do not want to be, where the economy is in a mess, and we want to be over there. Here is the plan for how we are going to get there'. In other words, the Fightback package offers both hope and a plan for how we can recover in this country increased productivity and increased standards of living and, indeed, ensure that by the turn of the century we are still a nation which is able to compete internationally.

Effectively, we are abolishing seven taxes. We are abolishing the wholesale sales tax; payroll tax; petroleum products excise; the superannuation lump sum tax; the customs duties that are imposed upon such things as children's clothing and footwear with an effective tax rate of anything up to 35 per cent if expressed as a consumption tax—so much for not taxing the necessities of life; the training guarantee levy; and the coal export duty.

In return, we are restructuring the tax system and replacing the wholesale sales tax with a broad-based goods and services tax. Our goods and services tax moves away from the concept of the wholesale sales tax which was introduced in the Great Depression—which the current recession is being likened to—when a narrow-based tax on goods was introduced to make up for forgone revenue from input duties, which of course at that stage were still running the Commonwealth Government.

Back in those days most people's employment was in the area of making things. That is not true now; most people's employment is in the area of services. Alas, any argument that says we should penalise only those people who are making things by taxing them, as distinct from people who are in the services industry, makes no logical sense and certainly has no moral base. The reason why we give the goods and services tax its name is that it will be placed on both goods and services, so that those people who make things will not be penalised, giving those people who are in the service sector an advantage which has no moral basis.

I think it is worth putting some figures on the record to show the way in which the current Government has impacted on the average family. A single income couple with two children on average weekly earnings is nearly five per cent worse off than that family was just over eight years ago when this Government came to power. Gone are the days in 1984 when a family could spend an average of $17 a week on health and education; that cost is now $33 a week.

The dream of home ownership has become a nightmare for many Australians. We should bear in mind that it is that dream of ordinary Australians to have a family home that Senator Walsh and his ilk would put a capital gains tax on. That is certainly something that we would never do and have rejected. The average Australian family home today costs approximately double what it did when this Government came into office. What would have taken the equivalent of four times average annual earnings to buy now takes 5 1/2 years average annual earnings. In other words, people have to work harder and longer to acquire the same home that they could have had eight years ago.

In the last eight years the Federal Government's tax take has increased by 34 per cent. Personal income tax has increased by 30 per cent, sales tax by 60 per cent and fuel tax by a staggering 189 per cent. This is a country which has been described as suffering the tyranny of distance; this is a country which has great distances to cover; yet we tax the very means that we have to cover those distances.

As I mentioned before, I often hear the Government ask, `Why are you going to tax the necessities of life?'. For thousands of Australian families who live in the west of Sydney, being a two-car family is a necessity of life in order to get to a job, to get about, to get to see grandparents and to have some sort of interaction with the rest of the community. What we will do by removing that excise on petroleum products is make it, on average, $10 to $11 cheaper each time that family fills up the petrol tank. Believe me, for a family struggling to make ends meet, that reduction in the cost of getting around is an enormous benefit in meeting the necessities of Australians' lives.

Let us look at the question of baby food, which is often trotted out in accordance with that emotional response. The Labor Party would have us believe it is tax free. It is not. Let us look at the way in which it is manufactured and produced and where the inputs are—inputs for which there is no rebate or refund. Let us say that I am a manufacturer of baby food. In my factory I need a fork-lift truck to move the pallets with the baby food on them. Because it is an aid to manufacture, I do not have to pay wholesale sales tax on that fork-lift truck. But immediately my baby food leaves the factory, it goes onto a truck and sales tax is paid on the truck and fuel excise is paid on the petrol that goes into it. The cost of the baby food has already increased as we transport it from my factory to the wholesaling outlet.

The wholesaling outlet will also need a fork-lift truck to move the baby food around. It is no longer in the manufacturing sector; it is now in the distribution area. Therefore, wholesale sales tax is payable on the fork-lift truck in the wholesaling sector. When the baby food leaves that wholesaling centre it goes back on a truck, with wholesale sales tax paid on the truck and fuel excise paid on the fuel to get it to the retail outlet, where it is stored on shelves and dealt with in a host of ways on which, again, there is an impact of wholesale sales tax. We have not even talked about the more important impact of payroll tax which, in turn, contributes to the cost of that baby food.

It has been estimated by one of the organisations which represents supermarket owners that, when our package is introduced, far from there being a negative impact on the consumer, it is likely that the overall bill to be paid on leaving a supermarket could reduce by five per cent because of the collective abolition of taxes and because of the overall benefit that is gained from the mix of products bought. For instance, on Coca-Cola we presently pay 20 per cent tax. That is an interesting story on its own, because if we buy still spring water we pay none, even if it is imported. If we buy orange juice, we pay tax; if we buy Kleenex tissues, or any other brand, we pay tax. A whole range of things, such as detergent and toothpaste, are already taxed at the ordinary rate. So the statement that the overall bill can reduce by some $5 is a reasonable one to be examined.

The tax area of our package has always had three elements: firstly, to reduce the marginal tax rate and give people more control over the amount of tax they pay; secondly, to abolish the wholesale sales tax and replace it with a goods and services tax; and, thirdly, to introduce a compensation package to assist those people who are unable to benefit from the restructured tax system.

The figures that we are propounding are quite dramatic, as are the cuts in the marginal tax rates. By raising the threshold from $5,400 to $7,000 it is estimated that an additional 320,000 low income earners will no longer have to pay income tax at all. The marginal rates will be cut across the board and are quite intentionally targeted at middle income earners—the same group of people that Sir Robert Menzies called the forgotten people. These are the people who have been unmercifully squashed by this Labor Government. It is that middle group of people which has been so hurt by the policies that this Government has introduced.

The reason that the Fightback package has caught the imagination of the Australian people is that they know that they have been unfairly treated; they know how the accord has impacted upon their wages; they know without anybody telling them how the tax rate has risen via bracket creep; and they know how automatic indexation has affected the things they buy on a daily basis. When the Government comes to refute, or to attempt to refute, our package—and, as I said, the only thing it can do is try to attack it because it has no policies of its own—it does it in the face of the fact that ordinary Australians know how much this Government has hurt them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, I was dealing with the benefits that the Opposition's Fightback package will bring to ordinary Australian families. It has captured the imagination of Australians because it offers hope; it offers a plan; and it offers logic and equity. I dealt with the comments of Senator Walsh, who was using that well-known technique of the Labor Party: when one does not have a good argument or policy of one's own, one appeals to the base elements of fear and envy. I was reminding people that Senator Walsh is the proponent of death duties, maintaining payroll tax, taxing the family home and introducing wealth taxes—one could say a naturally taxing man.

PARA.TAB: He did, however, make a point relating to the question of small business, which I think I need to refute now. He was very derogatory of small business people generally. He derided a particular small business organisation, again in the way that he so often does, to play the people and not the principle. I think it was important then to understand that there was a real advantage for small business people. At the moment, if a retailer is selling products which are subject to the wholesale sales tax, it is necessary for him to raise the money in order to pay the tax at the wholesale point of sale and he does not recover that money until he sells the product. Depending upon the life of that product, it could be three months, six months or never. In the meantime, many small business people have to go to their bank and raise an overdraft, on which they are paying interest rates—which have been very high for a long period due to the monetary policy of this Government—in order to meet a bill from the tax man. They do not recoup that money. It will be either exclusive of the interest they have had to pay or their margin would have to be raised more in order to recoup that amount of money.

Under the goods and services tax proposal, it will be a much more equitable situation in that, because it is a value added tax where the tax is paid at every transaction, equally at every transaction a full refund is paid of the tax that is incurred on the level immediately preceding the transaction. That enables the small businessman to have those inputs relieved of taxation. To the small businessman this means that cash flow can increase. He is entitled to get his refund long before the goods are sold. So there is a boost to his cash flow.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying everyone will be better off?

—I never make statements like the Labor Party does. I remember well the statement that no child shall live in poverty; I remember well the statement that there shall never be a capital gains tax; and I remember well the promises the Labor Party made in global or universal terms. We are honest in that we say the vast majority of Australians will benefit and those who do not will be compensated. If Senator McMullan wishes to be dishonest, that is a matter for him. But we will not be dishonest in that manner.

PARA.TAB: I am talking about the small business people who have been subject to the wholesale sales tax and have had to borrow money from their bank in order to pay the tax that the Government likes to impose and defend. It thinks it is a good tax. As I have said, there can be an increase in cash flow for that small business person.

Of course, the other thing which is of importance to small business people is that the paperwork will be simple. We will not be reliant, as we are now, on the very wide ranging and very difficult to interpret rulings of the Commissioner of Taxation. I will give honourable senators an example to remind them how difficult these rulings are. As I said before the dinner break, if we buy a can of Coca-Cola or a can of Fanta, then we are paying a 20 per cent tax. If we like to drink natural spring water which has no bubbles, then it is tax free. If we like to drink natural spring water which has bubbles, then we pay a 20 per cent tax. If we like to drink natural spring water which has no bubbles but the label of which says it is mineral water, then we pay a 20 per cent tax. If we like to drink natural spring water which is not called mineral water but the label of which displays the minerals contained in the water, then we pay no tax.

So we get into the wonderful situation where we can pay a 20 per cent tax on a popular soft drink that children and adults like to drink, but if we choose to drink perhaps a rather more expensive spring water that may be imported, of course we will not pay the wholesale sales tax. That is a very good example of the sheer stupidity of the gyrations that the Commissioner has to go through to make determinations. All of that will be abolished, of course.

I turn now to the issue of imports and exports, and in particular to tax on exports. Of course, this Bill had its origin in the 12 March statement. That was some several months ago. Of course, everyone will recall that the Government's idea of priority was to ban freedom of speech, so we had to have a guillotine to put that Bill through, while this Bill, which was foreshadowed in the 12 March statement, to ease the burden on exporters could go on waiting and being pushed back repeatedly because the Government clearly did not believe it to be important.

However, prior to the introduction of this Bill, the result of the imposition of wholesale sales tax on business inputs has in fact been acting as a tax on exports. Monash University has estimated that about 10 per cent of the wholesale sales tax or $1 billion is a tax on inputs falling on exports and is equivalent to an export tax of 2 per cent. This Bill is designed to improve that situation but does not really go anywhere near far enough to alleviate in any way some of the major problems that flow from those input taxes, which of course is the cascading effect.

For those honourable senators who do not understand what `cascading' means, it basically means that we pay a tax on the tax. One of the fundamental and underlying principles of our tax package is that we do not have a tax upon a tax. But, in spite of the exemptions that the Government has conceded in the March industry statement, even after the passage of this Bill, there are still to be business inputs which will not be subject to the exemptions from the wholesale sales tax. That is the important point.

TALK.START.PARA: —You say there is no cascading in your proposals? Of course there is!
—If Senator McMullan listens, he might learn something. Under our package, there is no cascading effect. Got it?
—Do you want a bet?

—Yes, indeed. But underneath the Government's proposals in this Bill the cascading effect remains in place and, indeed, business inputs are still attracting the wholesale sales tax. Of course, the only way to cure this is to adopt the package that we are introducing.

PARA.TAB: I suppose the most important point to emerge from this debate is that the Government is simply floundering. It is paralysed in terms of policy. It has no policies of its own. When it comes to counter the things that we say, it cannot come back and say, `We've got a splendid policy; this is what we would do'. No, Government senators have to try to find potholes or shoot grapeshot into a policy which has caught the imagination of the Australian people.

I heard Senator Gareth Evans in this chamber today. It was a delight to see him on his feet. I am sure the viewers enjoyed it. He knows so little about economics. He is very concerned about the human rights of people in places such as Cambodia and other parts of the world, but he has no concern that here in Australia his own Government is banning freedom of speech for ordinary Australian people—with the help of the Australian Democrats, of course, whose price for this was $1.8m of so-called free advertising, for which the shareholders of commercial television stations must pay.

Senator Evans was making a rather bad fist of talking about things economic today. I was amazed that he had the audacity to stand there and defend the Government's record, saying that everything is terrific. If those opposite go out into broad Australia—and I suggest that some honourable senators who are presently on the Government benches should go out and meet some Australians—they will find that the people are not satisfied. They will find that the people hurt; they will find that one million of them are unemployed, and that family life is being disintegrated. Yet we had the spectacle of Senator Evans standing there saying, `We've got great policies, we've done the right thing, we are all terrific; and if you ever vote for us again you'll get more of the same'. That is exactly what the Australian people are saying that they will not have. They are saying to the coalition, `You've caught our imagination; you've given us a vision and you've given us a plan'.

As I said right at the beginning of my remarks, this poor, pathetic Bill has an explanatory memorandum which is twice as big as it is. That says it all: the regulators have gone mad; they have lost the plot and they simply want to perpetrate on the Australian people more hoaxes by way of explanations as to how they got us into this mess. Those opposite think they will solve the problems by changing leaders in some way, shape or form. As I said earlier, that is obviously why Government senators have been out of the chamber in great numbers through the course of the day. But the Australian people will not be fooled. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991. I begin my remarks by looking briefly at the history of sales tax in Australia. Sales tax was first introduced by the Scullin Labor Government, at a rate of about 2 1/2 per cent, in the 1930s. There were only about a dozen exemptions to the wholesale sales tax when the Scullin Labor Government introduced it. This Bill is the twenty-ninth to amend sales tax Acts in the Parliament. Therefore, something like 28 sets of amendments have come before the Parliament, and with that legislation there are two volumes of regulations.

PARA.TAB: I highlight the point that Senator Bishop has just made so adequately: the explanatory memorandum is more than twice the size of the Bill. It is no wonder that there is much confusion still about the wholesale sales tax regime.
Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators opposite can parrot all they like all night; I will not take any notice of them. I wish to relate the Bill to sales tax ruling ST(NS)3005, which came into effect on 21 March 1991. My colleague Senator Panizza covered some of the points that I wish to raise with regard to this matter. This sales tax ruling is headed `Goods for Use in the Agricultural Industry'. It in fact clarified the position of agriculture in many areas. It removed a number of anomalies that existed and allowed farmers to seek exemption on inputs to production in many areas, with confidence that they were in fact operating within the law.

PARA.TAB: Through the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan), who is at the table, I ask the responsible Minister: will this ruling be left in place or will it be altered as a result of this legislation? To begin with, I want to highlight what appears to be an anomaly at the beginning of the legislation. The general outline in the explanatory notes explains goods producers, cargo handling, R&D activities, subcontractors, new activities, office furniture and lubricants, the main use test and so on. The section about the main use test states:

SPEECH.PARA: The new exemptions will apply where more than 50% of the use of goods is in one or more eligible activities.

If we turn to the taxation ruling that was put in place on 21 March this year, with regard to the definition of goods that will apply, we find the words `primarily and principally'. Once upon a time, `primarily and principally' meant more than 50 per cent of the use of the particular goods.

PARA.TAB: We find that the definition has been changed. Honourable senators on the Government benches can shake their heads as much as they like but that is precisely what it meant. Paragraph 3.12 of taxation ruling 3005 now states:

SPEECH.PARA: "Primarily and principally" means the first ranking of the possible or usual uses of the goods being considered. It is not necessary that the use in question accounts for a majority of the usage, but it must exceed any other usage.

That is in direct conflict with the definition of the main use test. I put this question to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, who is at the table: will we find that, after much negotiation by the industry to sort out the anomalies that existed in the wholesale sales tax, we will in fact have ruling 3005 amended? I think it is very important that that question be answered.

PARA.TAB: The next point I want to raise in terms of this Bill relates to the question of refund for unused stock on hand. I will deal with this a little later on in my speech. However, I find it absolutely extraordinary that in some areas if one does not use all the product that one has bought—for example, one could have 50 or 70 per cent of a drum of oil left—one can actually make a claim. Yet one cannot claim in respect of a bearing, for example, with a life expectancy of 100 hours that may have been used for an hour or 10 hours. It is an extraordinary anomaly.It would be far more satisfactory and far more honest for the Government to say that a claim could be made in respect of all the items which had been bought and on which wholesale sales tax had been paid since the industry statement was made.

While this Bill certainly seeks to remove some anomalies, we still find that a changed set of anomalies exists. Senator Panizza outlined some of these. I would like to take it a little further. I find it absolutely extraordinary that, under the ruling brought down, one can claim all wholesale sales tax exemptions on a four-wheel drive vehicle that has steering wheels and is fitted with a rear tipping tray but one cannot do so if the vehicle happens to be used as a prime mover to tow a trailer. That is totally illogical.

Senator Panizza and I are highlighting these anomalies—I have just referred to the trucking industry but they apply to other industries as well—because they are totally inequitable and cause a distortion in the placement of investment. This is one of the principal reasons the wholesale sales tax, which has been changed over the years by 28 Bills, has to go. It creates inequities not only within and between industries but between individual producers within an industry and, as such, it causes distortion in investment patterns.

I would like to reiterate my concern with regard to the taxation ruling and the main use test that has been spelt out in the explanatory notes. I have to say that I would be most disappointed if this new concept of the main use test became the definition as against what is in the taxation ruling. It would create another set of anomalies and it would create a situation whereby people in various industries, particularly agriculture, would yet again be penalised under the sales tax regime.

In my further comments I would like to deal with a number of aspects as to why the wholesale sales tax has to go in order to create a much better taxation system in this country, one that encourages production and creates a situation in which our exporters are not penalised. I wish to highlight my comments and the necessity for them by referring to an answer to a question that Senator Gareth Evans gave yesterday. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The recession is continuing as far as the aggregate figures are concerned. The overall GDP result in the September national accounts quarter is disappointing, but it is important to realise that gross non-farm product rose by 0.4 per cent. Obviously, that was not enough to ensure an overall net positive result in an environment where, in the farm sector, there was a full 16 per cent reduction in output

I highlight this answer because it emphasises how tired this Government is. The changes in this Bill emanate from a March industry statement made nine months ago. This Government must stand condemned for not having introduced those measures then. Had it done so, the disastrous position stated yesterday by Senator Evans would have been better in the non-farm sector and significantly better in the farm sector. This Government, through its discredited former Treasurer, Mr Paul Keating, organised the recession we had to have, and the lack of policy initiatives and the incapacity of Mr Hawke and his incompetent cohorts to implement policy change have exacerbated it.

PARA.TAB: Even these changes would leave our transport industry the heaviest taxed industry in this country, and many industries carrying taxes on production that are totally anti-business, anti-production, anti-employment and, as such—to pick up the words of the failing Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)—they must be described as anti-Australian. Australia will not and cannot be internationally competitive whilst our current industrial and taxation regimes stay in place.

We must have a taxation system based on incentive. It must give reward for effort. In our industrial system there must be freedom of choice for individual employees to make their own workplace arrangements with employers, if they choose to step outside the centralised wage fixing system.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will be exploited.

—They will not be exploited. Senator Sherry is totally wrong on that point, and he knows he is wrong. There must be freedom of choice as to whether the employer and the employees want to stay within the centralised wage fixing system and use the Industrial Relations Commission. There must be freedom of choice as to whether the parties use a union, an employer organisation or a consultant, or do it themselves.

PARA.TAB: The Government—including Senator Sherry —continually misrepresents our industrial relations policy when it claims that we will dismantle the Industrial Relations Commission. It continually does that. In fact, we will be amending the legislation to allow freedom of choice as to whether employers and employees stay in the current system or move out. By doing this there will be positive incentive to lift productivity and gain huge financial reward.

Our proposal with regard to the changes contained in the tax reform package will mean that 90 per cent of Australians will be paying 30c in the dollar or less on taxable income. What an incentive that will be for people to lift their productivity. It will mean that the inequitable wholesale sales tax, which is charged at varying rates ranging from 10 per cent to 30 per cent and at different levels between industries, will go.

The current wholesale sales tax, because of its selective application, causes distortion in investments. I want to pick up a point that Senator Walsh made. Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, he tried to argue that our proposal to remove payroll tax would benefit industries paying the payroll tax and would disadvantage those which do not. That is just a nonsense argument. The payroll tax has caused a distortion in investment and it has cost employment.

It must be remembered that the wholesale sales tax targets exports and favours imports. It saddles Australian manufacturers with a tax system which actively disadvantages them on world markets by taxing inputs which, under most other indirect tax systems, are tax rebateable. Let us never forget that the man whom the Right of the Labor Party is fighting desperately to make Prime Minister after the current Prime Minister is sacked—just as happened to John Kerin last week—is that discredited ex-Treasurer Paul Keating.

Mr Keating forced business to pay interest rates well in excess of 25 per cent in an endeavour to stop imports flooding into the country. His reliance on monetary policy and his inability to recognise that there must be incentive, reward and profit in one's industrial and taxation systems should condemn him to the depths of the pits forever. His epitaph should read, `Here lies the ex-Treasurer who took Australia's unemployment and bankruptcies to record levels'. I would like Government senators to think about that when considering this particular man for Prime Minister, which they are currently doing.

The removal of the anti-employment payroll tax will give business an increased capacity to employ people and begin to grow again. The removal of the petroleum products excise will allow Australian transport industries and the producers to move towards becoming internationally competitive. There are three other taxes that we, when in government, will be removing. The seventh tax, the coal export levy, has already been removed by the Government since we announced our Fightback package. I welcome that. The removal of these taxes will all contribute to revitalising business and hence employment. They will all contribute to lifting our productivity and moving towards overcoming our current account problems. Only when we lift our export performance above our import requirements will we be able to get on top of our national debt problem and start reducing it.

Let us never forget that it has been under the Hawke-Keating partnership that our foreign debt has increased from $23 billion net to almost $140 billion net. It took 83 years for our net debt to reach $23 billion; yet in the past eight years it has increased by a further $110 billion. Hawke and Keating have mortgaged our nation. The coalition's tax reform package is designed to create an economic and business environment so that we can lift our output, reduce unemployment and become internationally competitive. Only then can we stabilise our debt and start reducing it.

In closing, I would like to reiterate what I said at the start with regard to clarification of the 3.12 in sales tax ruling ST(NS)3005 which came into effect on 21 March; how that fits with the general definition of the main use tests; and how it will be administered in the partial usage of goods that have been bought in that time. I support the amendment moved by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —We see before us a rather poor attempt to amend what is even poorer legislation. I refer to the whole regime of the wholesale sales tax. It is interesting to go back to the inception of the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991. As honourable senators would well know, the inception of this Bill lay in the March industry statement, not in the September, October or November industry statements. It is an absolute disgrace that this Government waited eight months between the March industry statement and the introduction of this Bill into the Senate. This Government likes to govern this country by press release. It loves to put out a press release and tell us what it is going to do but, when it comes to doing it, that is another matter.

PARA.TAB: I will not rely on the estimates of the costings contained in the explanatory memorandum. It is interesting to note that the Government disagrees lamentably with the costings it gave in the industry statement. I will give the Government the benefit of the doubt. I will rely on the statement of costings which were made when the industry statement was brought down. The fact is that this Government, by delaying this Bill as long as it has, by effectively making the commencement date of the Bill the end of December instead of 1 July, has obtained a windfall taxation revenue of $100m. All the while the Government was telling the farmers and businesses of this country that it was going to relieve their tax burden, it was sitting back and rubbing its hands with glee.

TALK.START.PARA: —A con trick.

—Exactly. It was a big con trick. The second discredited Labor Treasurer—not Mr Paul Keating but Mr John Kerin—who used to be the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, made a big thing about how he was the friend of the farmer. He became the Treasurer and the friend of money—provided he had his hands on it. That is the truth.

PARA.TAB: It is a disgrace that this Government waited eight months to introduce the Bill. Its implementation will effectively be six months late, and the Government has saved itself $100m. In addition to that, the Government has added another $350m of costs to industry this year by delaying the implementation of this Bill by six months.

In case the stunned advisers cannot figure out why, it is because the Government estimated that the saving to business for a full year of the measures contained in this package would be about $700m. That is a measure of the cascading that is caused by this Government's current ramshackle wholesale sales tax system; it is an indication of the cost to industry. That is a clear indication why this whole wholesale sales tax system should be thrown out lock, stock and barrel.

Before anybody pops up to suggest that there are transitional provisions in this Bill, let us get it perfectly clear what those transitional provisions are. They are not as generous as some of the people on the other side would have us believe. They are a big con trick; they are not generous at all. One of the provisions is that one had to have purchased the item but not used it before the commencement of the Bill. Most of the items that have been purchased have probably already been consumed. The transitional provision is the typical Indian's gift: he gives it and takes it away. That is what this Government is doing. All the time it is taking money from ordinary taxpayers; all the time it is depriving Australians of the opportunity of a decent standard of living; and all the time it is depriving business of an opportunity to survive, flourish and prosper.

Let us look at the ludicrous wholesale sales tax system that is the joke of the Western world and, most importantly, has brought this Government into ridicule. Day after day, we see dishonest Ministers such as Senator Cook, Senator Richardson, Senator Gareth Evans and Senator Button coming into this chamber and saying to this Senate—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crowley)—Order! I ask you to withdraw that reference of dishonesty to Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I withdraw. We see disgraceful and appalling performances by disgraceful and appalling Ministers. They come into this chamber and say that the coalition's wholesale sales tax, as part of the tax reform package, would put a 15 per cent tax on the essentials of life.

PARA.TAB: This Government may not be aware that it already has a 20 per cent tax on many of the essentials of life. According to this Government, it is not essential in life for people to brush their teeth in the morning; it is not important that a person can have a shave. I suppose it is great because it means that some of the Government Ministers will not be called barefaced liars. That is what this wholesale sales tax system does. The Government says, `We tax only the luxuries'. Sure, toothpaste is a luxury; toothbrushes are luxuries; razor blades are luxuries. They are the priorities of this Government.

What is worse—what is more insidious than that—is that this Government says to us that the more of a luxury something is, the higher the tax, and the less of a luxury it is, the lower the tax. Let us examine that ludicrous proposition for a moment. It is a fact that if we buy an atlas or a street directory we pay 10 per cent wholesale sales tax. If we buy toilet paper, we pay 20 per cent wholesale sales tax. I can see the advisers nodding. This Government is saying that it is fine to buy a street directory to find where a public lavatory is but, as soon as we try to wipe our backsides, that is a luxury. That is ludicrous and the Government knows it. That shows how ridiculous this whole argument about taxes on luxuries and no taxes on necessities is. The Government does not know what it is taxing. It does not have any priorities.

According to this Government it is not an essential thing in life for us to wipe our backsides after we have been to the toilet: the Government imposes a 20 per cent sales tax on toilet paper. Goodness gracious me! Some of the honourable senators opposite ought to wrap the toilet paper around their heads because that is how poor their grasp of reality is. It really is disgraceful. That is the essence of this Government's taxation policy.
