The Government Ministers who come in here parroting the lines that their faceless minders have given them do not tell us that there is a 20 per cent tax on most cars—a 30 per cent tax on ordinary family cars that most people aspire to have. They are luxuries in life. This Government does not tell us that if it had the guts to implement a tax reform package cars would be cheaper.

This Government does not have the guts to tell people that soap is a luxury under its regime because, again, like toilet paper, there is a 20 per cent tax on soap. I suppose the good thing about not being able to afford soap is that the smell of having not washed for a month might wipe out the fact that honourable senators opposite have not wiped their backsides in the same period either.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't need toilet paper.

—Yes, but they would not understand at all. While for some of us on this side the maxim is `cleanliness is next to godliness', on the other side of the chamber it is `taxation is next to godliness'. After all, the man who imposed this ludicrous tax regime, the discredited ex-Treasurer Paul Keating, the now leadership aspirant, thinks he is God. What is worse, half of the people who sit on the other side of the chamber believe it. They believe that this man who destroyed this nation's economy is God. They would be willing to vote for him. They would be willing to condemn this country to yet more of the misery that Paul Keating imposed during his eight years as Treasurer. That is the extent of their morality. That is the extent of their grasp of what is happening in this nation.

PARA.TAB: It is wholly unsatisfactory that this Government can come before the people at this time—a time of national economic crisis—and tinker at the edges. The Government has not even had the decency to match its high rhetoric by doing away with its taxes on necessities. If it wants to talk about taxes on necessities, that is fine. When it has abolished the sales tax on toilet paper, soap, detergent and so on, then it can start to talk.

TALK.START.PARA: —And inputs.

—Yes, and inputs. Until the Government does that, it is just a pack of hypocrites who will say anything for the television cameras, who do not give a damn about honesty, who do not give a damn about morality and who do not give a damn about the plight of ordinary Australians. Yet when another group of people in this Parliament—the coalition—comes before the people with a package of measures that will see sweeping reform of our ramshackle tax system, will see an opportunity for incentive and will see an end to the taxation on business, what is the response of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)? He says, `We will destroy this package'. Sure, like he destroyed the economy.
—Like he has destroyed Australia.
—Sure, like he destroyed the aspirations of one million unemployed and like he destroyed the aspirations of hundreds of thousands of people who are bankrupt in his Australia. That is what he will do.

PARA.TAB: The people do not care whether he wants to destroy the package. They do not care whether he thinks he has destroyed the package. What the people of this country want, need and pray for is hope and inspiration. Instead, they get nothing—not a thing—from this Government. This Government is wholly incapable of even answering the breadth of vision contained in the tax reform package. It has no answer to the end of $20 billion of taxation on business inputs—no answer at all. It has no answer to an end to taxes on jobs through the training guarantee levy, which it created. It has no answer to the end of the tax on jobs through the payroll tax, which leader after leader of the Labor Party has condemned but has never had the honesty, the integrity or the fortitude to do anything about.

This is the do nothing Government. It says, `If you do nothing and sit back, eventually people will come to expect what we have done to this country and they might be stupid enough to vote for us again'. The sad news for Senator McMullan and his lonely friend in this chamber is that the people will not be stupid enough to vote for them again. The great tragedy is that the people of this country have to wait another 18 months for the chance to get rid of them. That is what the people of this nation want; they want to be rid of this loathsome Government; they want to see it out the door; they want to see real change. But this Government could not even summon the courage to have an election, to put it to the test.

If Mr Hawke is so correct in saying he is Australia's mate, if he is so correct in saying, as he said recently—interestingly, before he visited Cairns, not after—that the people of far north Queensland were against the tax reform package, then he would put it to an election. He would go to the polls and say, `Fine, we'll test it'. But this is the same Prime Minister who is so devoid of integrity, so devoid of any fortitude, that he will not even put his own leadership to the test by calling a Caucus meeting on Tuesday and doing the honourable thing. This is the same man. No wonder the Australian people are sick of him.

The amazing thing is that this man, Mr Hawke, makes wild and grandiose comments on television such as, `The tax reform package is un-Australian'. I will tell the Senate what is un-Australian—whingeing like a Pom. That is what he is doing. He is whingeing like a Pom. I have not seen him come up with one valid or sustainable alternative to the tax reform package. What did he do? He whinged like a Pom on national television. We are only waiting for his Lacoste crocodile tears to come flowing down his cheeks. There is nothing so un-Australian as a hypocrite and a whinger, but that seems to be what we are treated to by this Government.

All the while we hear this rhetoric from the Government, but nothing substantial. We see this ludicrous Bill that will create provisions—and they are great. There will be a sales tax exemption, provided the item is used exclusively for, for example, primary industry. So if we buy a chainsaw and we use it to cut fence posts with, then fine, we get a sales tax exemption; but, if we also want to use the chainsaw to cut firewood, we will not get the sales tax exemption. What do we have to do? We have to buy two chainsaws. That is the logic of this Government.

Then, of course, there were numerous attempts by the former Treasurer and primary industries Minister to explain the sales tax exemption on general purpose vehicles. It was really quite incredible. We get to the point where we can have a sales tax exemption for our general purpose vehicle, but we are not allowed to take trips into town to buy goods, even if they are for the property or the business, or to visit stock and station agents, et cetera. In fact, the Government even has ideas about what constitutes contiguous properties. So maybe we are allowed to drive this general purpose vehicle, on which we got the sales tax exemption, across the road from one paddock to another, but if one paddock is further than a mile down the main road from the other paddock, then there is probably no sales tax exemption. What a sack of garbage. How ludicrous can the Government get?

It has also been suggested that there are other flaws in the wording of this Bill. One of the big eight accounting firms has suggested that the present wording of this Bill might not deliver all the things that the Government says it will deliver. That is something we might have to look at in the committee stage. At the end of the day we sit back and ask, `Why do we bother trying to amend this legislation in dribs and drabs, in bits here and there? Why do we not just get rid of it and have something new that will take the costs away from business?'.

On the radio just the other day the head of a newly formed group called the Australian-Owned Companies Association said that one of the reasons that industry is so uncompetitive in this country is that we have so many indirect taxes which impose additional costs on business. He cited not just the wholesale sales tax—of course that is a big part of it—but also the payroll tax and the training guarantee levy which this Government has done nothing about. He said that no country with which we compete imposes any of these taxes on business, yet we do.

He went further and talked about what a sham this Government's taxation policy has been, not for the past two or three or four years but for the past eight years. He said that when this Government purported to change company tax rates, it had absolutely no effect at all because at the same time the Government changed depreciation so that in fact there was no net benefit to business. The Government was saying, `Aren't we great, boys, because we have taken the tax off business', but at the same time it was saying, `You are not allowed to write off your purchases or depreciate your assets as fast'.

So if the Government gets it from the right pocket today, it will get it from the left pocket tomorrow. The thing we can be sure of is that one of these Government Ministers will have his hand in our pocket at any time. Looking at the front bench on the other side of the chamber, that is a pretty frightening thought indeed. The truth is that all across this country, the Government has its hands in the pockets of business, has its hands in the pockets of families, and has its hands in the pockets of battling Australians.

I will give an example of how highly taxed we are in this nation, an example that most people in this country will be able to appreciate. Take an ordinary truckie who owns his rig and operates it himself. He would like to say that he owns his business, but in reality he does not because every year he pays not only registration charges but also sales tax on parts and on his truck. He pays fuel tax, provisional tax and, if at the end of the day he is lucky enough to make a profit, he pays income tax.

When we add up all those taxes and put them on one side of the scales and put on the other side the amount of money he takes home to his wife and kids at the end of every week, it is clear who owns that business. It is not the truckie; it is the Government. The Government owns the profit of the business; the Government owns the profit of his labour. Instead of the poor truckie being a self-employed businessman, he is reduced to nothing but some sort of serf on wheels whose task it is to try to put what money he has back into his business so he can keep generating money to give to the Government. That is the Government's vision for a better Australia.

The Taxation Office having collected all of these taxes, the Government having put hundreds of thousands of people out of work and having closed down thousands upon thousands of businesses—you can bet your bottom dollar that every business that goes down has a large debt to the Taxation Office or has just paid a large debt to the Taxation Office and cannot pay its other bills—it is ludicrous that this Government has a Taxation Office which has on the bottom of its letterhead, `Taxes—building a better Australia'. Building a better Australia! The Taxation Office! `Taxes destroying what could be a better Australia' would be a much more appropriate logo to have on the bottom of its letterhead.

What we in the Opposition say is not just that we should do away with the wholesale sales tax and replace it with something logical but, more importantly, reduce the tax burden on ordinary Australians and on businesses in this country—not just to create jobs but to give ordinary Australians more of their own money back. That is a concept the Government has not grasped.

I talk to a lot of primary producers. Let us talk about the end of the chain and about the primary producer, the miner or whoever who actually produces the wealth that gets processed, that is sent overseas and earns export dollars for this nation. All along the way, taxes are taken out. There is taxation on freight charges; taxation on input costs; taxation through wholesale sales tax that makes our exports more expensive at the wharf than the products of our competitors overseas. We have the only government in the Western world that is stupid enough to talk about having an export mentality and then makes our exports more expensive than our competitors before they can get off the wharves. If that is export mentality, it is a sick mentality indeed. But that is what we have.

What happens is that all along the way the money which ought to be going back to the people who produce the wealth—be they farmers, miners or whatever—goes to Canberra to support the phalanx of bureaucrats we see swanning around in the corridors. It goes to support the army of pen-pushers encamped on the fields surrounding Parliament House. The money does not go back to the people who actually generate the wealth because this Government, through its dishonest and hidden taxation system, has appropriated the wealth all the way through.

It may be only 2 or 3 per cent or, in the case of some industries, 5 or 6 per cent, but if we add 2 or 3 per cent to the income of a country town such as Longreach, if we add 2 or 3 per cent to the income of a town such as Blackwater, which produces hundreds of millions of dollars worth of coal for us to export every year, we can see the effect clearly and palpably on these towns. But this Government cannot because it has no vision, no plan and no strategy for a better Australia. It is locked in the myopia of its own failed plans. Yet the Government persists.

To try preaching to the people on the other side of the chamber is almost a hopeless cause, because they fail to understand what they are doing to this country. But we on this side of the chamber see clearly that the impost on business, the taxes on jobs, and the destruction of employment prospects for hundreds of thousands of Australians have made this country poorer. Once upon a time this country had the highest standard of living in the world. Now we are told that it has the fourth highest standard of living in the world. I spoke to a school group last year and one student asked, `If we have the fourth highest standard of living in the world, why should we worry?' I said to him, `For a simple reason: when your children come along it might be the twenty-fourth highest standard of living in the world, the forty-fourth, the sixty-fourth or the 124th'.

As far as I am concerned, my job is not to come to Canberra to sit back whilst this Government destroys the aspirations of a generation of Australians. It is to come to Canberra to provide an alternative solution to the misery and despair this Government has wreaked upon us; to provide some hope; to provide some incentive; and to provide some leadership, because this Government has none. That is why it is absolutely critical that as soon as possible this nation has the opportunity to throw out this discredited Government, its discredited Ministers and its discredited economic plans, which have done nothing but reduce the standard of living of most middle and low income earners in this nation over the last eight years.

For that reason, I have great pleasure in supporting the amendment that has been moved by the coalition to this Bill and in condemning roundly a system of taxation which does nothing for business but make it less competitive, less efficient, less lean and less able to survive in the economic maelstrom that this Government has brought upon this nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are discussing the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No.3), which is a very significant piece of legislation because sales tax has been crippling Australia for a very long time. The contrast between this bankrupt Labor Government and the positive program of hope that has been offered by the Liberal and National parties could not be greater. On the one hand we have some very belated tinkering with sales tax, masquerading as reform; on the other, a blueprint for change to a fairer total tax regime.

PARA.TAB: It was very interesting to listen to the debate this afternoon, because not one speaker from the Government came up with any prospect of change, any prospect of hope or any prospect of vision. All they have done is exactly what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has told them to do; that is, destroy the package of the coalition. It is one thing for the Prime Minister to constantly repeat that he wants to destroy the package of the coalition, but does he have one continental of care for this country? He has the audacity to talk about our package being un-Australian. When he wakes up and says that his one aim in life—this is his only aim in life at the moment; obviously, his other aim in life, to retain the prime ministership, is on a short fuse—is to destroy the coalition's tax package, surely he has problems.

This Labor Government pretends that it is helping enterprise, six months after the fanfare of the March statement, by providing some extensions of sales tax exemptions over business inputs. We honestly believed—considering that we had sufficiently flagged that we would be exempting business inputs, that people would be able to get full rebates on their business inputs—that this Government would have the courage of its convictions to say, `All right, we will gazump the coalition on this point and make sure that there is some incentive for business to produce, some incentive for Australians to buy Australian-made products and we will exempt business inputs'.

But what has the Government done? It has squibbed out. It has absolutely no courage and no ability to work out the facts of how the pieces of the jigsaw actually fit together. All that is being offered is $445m in 1992-93, a mere fraction of the $6 billion of sales tax that falls on business inputs and investment items.

Of course, one of the great problems that this Government has is that there are so few people on the Government benches who have actually had to run businesses, who have actually had to employ staff, who have actually had to pay the punitive tax on employment called payroll tax, who have actually had to pay 21 days after the end of the month this dirty thing called sales tax, with all its inequities, with all its exemptions and with all its illogicality, but there is no-one over there who has actually had to run a business and do it all.

Take Senator Maguire, for example. He loves cheap shots; he really does. His utterances last week and today have been nothing short of amazing. But, of course, it would do Senator Maguire some good if in fact he had a real job that actually made him go and look at what makes the world tick. But no, this little charmer called Senator Maguire has been a ministerial adviser to the South Australian Premiers Dunstan, Corcoran and Bannon, and he has been a public servant in the Premier's Department. Of course, he has had prior employment in the petroleum distribution industry. I suppose that means that he was pouring petrol at a petrol station—heaven only knows. But that, according to the Parliamentary Handbook, is Senator Maguire's background. So the best thing for Senator Maguire—and a lot of Government senators and members—would be to get out there and try to find a real job, if anyone is game to employ him. But, of course, the reality is that they do not know what the real world dictates.

When this Government claims that the overall benefits of its legislation to the business sector would reach $1 billion, it is admitting to one of the greatest weaknesses of sales tax. Sales tax, of course, is an absolute and utter contrast to the goods and services tax because it is a cascading tax which applies to goods that have already had tax paid on them. But does this Government care? The answer is no. It does not care what cascading effect a petroleum excise has. It does not care how many times people have to pay it. Therein lies the lie—the lie that is going to be told day in, day out, week in, week out, month in, month out in the course of the next 18 long months till this Government is thrown out of office; the lie that the goods and services tax is regressive. If there is anything regressive, it is the current taxation system of this Government.

As the coalition has argued, sales tax is a concealed, insidious and parasitic tax on the economic activity of Australia because it increases the end costs of a multitude of goods and services that officially are not subject to tax. That is the sales tax that this Government is now arguing to retain.The effect of sales tax on final consumption expenditure for housing is 7.4 per cent; for furnishings and appliances, around 8.5 per cent; and for transport, 8.1 per cent. And this Government reckons that is fair!

Of course, when we consider that over $2.2 billion worth—21.4 per cent, to be precise—of total tax receipts is raised from vehicles, tyres, batteries and greases, we do not need to ask why the totality of business costs is pushed upwards.

But, once again, let us remind ourselves that this Government neither knows nor understands how the business sector works because those opposite have not been there. They have not had to pay the wages; they have not had to pay the telephone bill; they have not had to pay the rent; they have not had to pay payroll tax; they have not had to pay the superannuation imposts that they are putting up higher and higher all the time; they have not had to pay the workers compensation bills before they have taken a dollar home for themselves.

No, the mob over on the other side have always basically worked in a trade union situation with their take-home packages being guaranteed, regardless of the reality of what other people are getting out there in the work force. That is the unfairness of it.

We say that people who work for a living should be rewarded for it. We also say that those who condemn the application of a goods and services tax on foodstuffs should not be allowed to forget that sales tax—the sales tax that this Government fights to retain—adds 3.8 per cent to the final cost of food.

What sort of compensation has this Government given any taxpayer over the last decade? Not one cent. Prior to the last Budget, sales taxes had gone up by 208 per cent, yet what had this Government given by way of compensation? Not one cent. Had it increased pensions accordingly? No, it had not. Had it given tax reductions? No, it had not. Had it increased family allowances because of the 208 per cent rise in sales tax? No, it had not. Has it increased any allowances because of its greed and gluttony for sales tax? Not once. Therefore, this Government has a real problem inasmuch as it does not know what to do. It does not know how to replace this sales tax system; all it knows is that it has a real problem in trying to fight down an economic package that it cannot argue with.

All those opposite will do for the next 18 months is say, `You've made a big hole in the figures'. They do not bother to look at the whole philosophy behind the package, which is to make sure that there are two million more jobs in this country. What the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) and this Government are absolutely thrilled to ribbons about is that they have got nearly a million people now unemployed —and all they are offering is more of the same. All they want is more of the same.

Have we heard for the last 3 1/2 weeks one single solitary glimmer of hope or expectation that those opposite will change? This Government has not come up with one thing that it will do differently. All those opposite keep on saying to us is, `You're going to have more of the same. If you like this medicine, tough, great, good, because you're going to have more of the same. If you don't like this medicine, equally tough'. That is what this Government is all about. On no occasion has Senator Button, Senator Gareth Evans, Senator McMullan, Senator Collins, Senator Robert Ray, any of these bright sparks, to say nothing of the lame duck, jelly-back Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, the heir-apparent, Mr Keating, gaffe-prone, Mr Howe, or the ex-Treasurer—I do not know which `ex' now—Mr Kerin—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's hard to keep up.

—It is hard to keep track of the numbers. Not one of the ex-Treasurers—or the current Treasurer—or the others has said, `This is what we are going to do. This is how we are going to change things. This is how we are going to stop one million unemployed going to two million unemployed. This is how we are going to get people rewarded for the hard work they put in. This is how we are going to make business enterprises more profitable and more attractive to Australians'. We have not heard one word; it has been zip the lip, total silence. All we got today was Senator Evans performing like a trained seal, going off his brain, gritting his teeth and snarling at the Senate. It did not really achieve anything because the same problem still arises: no answers.

PARA.TAB: Australia has been fed the excuse that sales tax is an acceptable impost and is easy to administer. We have heard Government speakers say that today—`It is easy to administer'. It is easy to administer for them. But it sure is not easy to administer when one is on the receiving end and in business. It might be cheap for the Government, but a different story comes from the 75,000 enterprises which must collect and remit the tax—a very different story. Ask one who has had to do it. I am one of them. But no, the galahs on the other side of the chamber have never had to do it.

It is not a cheap and easy tax when it costs these businesses $50m in accountancy fees, $50m in lawyers fees and $400m in staff to administer it. Is that cheap? Let us see where they will rake up the money to pay for it. Ultimately, the entire Australian economy—not just these 75,000 businesses—must carry the can and pay these costs. Such are the consequences of a tax with four different levels and 650 exemptions—not just the odd one or two, but a mere 650. Those opposite should see how difficult that is to track down when one is in business. Once again, who in the Government would understand that?

Relief for business in the context of sales tax will only add to its complexity. More money will have to be paid to accountants in order to find out just what relief is attainable. Does the Government mind that? No, not as long as it gets the tax; not as long as it has all of those people out there collecting tax for it. Does the Government give them any reward? No way. That is what we are about. Sure, we will ask businesses to collect taxes, but they will get a benefit for it. They will get their taxes rebated on every input.

Will this Government do that? No. In this legislation, the Government talks about some inputs being exempt. But even that Einstein Senator Maguire—who thinks he knows everything and can come in and lecture every person in the Senate—today, one week to the day after he made the first outrageous suggestion that essential items should be tax exempt from the GST, still has not had the nerve to read the document to find out that that is the worst possible option. He does not have a clue. Unfortunately, no-one in the Government has bothered to read it. That suits us fine; we will not encourage the Government to read it because its ignorance is bliss—it is bliss for the Australian people and it is bliss for us.

Farmers are also presented with a thimble and pea trick by the Government, which uses the term to criticise the goods and services tax. This Government pretends to be the friend of the farmers. Let those opposite go out and talk to the farmers and see how many mates it has—there are not too many. But how else can we describe an exemption for two-wheel drive farm vehicles that disappears once they are driven more than a kilometre down the road? That is the logic of this Government—absolute and utter nonsense.

Contrast that bureaucratic nonsense with a predictable, broadly-based goods and services tax that will provide a full rebate of tax on farm vehicles and any other business input. Under the coalition, business will pay $7.7 billion less in input taxes. Here is this Government saying, `But you're putting a 15 per cent tax on everything'. Does it ever take into account the seven taxes that we are abolishing and the $7.7 billion less in tax on inputs? No. Senator Loosley and Senator Faulkner are too interested in having a punch-up at the New South Wales State conference —or whatever it is called. Of course, Mr Keating and Mr Hawke are too busy watching each other's back and Mr Hawke is too busy sacking Mr Kerin. Everyone else is too busy waiting for Mr Howe's next gaffe. Nobody can bother looking at the reality of $7.7 billion less in tax on inputs.

It is ludicrous for this Labor Government to condemn the goods and services tax without taking even a cursory look at the compensation levels. As I said before, the Government is talking about the goods and services tax being regressive and favouring the rich, when it is a proven fact that sales tax under this Government has had its maximum effect on poorer Australians.

The impact of this dishonest tax—the sales tax that no one really knows they are even paying—is a rise from $480 per head to $760 per head since 1983 without, as I said before, one cent in compensation. This Government might say, `But we gave tax reductions last year or the year before'. Let us not be bluffed by that. That was a wage-tax trade-off with the political masters of this Government, the ACTU. It said, `We won't ask for a wage increase if you give us a tax reduction'. The Government cannot have it both ways. It cannot now say that it is compensation when sales tax increased from $480 per head to $760 per head and then say, `But that is also the wage-tax trade off'. It has to be one or the other.

This Labor Government could not care less that ordinary Australians are picking up the bill for what is now, after the last Budget—only because it did not have the courage to increase sales taxes any more—a 168 per cent increase. Since 1983 and prior to the last Budget the increase was 208 per cent.

It is also an indictment of the Hawke Labor Government that 4.2 per cent of incomes of the poorest 10 per cent of families with children is consumed by, guess what? Sales tax. The most affluent 10 per cent of such families spend only 2.9 per cent, but the poorest spend 4.2 per cent on sales tax. So much for the regressivity of the goods and services tax that will be accompanied by a rise in family allowances carefully targeted towards less affluent families. I might add that those people who have incomes below $30,000 will have their allowances doubled.

Has this Government done anything about that? No. Has it done anything about increasing the zone allowance? No. Has it done anything about tax reductions for the poor? No. Has it done anything about increasing any of the other benefits for the less well off in society? No, not a jot. Yet those opposite come in here and say, `But you've got a little problem with your figures'. I still challenge them: what are they going to do about it? What is their option? Have they not got an option? They have not got an option.

If members of this Labor Government persist in the statement that the coalition is proposing a new and additional tax, their noses are likely to grow as Pinocchio's did, and that is very, very long. It is no longer even a matter of the goods and services tax replacing sales tax. We talked for a very long time about the goods and services tax replacing sales tax but, as I said before, it is now replacing seven taxes. It replaces not only the sales tax but also the payroll tax, the excise on petroleum products, the customs duty, the coal export duty, the training guarantee levy and the superannuation lump sum tax.

Of those seven taxes, three are on employment. If ever anyone wants an incentive for people to be able to employ more people, take the taxes off employing staff. The anti-business taxes supported by this Labor Government—in fact, promoted by this Labor Government—directly add $15 billion to business costs, not to speak of an extra 20 to 30 per cent cascading effect of tax on tax. Does this Government care about that? No. It never has and it never will.

Of course, the lie that is being promoted is that we will put an additional tax on every product. Do those opposite talk about the cascading effect that they already have in place? No, they do not. How can Labor—Federal or State—claim to be concerned about unemployment when it is prepared to tolerate a tax on jobs in the form of the payroll tax? Labor and its political masters, the ACTU, claim that they are the friends of the workers, yet they are prepared at a Federal level to defend a tax on employment a la the payroll tax.

All the Labor State Premiers—who, I might add have run their various States into the ground; nonetheless, they are still State Premiers—have agreed with the abolition of payroll tax. Yet now this Federal Government has seen fit to zip the lip and say, `We don't believe in that. That is not our belief. They might believe in it, but we don't believe in it'.

Then again, the Prime Minister does not believe a lot of what Premier Kirner says of late. Premier Kirner believes what we believe—that it is about time the Government came up with some alternatives. Premier Kirner has been told to go and butt out in the same way as Dr Lawrence has been told to go and butt out because she too believes that the Government should come up with some alternatives. The fact of the matter is that the Government is too preoccupied with leadership issues to dream up an alternative, let alone come up with a substantial one.

The fact that the payroll tax applies only to larger businesses means that smaller enterprises will stay small. That is the way this Government likes it. It likes small, cosy, little organisations so that they cannot grow any bigger and cannot get out of hand. This payroll tax raises 5.7 per cent of total national revenue compared with a 1.1 per cent OECD average. In fact, 14 of the 24 OECD countries do without this form of tax, and the coalition believes that Australia should follow suit. Why not?

This Government has not yet been able to give us an answer as to why we should not follow suit, why we should not abolish the tax. All it keeps saying is, `But you have a hole in your figures'. No-one has been able to prove that. The Government has not and will not be able to prove that. With the ability that the Government has on its front and back benches, no-one will ever be able to do so.

The payroll tax is levied upon 3 1/2 million jobs, 60 per cent of those being in the private sector, to the obvious detriment of labour intensive industries. The tax restricts private enterprise and, above all, weighs upon unemployed Australians who now have fewer job opportunities—175,000 in the estimation of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures.

The excise on petroleum products has a 55 per cent overall incidence on business. We are gunning for the anti-business taxes because they are instrumental in keeping Australians in Labor's recession. We do not want these anti-business taxes in this country any longer. It is a shame that the Government will not do the same thing. For over 12 months Dr Hewson has offered a bipartisan approach if this Government has the courage and the will to do away with many of these taxes. Has it? No, it has not and, therefore, the Opposition has had to make the tough decisions and say that this is what is necessary.

The sales tax and the goods and services tax cannot be separated from the question of personal income tax. This Labor Government has pushed up sales tax and extended it to more and more everyday items because it is a less obvious and unpopular means of tax increase than raising income tax. That is where the Government has been dishonest. It has been totally dishonest in the way in which it has pushed up taxes. If the Government kept on pushing up the levels of personal income tax in the way in which it has pushed up sales tax, it would have been out of office a long time ago. But, no, the Government says, `Let's push up sales tax by 208 per cent because not a soul will know about it'. That is right—very few do know about it. Now the trap has been sprung and the whole world will know about it.

A contrast will be made with a goods and services tax at 15 per cent that will not alter under a coalition government. The mob on the other side of the chamber say, `But how do we know you are not going to increase it?'. Dr John Hewson has given an unequivocal commitment that he will resign from Parliament if it is increased. Labor's Prime Minister is dead meat. He will not even quit while he is dead meat, let alone quit because he has increased indirect taxes by 208 per cent.

Let us face it, even after an increase of 208 per cent, the Prime Minister has not budged from his job. At least Dr Hewson is saying before the event that, if the rate increases, he will quit; he will resign as Prime Minister. Equally, of course, there will be a contrast drawn in respect of Labor's reliance on income tax bracket creep to raise the effective rates on average incomes. Had taxation been subject to some honesty and indexed, the marginal rate of 38 per cent that today applies to average weekly earnings would be below 30 per cent. This is not the case, as we well know. Australians will be subject to another Labor lie that the reductions in personal income tax to be provided by the coalition will help mainly the rich.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who gets the biggest percentage increase? People on $70,000 a year.

—I am glad that Senator McMullan mentioned it. He took the bait. Someone on $7,000 a year gets a 100 per cent tax reduction whereas someone on $100,000 a year gets a 16 per cent tax reduction. Of course the dollar terms will be bigger because one pays more tax when one is earning $100,000. But Senator McMullan cannot understand that. Maybe Senator Brownhill, who follows me, could take the time to educate poor old Senator McMullan because he does not understand that people who earn $100,000 pay a lot more tax than those who earn $7,000. Therefore, when one gives them a 100 per cent reduction at $7,000 and one gives them 16 per cent at $100,000 the dollar terms will be different. I will lend Senator McMullan these Fightback! documents overnight for him to read. Senator Button has reached page 342 and Senator Gareth Evans has reached page 247. Senator McMullan can read nearly 600 pages tonight, if he wants to, because they are on offer.

PARA.TAB: Australians will learn all about this. In dollar terms, it is very different. However, it is a fact that the coalition reform of tax scales will mean that in 1994 a person on an income of $20,000 will pay $814 less in taxation, a reduction of 28 per cent—Senator McMullan does not understand all that because he just says that one will be paying less from here to here—while the $5,305 cut for an income of $100,000 amounts to a reduction of less than 14 per cent. Twist and weave as it might, Labor will be caught out.

Labor cannot change the fact that the coalition will ensure that 95 per cent of taxpayers will pay no more than 30 per cent of income tax when over half of these taxpayers today are paying tax at 38 per cent or 47 per cent. Let us forget the Labor lie. Tax reform is targeted towards lower incomes, with the $1,600 rise in the threshold ensuring that another 320,000 low income earners will pay no tax at all. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In essence, the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991 is outdated. The Government is legislating to give effect to measures that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made in March this year. A day is a long time in politics. March is a long time ago. Since March the Prime Minister has progressively, as Senator Knowles has so ably said, lost his grip on his job. I compliment Senator Knowles on her speech. I think she has covered just about every part of the Bill, plus most of the goods and services tax which is the Opposition's tax reform package, in her speech. She has done it in a most able manner.

PARA.TAB: The 12 March statement was another in a long line of rethinks on the direction in which the Labor Government thought this country should be going. There have been 18 major economic statements in eight years by the Hawke Labor Government, but it has still not got the direction right. That is the big concern of all people in the Australian community at the moment. The Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) claimed in his second reading speech on this Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: These measures demonstrate the Government's commitment to reduce the costs incurred by Australia's goods producing sectors.

As I said, these measures were proposed in March. Since then, bankruptcies for the September quarter were up 72 per cent on last year. Last year was a record year for business failures. That is an indictment of the Hawke Labor Government.

PARA.TAB: This legislation is all about reducing the costs for producers, but the Government has elsewhere shackled industry with a one per cent training levy. Sales tax is the great, silent thief. This Government just loves it. This tax has crept up over the years in a most insidious way on all people in the community. Together with fuel excise, it is the big earner for the Government. The marvellous thing about it is that no-one really knows it is being levied; it has just crept up. Any Australian that we ask will say that he or she does not have a clue what goods sales tax is applied to and how it applies.

This year the coalition has highlighted the appalling mishmash of taxes which we have in this country. One thing that really stood out—we have made the public realise this—was just how iniquitous sales tax is in this country. For example, while we tax toothpaste at something like 20 per cent, we do not tax caviar; while we tax sleeping bags, we do not tax imported suits. The system is archaic, unbalanced and unfair. A wholesale sales tax, which we are debating here, is inappropriate and outmoded. Honourable senators will remember that in 1985, Mr Keating—one of the Government's ex-Treasurers—condemned the wholesale sales tax as anomaly-ridden. There has been little improvement in the wholesale sales tax system since.

One of the worst features of the wholesale sales tax is the negative impact on exports for people in the farming areas, the people who produce our export incomes. It has been estimated that over $1 billion has been added to the cost of Australian exports as a result of the wholesale sales tax of the Hawke Labor Government. There is not such a burden imposed on our trading partners. That is where the problem lies. It makes Australian exports less competitive, a fact which was acknowledged by Mr Keating only recently.

Under the existing wholesale sales tax system, some sectors of the economy suffer more than others. The transport and equipment sector is particularly hard-hit by sales taxes. People have not screamed about the sales taxes because of ignorance. The Government is not about to inform the public, because sales taxes have become a very handsome profit earner for the Government. Sales tax collections amount to nearly $10 billion this year. In 1983, sales tax earned about $3.8 billion. The Hawke Labor Government has turned sales tax into a tidy little earner.

I wish to make a couple of points about the comments Senator Walsh made earlier. He said that things would be worse under a coalition government. Let us look at what happened under the Hawke-Keating Labor Government. In 1984, the balance of payments on the current account was some $7 billion in deficit; this year it is approximately $16 billion in deficit. In 1984, Australian people were paying $35 billion to the Hawke Labor Government in income tax revenue; this year it is estimated that taxpayers will be paying about $67 billion.

As I have already mentioned, sales tax has gone from about $4 billion to nearly $10 billion this year. When the Hawke Labor Government came to power, our foreign debt—we have all talked about this a lot in this place—was $51 billion; this year it is $124 billion. Many other things have happened, too. This year farming sector costs have doubled and income has halved—it is less than half in many places. The rural sector has been absolutely crippled by the Hawke-Keating Labor Government and the Hawke-Kerin Labor Government, and it will be crippled under the Hawke-Willis Labor Government.

The Government has acknowledged the inequity of the sales tax system. It has known for some time of the inconsistency of the schedules in the wholesale sales tax system. It has amended them several times but, as we have seen, a lot of inequities still remain. Despite the Government's 18 economic statements in eight years, it has still not been able to bring about direction for its tax regime.

This is the twenty-ninth sales tax Act passed through the Parliament since 1930, when wholesale taxes were first introduced into Australian law. It started, incidentally, at 2.5 per cent. Since then it has steadily been tampered with in one way or another. Twenty-eight amendments and two volumes of regulations later, it is still imperfect and the Government still has not got it right—like a lot of other things that this Hawke-Keating, Hawke-Kerin, Hawke-Willis Labor Government has not got right. It is yet to overcome its ad hoc knee-jerk approach to legislation and to government.

The coalition has an alternative. We have been able to present a blueprint for Australia. No longer will we have a multi-tiered discriminatory approach to taxation—an approach that has been so inconsistent and administered by stealth. We have said that we will have an up-front 15 per cent tax that is not discriminating, is equitable and applied across the board, and is not anti-business. We have had, as Senator Knowles said, a commitment by Dr Hewson and Mr Fischer that the goods and services tax will not rise above 15 per cent. They gave a firm commitment that they would resign from parliament rather than let it rise above 15 per cent.

The wholesale sales taxes we have now are borne by the 75,000 businesses that pay such taxes. Accountants estimate that business spends some $50m a year on accountancy fees just trying to get goods that have been produced subject to wholesale sales tax properly classified and to deal with the administration of the tax. At the moment they spend approximately another $50m on lawyers fees and another $400m employing people in business to administer the wholesale sales taxes. That is a total of about $500m. In my book, it is anti-business.

This legislation, like the entire wholesale sales tax system, militates against export producing industries. It adds to the price of our exports, and by doing so it reduces our ability to be competitive. That is evident when one looks at the latest national account figures. We can see how desperately unproductive we have become when gross farm product slumps a massive 16.1 per cent.

The Australian economy has shrunk by about $12.5 billion since the June quarter last year. Financial analysts suggest that, despite what the wishful thinkers on the other side of the chamber think, we are in a deeper recession than in 1982 and the equal of what we were in during the 1930s. Against that background what do we have? We had a sacking the other day of the messenger but no changes to the message for the Australian people. We have a fiddling at the edges of the wholesale sales tax regime when what we need is a major restructuring of the economy.

The Government has had some eight years to get it right and it has not. I can guarantee that it is unlikely to have even another 18 months. The coalition has a tax reform package which is an answer to Australia and will put incentive and enterprise back into our economy. We have a goods and services tax package which will enable people to get up and have a go, and we have a vision for Australia. The quicker we can run to an election and let the Australian people have a chance to prosper under a coalition government, the better it will be for the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Brownhill's speech has collapsed. I was waiting for another 10 minutes. I am caught just a little bit short. We are not debating the Australian Institute of Health Bill, but the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991. As I have had the pleasure of sitting in the chair during a number of contributions to this debate, it would not really matter what the name of the legislation was and it certainly would not matter what the content of the legislation was. With that kind of freedom from the other side, Mr Deputy President, I may indeed stroll somewhat away from the main theme here.
—You didn't stop anyone else from straying.
—I will be looking for relevance.
—I thought Senator Panizza would say that I was well ruled. I did not stop anyone.
—I stuck to it.

—Well done to Senator Panizza, but if other honourable senators had other things to say—and I believe that Senator Brownhill was just saying that Senator Knowles's contribution canvassed the lot —then I do not really think that I am under too much of a constraint.
—Take a wide latitude.

—I thank Senator Loosley. Though it is a bit sad that honourable senators from the other side did not address themselves to the proposals in this legislation, they somehow or other are going to vote for it in a few minutes, despite having spent most of the night saying what an appalling piece of legislation it is. I do not really think they have thought about it at all. All they know is that there is a goods and services tax package which they think is better. I am not sure whether they do think it is better. They just think about `it' because they have finally got something to think about. That has enabled them to focus on `it' to the exclusion of everything else, which I must say is a bit of a worry.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot and speakers for the Government on this legislation have pointed out that one of the benefits of having a flexible and adjustable wholesale sales tax is that we can actually modify or send very significant signals about the way we adjust the tax according to things that we wish to favour. For example, we can signal the Government's indication and support for goods that are environmentally encouraging or are in sympathy with the new thinking about the environment by reducing the sales tax there. This is an option we do not have with the flat rate of the value added tax of the Opposition, a point those opposite do not wish to talk about. Honourable senators opposite somehow suggest that it is better to have a GST than anything else; they do not argue cogently why the adjustable wholesale sales tax is so bad. I think their arguments mainly consisted of `This was really their idea and we pinched it'. Therefore they lagged it off, which is a bit of a problem. Did they not think it was a good idea when they first had it? If it was, why would they not therefore want to say to the Government, `Well done for at least developing this point.'? But they did not say that.

Having asked for exemptions to or considerable cuts in contributions to production and productivity in this country through exports, through processing, through the contribution of transport costs, and having seen all of these things changed by this Government's legislation, after the Opposition has been howling for them for months—indeed years—the Opposition apparently can find nothing good in the legislation. I find that somewhat of a disappointing argument by the Opposition; it is certainly not convincing.

As I say, I had the pleasure of sitting in the chair and listening to some of the contributions by Opposition senators. I heard Senator Knowles, for example, arguing at length about the regressive nature of the sales tax—the appalling regressivity of the sales tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seemed to be a regressive speech.

—I thank Senator Loosley. I wonder how Senator Knowles could possibly oppose a sales tax on the grounds of regressivity when her own goods and services tax will do exactly the same, only far more so—not $10 billion but $27 billion worth of tax hitting in the most regressive way.

PARA.TAB: I cannot understand how Senator Knowles finds small regressivity to be an odium but massive regressivity to be something to be skipped over. I think she said, `Well, it will be sort of covered up by all those things that you give back, such as doubling the family allowance, tax cuts and all those sorts of things'. But Senator Knowles's arguments were particularly difficult to sustain. If she ever read her speech I think she would be a bit shocked to find that she was arguing against the limited regressivity of wholesale sales tax and for the massive regressivity of her own Party's tax. An earlier contribution by Senator Short seemed to suggest that there would be no inflation under this consumption tax proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —A one-off affair.

—Well, now we have a difference. Senator Short says that there is no inflation and Senator Watson has just contributed a one-off. They do not even know, between the two of them, whether or not there will be inflation. Senator Short actually defines inflation as the rise going on again and again. I do not know then, by definition, whether Senator Watson's one-off could possibly conform to the definition of inflation. All we know is that it will put the prices up. Whacko! You tell us! Even the Opposition's paper says that it will be somewhere between 4.4 per cent and 4.7 per cent, and there does not seem to be agreement on that, either.

PARA.TAB: Some of those opposite understand that an area of concern and interest of mine is health. I have been particularly interested—unlike Senator Knowles's claim in this matter—to read the Opposition's health policy in great detail. Indeed, I could wave it about before a television camera if one were here and everyone would see how closely underlined my copy is. One of the things which the Opposition's health policy does, but does not tell anyone about, is whack on costs. It puts up inflation and it will only stay up. There is no one-off with the Opposition's health policy. It is built in to stay.

Australians will pay more for their health; the nation will pay more for its health. The Opposition is whacking on inflation, conservatively estimated at 0.7 per cent. What a modest little sum. Other people are inclined to a little less modesty; they will be going for the whole one per cent and there it will be, for ever and a day. They are the bits of inflation that those opposite have not come clean about. They are the bits of inflation that they do not want to tell us about. They are the bits of inflation that will add to the push for increases in wages, and to the whole equation falling apart because those opposite have not factored it in. They do not want to know about inflation into the future, but it is there. It is there in just these 30 pages of the Opposition's supplementary paper No. 3 on health. It is in there for anyone to see. I have given a very conservative estimate of the inflationary effect of it.

The other lovely things in this document under health are amazing. The Opposition plans to give $200 towards the cost of private health insurance to people earning $20,000. That little trick will cost them another $600 because at the lower level the package comes in at $800 and that does not buy the supplementaries. To sucker people into spending $800, the Opposition will give them a $200 seduce fee.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the rest of the incentives? Tell the truth for a change.

—Most Australians can tell the difference between $200 and $800. They also know what happens if they buy health insurance. Is it not interesting? The truth of the matter really troubles those opposite. They say there will be no inflationary effect; maybe there will be an inflationary effect; by definition it is non-inflationary; it is a one-off; it is a one-up. Nonsense! Rubbish! Ridiculous! Of course the introduction of a 15 per cent goods and services tax is inflationary; of course it will be a one-off major hiccup; and of course it will go on into the future in all sorts of bits and pieces of the package. I am only citing health. Not only will it add to inflation, but also it will add to costs. As those opposite know, we have added a co-payment for people who are bulkbilled but not card holders.
—You were opposed to it.

—Indeed, I was. Senator Alston knows that full well. He just beat me to saying it. My view is quite clear on that and I put it on the record. I stood up here and opposed it. It is Government policy and I will support it. I have no trouble with that and it is all on the record. But Senator Alston and others opposite want to hit people for $6.50 as a minimum. Australians are not silly. They understand the difference between $2.50, even $3.50, and $6.50. They all conclude that $6.50 is more. They do not want to pay that if they have a choice. They do not want to be denied bulkbilling. They do not want the inflationary effect of putting up the price every time they see a doctor. That is inflationary per se, and it is inflationary to buy private health insurance.
—No, you reduce your usage.

—If Senator Alston wants to say it is not, I cannot help it. Invincible ignorance reigns supreme on the Opposition benches again. Yes, it is inflationary and any facts will tell Senator Alston that it is inflationary, and it will be inflationary into the future. But the most inflationary thing about it altogether is that it allows doctors an unfettered licence to charge like wounded bulls. One of the reasons people are getting out of private insurance at the moment—
—Speaking from experience, are you?

—I was about to finish my speech, but I might take the whole half hour as I am enjoying myself. I have a lovely book with some wonderful quotes from Earl Page. Do those opposite remember Earl Page? I do.
—Are you going to read this out in conclusion?

—I thought so. I will not read it yet, I will hold on to it for a little longer. It is an excellent quote. It says that the Opposition has discovered nothing. Its policy at the moment would do Earl Page proud. `Thundering backward to the fifties', is what I could call the health policy of those opposite. It is inflationary; increases the costs to individuals and the costs to the nation; there is no cap on the costs of doctors' fees; and it does not address quality of service at all. It does none of the things that this Government has put in place and is in the process of elaborating on. There is also no restructuring of general practice in the policy of those opposite. The policy of this Government is doing that right now.
—What a way to do it—one million unemployed. What a price to pay.

—Senator Alston has terrible trouble with the inflationary contribution of the Opposition's health policy. He should know that it is inflationary because the inflationary effects of the Opposition's health policy will affect everything else that its economy covers. That is the effect that he does not know about. Health is not confined only to the cost of procuring health services. The inflationary effect of health is not confined only to when a person needs a surgical procedure, curative medicine, or anything like that, which can be bought by going to the doctor; the inflationary effect of health spreads its grip much wider.

PARA.TAB: Senator Knowles in her glorious contribution fell about at the notion that inflation did not matter. I would love to refer Opposition senators to their own speeches. They said that this Government was condemned for fixing everything else, but that inflation was too high. Now we have got inflation down and, whoopee-de, those opposite are not impressed. We do not govern to impress the Opposition because we could be here for a long time, but inflation is significant. I think secretly, in his heart, Senator Alston knows that inflation is a very important part of economic management. I think it is regrettable that he does not always say it. It is also regrettable that he has bought a terrible pup with the Opposition's health policy.

I cannot turn all the pages, that would take too long, but there is a lovely line that says, `The AMA shall negotiate with the private insurance companies'. No doubt the rule says, `The Government will pay, but the AMA will negotiate with the private insurance companies'. There is a bold and challenging line.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is like the ACTU.

—Dear, oh dear. What a terrible tragedy. The gains that have been made in this country have been undone by the `thundering backwards to the fifties' health policy of the Opposition without any other concerns, such as denying people access. The Opposition's definition of choice might be another entertaining one. Its health policy illustrates its definition of choice, `If you don't we'll whack you for an extra 800 bucks above $50,000'. That does not seem to me quite everybody's idea of choice.
—Senator Alston says it sounds reasonable.
—Is that right? An amount of $16 a week out of their preferred tax savings. My goodness me, $800 a week—
—A year.

—It is $800 a year. I do beg your pardon. It is $800 a year and $16 a week, I think. I have trouble because the Opposition said that it is proposing to give people considerable tax cuts, but health expenditure is very large.
—Senator Watson is quite right: I can account for only $16 or so out of the tax concession for a family on an income of $50,000. That is a lot of money.
—Are you going to say something about sales tax?
—Yes, I am. I am shocked at the insufficiency of Opposition members: they are not amused; they do not seem to have a sense of humour at all.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Order! Let us try to be reasonable about this. There is a fair degree of interjection across the chamber, and I think that is a healthy thing. Provided the speaker is not interrupted and provided false points of order are not made, we can continue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will continue and move towards a conclusion. The reason that I cite these quotes from Earle Page is that they do illustrate exactly the philosophy on which the Opposition's health policy is based. It is that core philosophy that ought to scare Australians into a great cold fright. I do not think it would matter too much if the Opposition's policy came out as a zero sum gain. I want to say to every Australian that the policy that has been proposed by the Opposition is underpinned by an individualistic notion of the cause of ill health. It is based on the individual as central.

PARA.TAB: Senator Walters, one of the genuine heroes opposite, said in her speech that what people in this country want is the right to keep their tax dollars, to keep their money, not to pay tax, because they know better than anyone else what to do with it. I am still wondering—I would like to have had the chance to ask Senator Walters—how she intended to fund the roads, how she intended to fund the schools and how she intended to fund her health policy when so much of this health policy is funded from the public purse, from the very tax dollars that she does not want to pay. Does she seriously mean that we should have no taxes in this country? Is the argument that we should reduce the wholesale sales tax; we should do away with the taxes? That is what Senator Walters was arguing, which seems to be a little in contradiction with the 15 per cent goods and services tax. I have some trouble with that speech from the Opposition.
I would like to quote Earle Page, but I am not sure I can get to him until three pages after where I am at the moment, so I will resist that and quote a footnote in the book:

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition's health policies of 1949 were a confused attempt to extricate the Commonwealth government from the impasse of the previous five years. They were presented as part of a wider project to free the people from the restraints of socialism—relying on individual initiative and the market—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I know that the Government would like to finish this Bill tonight and I think it would be good, on a point of relevance, to bring Senator Crowley back to what we are actually debating, which is the sales tax Bill.

—Order! There is no point of order. Senator Crowley is perhaps skirting the point; nonetheless, she is on it. She is entitled to make a speech in the fashion in which she chooses, unless she is way off the point.
—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I am in the process of concluding. The footnote continues:

SPEECH.PARA: They were presented as part of a wider project to free—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is for Thursday, Rosemary. You have the wrong speech.
—This is the speech whenever I am talking to an Opposition senator in this place. This is the core of it. The footnote continues:

SPEECH.PARA: They were presented as part of a wider project to free the people from the restraints of socialism—relying on individual initiative and the market—rather than the dead hand of bureaucracy.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Brownhill

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Standing order 194, `Relevance and Participation', says:

INTERJECT.PARA: (1)A Senator shall not digress from the subject matter of any question under discussion, or anticipate the discussion of any subject which appears on the Notice Paper.
I think Senator Crowley is anticipating a lot and not really sticking to the subject matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —She is concluding.
—I congratulate her on that, but she has been concluding for a fair while.

—Thank you, Senator Collins, but I have been capable of doing this myself thus far. Senator Brownhill, standing order 184 requires the President, or obviously whoever is in the chair, to maintain some sort of order. I have not been in the chair throughout this whole debate, but I have been listening. I note that every other speaker has been allowed an extraordinary degree of leniency. It is not appropriate at this stage of the evening simply to require that later speakers speak directly to the Bill in a fashion that earlier speakers have neither chosen nor been required to do. If Senator Crowley continues to make her speech and relate it as closely to the Bill as she can, as she has been doing, in my view she will be in order.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. As the Opposition is determined not to allow me to finish the quote, I will have to paraphrase it. We are dealing with measures—and I am happy to talk about this—which demonstrate this Government's commitment to reducing the costs incurred by the Australian goods producing sectors.

PARA.TAB: As I said at the beginning of my speech, I find it quite shocking that in a few minutes the Opposition will vote for its namby-pamby amendment and then vote for the legislation. Opposition senators have stood up in this place and argued that what has been proposed is exactly what we should do and that the Government has pinched Opposition policy. Is the Opposition for it or against it? The Opposition does not seem to be clear. Does it want to support a Bill that removes some of the imposts on productivity and the production of goods in this country or not? If it does not, it should say so and vote against it. Opposition senators should not come in here and spend all of their time taking points of order. Madam Acting Deputy President, I am shocked at Senator Brownhill calling that irrelevant point of order on me when he and everybody else rambled across everything in justification of the GST.

The point that I was addressing in terms of the health policy was that a member of the Opposition said in the course of this debate—and I remind Senator Brownhill that it is a debate—that inflation was not a very important matter. I think it is a very important matter. The Opposition has a health policy that is going to whack costs through the roof. The Opposition is going to do that because it still believes in the philosophy that underpinned Earle Page's thinking. It has not changed in 50 years; it was the same before the war. The Opposition has actually written a health policy and a goods and services tax policy.

The Opposition does not understand the subtlety of this legislation nor the Government's taxing policy. It has no understanding of these things; it does not appreciate them at all. Yet, having said all of that, the Opposition is about to vote for this legislation. I find that the Opposition's position is much more fraught than ours. If Senator Alston interjects, he will be out of order.

I will conclude on this point: it is unusual to conduct a debate properly in this place unless we are dealing with something like an MPI. This is usually because honourable senators come in, make their contribution and leave. As I say, I have had to listen to the absolute drivel—my father would have called it `unmitigated piffle'—that passed for the contribution of the Opposition. So, having sat here, listened and taken some notes, I thought I should make my contribution by way of refutation of the stupid points raised by members of the Opposition in their contribution to the debate on this piece of legislation. I will be very happy to vote for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an interesting debate to sum up. We have had put forward outlines of parts of the competing economic strategies that will be important in the debate next year and until the next election. We have started to see unfold the elements of the debates around those competing packages. They are to some extent reflected in the Sales Tax Amendment Bill (No. 3) and the Opposition's second reading amendment.

PARA.TAB: I want to make some preliminary comments about the broad parameters of the debate and respond to some of the points raised by honourable senators who made serious contributions to the debate. I may not be able to deal with all of them without taking undue time. I will try to deal as comprehensively as I can with the major questions that were raised and then come back to some of the other comments that were made in the debate.

With regard to the generalised question of the competing strategies reflected in the Opposition's second reading amendment, I have to say that the Government obviously rejects the view that we should be replacing the wholesale sales tax with the consumption tax, as outlined in the Opposition's package. There is a whole complex array of reasons. But broadly, it is, first of all, not fair because of the impact it has on necessities as against luxuries—that is, it makes necessities more expensive and luxuries cheaper. It does away with the necessary capacity for government to discriminate between necessities and luxuries.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why you have a 30 per cent sales tax on school exercise books.

—Thirty per cent? It does away with the necessity for government to discriminate between environmentally sensitive and environmentally damaging products; to distinguish between those things which are common household items and those things which are luxuries; those things which are to be exempted, and those things which are to be taxed at 30 per cent and the intervening rates. I will return to the misleading argument about simplicity a little later.

PARA.TAB: Senator Knowles made only one point to which I will take any time to refer. She correctly outlined the fact that indirect taxes fall disproportionately on the poor. That is correct. She quoted some statistics as they relate to the wholesale sales tax. They are not statistics I am directly familiar with, but I think the general thrust of what she said about them is correct, as it is in relation to all indirect taxes.

It is for that reason that over the next 12 to 18 months we will be debating these competing approaches—one reflected in this Bill, which is about reducing indirect tax, and one looking at the alternative strategy, which is about increasing indirect tax. It is correct to say that indirect taxes fall disproportionately on the poor; that is why we are proposing not to make the massive increases that are being proposed by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our GST doesn't either.

—It certainly does. It may be that the honourable senator opposite could argue that the package does not—I do not actually share that view—but he cannot argue that the GST does not. It quite clearly does.

PARA.TAB: I will now respond to some of the points raised in the debate, particularly by Senator Watson—although Senators Panizza and Crane raised some other points to which I will try to give some attention without taking up too much time.

Senator Watson raised the main use test—the more than 50 per cent test—and whether this will cause a lot of disputes. Whatever form of tax we have, including a GST, we will need to separate, measure and distinguish private from business use. There is no mechanism by which we can avoid that while trying to tax those two things differently. All in-direct taxes of which I am aware do make such a distinction. GST as proposed does and the wholesale sales tax does, and that leads to definitions and debates about how those definitions apply. That is inevitable.

Senator Watson raised a specific question concerning port equipment and whether lubricants for that equipment are covered. They are. In our view, paragraph (d) of the ancillary activity definition makes it clear that lubricants for port equipment are covered.

There was a concern expressed about problems that might be created for the vendor, who has to know what the purchaser will use a particular good for. The Bill, as I recall it and as I am advised, does not of itself change any of the responsibilities of suppliers. Senator Watson then went on to raise a concern about draft No. 4, which has not yet been issued. I am advised that it will be issued before Christmas.
Senator Watson suggested that the exemption does not extend to cover I think he said `software creation goods', or words to that effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —In computer installations where they have multiple uses.

—There is a slightly different point about multiple uses. But it is our understanding that when we get into multiple uses of things, as with the private business use, there may be demarcation arguments over definitions concerning any tax. But any software used in relation to carrying out eligible production processes is exempt under the R&D exemption. That is quite clear and that is set out in the Bill.

PARA.TAB: In responding to another query about the role of the IR&D Board, I want to make it clear that I think there is a bit of a misunderstanding on Senator Watson's part. The `or' is put in there instead of the `and' quite deliberately—I am being a bit cryptic, but I know that Senator Watson knows to what I refer—because the Bill is designed specifically to allow certain R&D entities access to the exemption, even if those entities are not goods producers. That is why it says `or' rather than `and'. I think that covers Senator Watson's major questions. If there are some others, we may come to them later, but they are the ones which I think went specifically to the contents of the Bill, rather than to expressions of view and opinion.

Senator Kernot raised a concern about the design and installation of energy efficient measures for goods producers, and she asked whether that will be covered. It will be exempt where it is involved with making the production process more energy efficient. She also raised the concern about the impact of the exemption for all office equipment inputs to a goods producer—meaning that the distinction between recycled paper and other paper would disappear. It is true that, for some uses, that will be the case. But I do not think it is appropriate that we should undermine the basic purpose of making business inputs exempt in order to make a marginal extension to the proper and appropriate exemption that does apply to recycled paper. I indicate that it clearly will not affect the preferential prices of the recycled paper which is used by the service sector. So there will still be a substantial benefit to those people who are producing and distributing recycled products, as there should be.

Senator Panizza raised a question about telecommunications equipment. When I first read the Bill this point struck me; it looked unusual. But when one reads it in detail one finds that it is in fact very narrow and specific. All we are excluding in this legislation are goods that are part of the major infrastructure of a communications network, such as satellites or telephone exchanges. Things such as telephones and handsets will be exempt; the legislation applies only if one has a telephone exchange or a major piece of satellite equipment within one's operation. That is what is excluded: parts of the network as a whole which are not part of one's personal or business use. I had the same impression when I read the Bill for the first time, but, upon careful reading, I think the honourable senator will find that it applies to that narrow situation.

Senator Crane asked me whether ruling 3005 of March will be altered. The answer is yes, it will be updated to add the new exemptions to its scope. That was Senator Crane's principal concern. I have to some extent skipped over a number of points, but I think I have covered everything that relates to concern about the meaning of clauses in the Bill.

A number of speakers expressed concern about the size of the explanatory memorandum in relation to the size of the Bill. There is a fundamental misunderstanding about that. It is very desirable that we have comprehensive explanatory memorandums. Many users in industry and the professions have commended this explanatory memorandum, which they find particularly useful. I think that goes to the specifics of the matters raised.

I now come back to make some concluding remarks about the nature of the wholesale sales tax, the amendment which relates to the goods and services tax and the concern that has been expressed that, somehow or other, the goods and services tax will be much simpler and will eliminate cascading. I wish to quote from the Price Waterhouse document entitled Fightback analysed. It is not a Labor Party document; it is published by the tax section of Price Waterhouse. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Exemptions in particular can cause major distortions in the industries in which they apply and in other business sectors dealing with those industries. . . the major problem is `cascading'.
It goes on to talk about the operation of the wholesale sales tax and the distortions that it causes. It continues:

They will not go away with the passing of the WST. The Coalition's GST proposal is far from a distortion free tax. Nor will it be without its quota of administrative complications and definitional issues.
The document says that the GST will be:
. . . just as much a source of complexity, dispute and litigation as any other form of taxation.
