In New Zealand, which has a simpler system than the one proposed by the Opposition, there have already been 100 goods and services tax cases before the courts, which is as many as there have been in Australia about the wholesale sales tax in 60 years. To argue that it will simplify and take the complexity out of the system is to delude oneself.

PARA.TAB: As soon as questions of definition, exemptions, zero rating and distinctions are introduced, problems of definition and complexity are introduced. Price Waterhouse states:

SPEECH.PARA: Complexity and dispute will also be unavoidable. Anomalies also will be unavoidable.

There are a lot of examples, but I have time to refer to only a few. When does a service provided by a hospital cease to be a health care service? At what stage does a service or other supply by a school cease to be educational? How do we deal with goods supplied by State government authorities and enterprises which may be sheltered from GST, irrespective of whether the supply would lead to significant distortions of competition? What will be the treatment of financial services that are supplied incidental to another business? At what point does an exempt financial service become a secondary financial service? How do we deal with different timing rules which may apply depending on the nature of the leasing arrangement?

PARA.TAB: Of course, there will be a need to distinguish between materials used in building construction and those used in other construction. That is where we get this question of cascading. People say, `No, there can't be cascading'. Senator Bishop said that there cannot be cascading under this goods and services tax. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Financial services and building construction are major inputs in all sectors of the economy. The exemption of the supplies must result in considerable `cascading'.

For example, the report states that in the tourism industry `as building construction is exempt, tourist industry operators will be unable to obtain input credits on these supplies'. Price Waterhouse goes on to say, quite correctly, that the tourism industry `will be subject to double taxation'. For all those reasons the arguments that have been put forward about cascading are entirely wrong, as are the ones about the greater simplicity and administrative ease for business. I will quote Price Waterhouse again:
A major problem will be determining the GST credit where supplies are used for both business and private or exempt purposes.
It says that it will spawn `the most complex rules and regulations' and:
Significant changes will need to be made to many accounting systems. . . it will be necessary to segregate and/or account for the following:

taxable sales, tax exempt sales, zero rated sales, tax collected on taxable sales, taxed purchases, tax exempt purchases, untaxed purchases, imports at duty/tax paid value. . . input taxes, taxes to be remitted to/secured from the Taxation Office.

I wanted to go on to a number of other points but I will mention only one more in the time available. People spoke of the wonderful benefits to small business because of the cash flow. Price Waterhouse point out, quite accurately, that the proposed GST will in some way affect the cash flow results of virtually every transaction in the economy. The report states:
Some companies may need to borrow to meet increased working capital commitments. Others will enjoy a significant cash flow advantage.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the correct term.

—I do not deny that some will have an advantage and that some will lose, but let us not have people coming in here quoting nonsense when they pretend to understand what they do not understand and say—
—We have not said that.

—Not Senator Watson, who does understand, but Senator Bishop came in here and talked of the wonderful benefits for cash flow to business without understanding that an equal number of businesses will be worse off. Because of the nature of their business, their cash flow requirements will be greater, and they will have to increase their borrowings. The last point I want to quote is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Much of the cost of this additional saving to business will ultimately be borne by final consumers.
This is the sort of document that needs to be read by everybody who wants to participate intelligently in this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do they agree with it or not?
—Price Waterhouse is not trying to come to a conclusion. The document says some things I disagree—
—Do they agree with it or not?
—It does not conclude on that.
—They do.
—Price Waterhouse may have said elsewhere that it agrees, but this document as I read it says `This is just a service to our businesses'.
—All qualified accountants agree with it.
—All accountants like it because it is a bonanza for accountants. They will make a fortune. No wonder they all like it. Senator Macdonald knows it is a bonanza for accountants.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, all I want to say is that the debate around this Bill has highlighted the first stage of a debate about competing strategies; about whether we will increase or reduce indirect taxes, the mechanism for funding government services as a means of making Australia fairer or less fair; about whether we will provide, through this Bill, assistance to industry in a manner that reduces the level of indirect taxes rather than try to do so in a way that increases indirect taxes, because that makes Australia less fair and other elements lead to the economy being less buoyant for the reasons outlined so effectively by Senator Walsh. I obviously oppose the amendment and support the Bill.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Short's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McMullan is one of the few representatives on the Government side prepared to provide this Senate with detailed explanations in answer to queries from the Opposition. However, I would like to take this opportunity to briefly mention that some of the comments made by Senator McMullan in quoting from the Price Waterhouse report apply with some relevance to sales tax law. I suppose it is the degree of weighting that one likes to put on those comments.

PARA.TAB: Whenever there is a distinction to be drawn between private or business, which we have in sales tax law and income tax law, there is a problem. We have this problem in sales tax tonight with the creation of this new 50 per cent rule. I thank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) for the undertaking that the Government will release prior to Christmas the sales tax new series No. 4 ruling, which I think will be a great help to industry.

I would like Senator McMullan to respond, maybe in writing because of the shortage of time, as to why the Government has changed the definition of `mainly' from `not less than 50 per cent' to `to the extent of more than 50 per cent'. I believe this has created some confusion. I understand the significance of the words `or' and `and', but I think there is still some concern about the overlapping as a result of this new legislation between the roles of the Commissioner of Taxation and the Industry Research and Development Board. The Parliamentary Secretary might like to take that on notice.

I also ask the Parliamentary Secretary to confirm for us that the term `eligible research and development boards' does extend to software created goods and the substantiation problems that will arise where goods are purchased in the first instance mainly for that purpose but, subsequently, as a result of later developments, lose that particular percentage. The Opposition supports the Sales Tax Law Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1991, which improves the quality of sales tax law, although, as we pointed out during the debate, it falls far short of what is required under our proposed GST legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the cooperation of Senator Watson in trying to speed the passage of the Bill. I undertake to give him a written response to the matters he has raised.

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator McMullan) read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, I was not here last Tuesday evening, 3 December. Senator MacGibbon made three allegations in his speech which are inaccurate. First, he referred to page 209 of the Cooke report and a purported donation which I received from the Queensland AWU; secondly, he alleged that I received that donation because I was running for the Senate at the time; and, thirdly, he alleged that the donation was illegal. Those three allegations are incorrect.

PARA.TAB: If honourable senators read page 209 of the Cooke report they will see that I received a donation from the Queensland Liquor Trades Union, not the Australian Workers Union. That is the first part of the allegation, which was incorrect. Regarding the allegation that the donation was illegal, I declared the donation in accordance with the Federal legislation with respect to the giving of donations. The next allegation made by Senator MacGibbon was that it was given to me because I was running for the Senate. Senator MacGibbon was only four years out. The donation was given to me when I was a candidate for the House of Representatives election in 1987, not in response to the last election.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you did get money from the Queensland Liquor Trades Union.

—Yes, I received a donation from the Queensland branch of the Liquor Trades Union. During the election campaign in 1987, I received numerous donations from a range of unions right across Australia. I do not hide from that, I do not resile from that; in fact, I am proud of my record as a trade union official. I am proud to represent workers in this country and in the State of Tasmania.
—What has Queensland got to do with Tasmania?
—Order! Senator Macdonald will cease interjecting.

—I am pleased that a number of trade unions saw fit to donate to my campaign. I reject the sorts of innuendo that some people opposite cast that there is something wrong with receiving donations from trade unions. There is nothing wrong with receiving donations from trade unions, any more than there is anything wrong with receiving donations from business. During that campaign in 1987 I received a range of donations from business people as well. I do not have any particular problem with receiving donations from unions.

PARA.TAB: The essential point is that Senator MacGibbon was wrong on three crucial points. After reading page 209 of the report of the Cooke inquiry, I do not see how Senator MacGibbon could make the three mistakes that he did. There are probably two ways we could look at the allegation that Senator MacGibbon made. One can either be a liar or not know how to read a report. They are the two perspectives we can put on Senator MacGibbon's allegation. I will leave the Senate and Senator MacGibbon to judge which one of those two aspects he was acting on when he made the comments about me last Wednesday evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter I wish to raise this evening is in reply to a question that I asked Senator Cook some time ago on the Moora straw based pulp and paper mill. Before I go any further, I wish to say that I advised Senator Cook's office that I would be bringing this matter up this evening. Let no one make an accusation that I brought it up without his knowledge.

PARA.TAB: I refer to a statement tabled by Senator Cook on 14 November which purported to answer the question I had asked on 11 November in relation to the proposed Moora straw based pulp mill project in Western Australia. Gratuitous and snide comments were made by Senator Cook immediately following the tabling of that statement. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . perhaps Senator Panizza ought to have told us whether he is in fact a shareholder in Riverhouse Packaging, one of the shareholder companies in the project.

At that stage I rose on a point of order and objected, attempting to give an explanation, but the President ruled that it was not a point of order because he was not to know whether I was a shareholder or not. I accepted the ruling.

PARA.TAB: I will comment on the second point first. My only knowledge of the company structure associated with the Moora project is from newspaper reports and the statement in the letter of 31 October 1991 from G.T. Bucknall, Secretary of the Printing and Kindred Industries Union, to which was attached a copy of the executive summary of an analysis of the project by Professor John Hicks which had been commissioned by the union. We know who commissioned it but we would like to know who paid for it.

From those sources I understand that the companies involved in the Moora project are the Riverhouse group, the Western Australian Pulp and Paper Co. Pty Ltd and the Moora Pulp and Paper Co. Neither I, nor, to the best of my knowledge, any member of my family or any company that I or my family is involved in, is a shareholder in any one of those companies or otherwise has a financial interest in the project.

As a grain grower, I have an interest in the activities and decisions of the Grains Council of Australia and the Australian Wheat Board. I am not, however, a member of the Grains Council or the Wheat Board and am not in a position to influence the decisions of either of those bodies. From time to time I have offered some public criticism of these bodies in relation to particular matters—whether it be this matter or any other matter.

I did not speak with the Australian Wheat Board about this project before decisions were made by the Australian Wheat Board to invest in the project. My office spoke briefly with a staff member of the AWB following receipt of the letter from the Printing and Kindred Industries Union. As a grain grower and as a person who wants to see Australia maximise its returns from its products, I have an interest in seeing the development of value added projects. I shall return to that point shortly.

The fact is that Senator Cook imputed to me a dishonourable motive simply because I asked a question. He did so without the slightest fact that could even suggest that there were grounds for the position he took. He made a serious accusation without foundation. It could be regarded as an attempt at intimidation to discourage honourable senators from asking legitimate questions. We have, unfortunately, come to expect that kind of snide behaviour from that gentleman sheltering behind the privilege of the Parliament. I ask that he apologise and withdraw his assertion.

I now turn to the statement that Senator Cook tabled on 14 November which purported to answer the question I had asked on 11 November in relation to the proposed Moora straw pulp and paper mill project in Western Australia. His statement completely ignored the context in which I asked the question. He is a person who at times twists his response. My question on 11 November was:

SPEECH.PARA: I refer the Minister to the call by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, to increase value adding opportunities in Australia. In light of this call, I ask the Minister whether he is aware of the actions of the Western Australian branch of the Printing and Kindred Industries Union in trying to wreck the proposed straw pulp and paper mill at Moora in Western Australia before it gets off the ground?

My concern is that projects which add value to Australian produce be encouraged and given every opportunity to prove themselves. Senator Cook may remember that on 10 October the Senate, in its response to a motion moved by me, condemned the Government for its ineptitude in allowing many mining projects around Australia to be either totally stopped or delayed, and also condemned the Government for eight years of lost opportunity on these projects.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook's tabled statement on 14 November in effect rubbished the initiative of trying to establish a viable pulp and paper project based on wheat straw as the basic raw material and, in addition, providing a further recycling opportunity for waste paper. He rubbished this attempt at testing another value added project; a project which, if viable, would add a further source of income to the rural sector, would increase job opportunities in rural Australia and would spread the range of raw material used for manufacturing packaging. It could, if successful, stimulate alternative processes and reduce or at least help contain the present reliance on woodchips—as well as be a way to dispose of straw, rather than burning it.

Whether the project will be economically feasible and worth proceeding with is for those involved as investors and risk takers to determine in the light of advice received and their best judgments based on the analysis of the facts. If those so involved want, in the meantime, to protect a future niche in an expanding market by competing against other companies currently manufacturing packaging material by importing cardboard container products then that is their affair. Once the Moora pulp mill comes on line there will be no need to import.

I understand that about 100 tonnes of boxes are presently being imported each month; that is, 1,200 tonnes per year. This relatively small amount contrasts with the approximately 35,000 tonnes per year produced on the domestic WA market. There are, of course, measures that can be taken to stop the dumping of products if dumping can be proved by those who are alleging that this is occurring in this case.

Senator Cook's shock-horror about the importation of cardboard container products and his blind support of the union's opposition to that is somewhat misplaced. Indeed, I understand that one of the companies presently manufacturing cardboard container products in Western Australia is itself importing pulp from Indonesia. In fact, one firm alone imports seven times more.

I do not know whether Senator Cook has seen the notice printed in the West Australian on 30 October 1991 headed `A Message to the State Government from the employees of Visy Board, O'Connor, W.A.' that had at the bottom `Visy Board Western Australia', together with the logo of the company. The advertisement was run by Visy Board of Western Australia and backed by a petition of more than 100 employees. At this stage I seek leave to have the advertisement incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: A MESSAGE TO THE STATE GOVERNMENT
From the employees of Visy Board, O'Connor, W.A.

PARA.TAB: State Government endorsement of a proposed straw pulp project to be based at Moora, has contributed to the development of a crisis situation for Western Australia's packaging industry.
The promoters of the Moora project—which is still in the planning stage—have for some months been seriously undercutting the local market by importing cardboard container products from Indonesia.
Whereas this may be only a short term practice, the effect has already been to seriously undermine major local packaging manufacturers jeopardising production and employment prospects.
The Government is currently waging a major campaign to promote re-cycling.
But if the import of containers continues they will impact heavily on W.A.'s re-cycling industry—because local manufacturers use more than 90 percent locally recycled paper in their product.

We believe that instead of assisting new industries to import products to compete with those already available in W.A., the State Government should be helping established West Australian industries to survive and to export, to create jobs and to earn much-needed foreign exchange.

If government is genuine about fostering the State's waste re-cycling industry and improving employment, we believe that it must review its support for any practice that may "impair" achievement of these objectives.

SPEECH.PARA: Authorised by ALAN HANCOCK, backed by a petition
by more than 100 employees.
Visy Board Western Australia

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. That notice promotes the possibility of some collusion between that existing operating company and the Printing and Kindred Industries Union to attempt to wreck a potential competitor. That notice must also cast some doubts on the claims that the proposed Moora pulp mill is not as viable as the unions and others are claiming.

PARA.TAB: If Visy Board believes the project is not viable, one would think that it would sit back and laugh, wait for the collapse and then pick up a cheap outfit. It could be that there is an intentional disinformation campaign to hinder the Moora project and make it impossible, or at least very difficult, for the Moora organisation to attract finance and get started.

Senator Cook's response to my question ignored the broader prospect of Australia adding value to its primary products; ignored the possibility of encouraging alternative material for the production of cardboard packaging; ignored the possibility of the longer term development of further employment opportunities; and ignored the possibility of providing employment in and helping stabilise rural communities. He simply rushed in to support a union body without any balancing considerations. It is yet another example of the one-eyed approach he brings to his portfolio to which this Senate has unfortunately become accustomed.

I look forward to Senator Cook coming into this place and withdrawing the accusation that I spoke on this matter because of some shareholding that he thought that I or my family might have had in that project. He had no reason to think that. He never proffered any reason for accusing me of improper conduct in the matter. When challenged by my colleagues on this side of the chamber, he walked out of the Senate like a coward.

TALK.START.PARA: —A mongrel dog. He should apologise.
—Order! Senator Macdonald, you will withdraw that statement.
—I am sorry, which one?
—You know exactly what you said, Senator Macdonald, and I ask you to withdraw it.
—I do not, Mr President, but whatever it was—
—You said that Senator Cook acted like a mongrel dog and I ask you to withdraw it.
—I withdraw that, Mr President. I was going to withdraw whatever you asked me to withdraw, and I do so.

—I would like to take a few minutes of the Senate's time to respond to the attack from Senator Sherry. At the outset, I thank Senator Sherry for the courtesy he extended to me by advising me that he was going to respond to some statements I had made in the past. If an honourable senator is going to make an attack against someone, it conforms with the established traditions of the Senate to advise that person. I must say that I learned of Senator Sherry's speech in Senator Durack's office when one of his staff advised me that Senator Sherry was running off at the mouth.

PARA.TAB: I did not hear all of Senator Sherry's speech and I will probably have to come back tomorrow night to address the parts of the speech that I did not hear. When I came in here, I heard Senator Sherry saying that anyone who did not understand the Cooke report was either a liar or someone who could not read a report. Having been here for nearly 14 years, I think I have established my reputation, and there would not be anyone in the chamber who would accuse me of not being truthful. All I will say is this: I am not a recycled pommy shop steward. I can read reports and, more than that, I can write them.

The charge I laid against Senator Sherry had nothing to do with Senator Sherry personally. All I was drawing attention to was the fact that a notation was made in the Cooke report that the laws of Queensland had been broken at the time, and that is a matter of fact. I also said it was a matter of fact that the socialist Goss Government changed those laws subsequently so that if the same action was taken today it would not be an offence.

My colleagues tell me that Senator Sherry said that I accused the AWU of making the donation to his campaign funds, and that really it was done by the Liquor Trades Union. If I did make that claim, I am quite happy to retract it and say that the Liquor Trades Union did it. However, the burden of my complaint was the way the Labor Party raised funds by standover tactics through the union movement and used it to get candidates elected. It was a technique which is not available to the democratic parties of Australia. On that point, I rest.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 23 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is propylene oxide an additive to technical chlordane; if so, would it be easy to achieve propylene oxide-free chlordane by ceasing to add propylene oxide to chlordane.

(2) Is the answer to Question on Notice No. 871 correct in stating that `Technical chlordane which is free of propylene oxide has been more difficult to achieve because of batch production methods . . . '.

(3) Why has the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council permitted Velsicol to continue to use propylene oxide in chlordane even after the National Health and Medical Research Council rescheduled propylene oxide to Schedule 7.
(4) Please specify the technical difficulties involved in ceasing to add propylene oxide to chlordane.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (4) Propylene oxide has been used as an additive to technical chlordane. Any specific technical difficulties which relate to ceasing to add propylene oxide to technical chlordane are not known. The answer to the Question on Notice No. 871 only referred to difficulties in achieving propylene oxide free technical chlordane because of batch production methods.
(2) The quoted extract from the answer to Question on Notice No. 871 is according to advice provided by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy from information supplied by Velsicol.
(3) The Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council has provided the following information:

`The Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council (AAVCC) has requested Velsicol to remove propylene oxide from technical chlordane in accordance with the National Health and Medical Research Council's recommendation. Velsicol advised the AAVCC on 4 September 1991 that no technical chlordane containing propylene oxide remains in Australia.'

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 11 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: Under new pharmaceutical charging arrangements, is the contraceptive pill no longer eligible for Government subsidy; if so, is this a responsible course of action considering the Government's National Women's Health Policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: On 1 November 1990 the maximum patient co-payment for general patients, under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS), increased from $11 to $15. On 1 August 1991, this increased, due to indexation, to $15.70. When this change occurred, the contraceptive pill, which costs approximately $12.50 per prescription, ceased to receive the approximate $1.50 Government subsidy for general patients.
However, concessional beneficiaries, who pay $2.60 per prescription, still receive the contraceptive pill with a Government subsidy.
There is no inconsistency between this course of action and the National Women's Health Policy.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 11 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will the Bureau of Rural Resources be asked to review its decision, announced on 17 September 1991, not to release, under Section 36 of the Freedom of Information Act, 22 documents relating to Dr Jim Hone's report on the assessment of the risk of transmissible gastroenteritis entering Australian pig herds.

(2) Will the Minister satisfy himself that these 22 documents do not contain relevant information to Australian pig producers, and that the decision-making process of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service is open to a proper degree of public scrutiny.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Minister does not consider it necessary to ask the Bureau of Rural Resources to review its decision on the release of 22 documents under Section 36 of the Freedom of Information Act.

Scientific papers and reports must be subjected to intense scrutiny by the author's scientific peers before they are approved for publication. This refereeing process is designed to ensure that the methodology, results and interpretation are sound, and that the grammar is acceptable, before publication is approved. In this way scientific knowledge builds on previous work which has been judged to be of a high standard and therefore credible. For this process to work, it is important that the referees report candidly on the work of their colleagues. This can only be achieved through this process of anonymous, confidential and very frank and thorough assessments. It is to uphold this principle and process that the Bureau of Rural Resources has decided not to release the 22 documents relating to Dr Jim Hone's report on the assessment of the risk of transmissible gastroenteritis entering Australian pig herds.

The Hone report did not assess the risk of transmissible gastroenteritis entering Australian pig herds. The BRR study by Dr Jim Hone used a mathematical model to evaluate some of the biological and production consequences if transmissible gastroenteritis were to enter and establish in Australia.The report concluded that control or eradication of transmissible gastroenteritis, should it enter Australian piggeries, will require accurate early identification, adequate surveillance of high risk piggeries and proper management of the disease within piggeries, including the control of movement of pigs between piggeries. Research is advocated on likely rates of disease spread between piggeries and the duration of immunity of pigs that have recovered from transmissible gastroenteritis.

(2) The Minister is fully satisfied that the 22 documents do not contain relevant information to Australian pig producers. The decision to import pigmeat from Canada followed intensive discussions between AQIS officers, producers and experts in the areas of pig husbandry and health over a period of more than 7 years. The study of Dr Hone did not provide any information that would cause the government to reverse its decision. I am therefore satisfied that the decision-making process of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service is open to a proper degree of public scrutiny.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 11 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: What material property testing, if any, was carried out before awarding the contract for the purchase of camouflage nets for the Army, pursuant to tender DCO 62-91178N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Extensive testing of Camouflage Nets and Camouflage Net Support Systems (CNSS) was carried out during 1989/90 prior to the award of the contracts. The tests evaluated the tendered equipment against the requirements of Request for Tender (RFT) 62-91178N, including the technical specification Army (Aust) 6583.
Testing was in the form of technical and field trials conducted by the following organisations:
(a) The Surveillance Research Laboratory carried out technical trials of visual, durability and safety (flammability) properties of the nets.

(b) The Materials Research Laboratory, Melbourne, conducted technical trials of flame resistance, visual properties, strength and durability, dimensions, and fungal and environmental resistance of the nets.

(c) The Maintenance Engineering Agency conducted trials with respect to maintenance support through the service life of the nets and CNSS. Trials covered properties such as durability of cover cases and carry bags, requirement to replace worn components, resistance to hazardous environment, safety, cleaning requirements, maintenance manuals and tools, and maintenance training requirements.
(d) The Engineering Development establishment conducted an engineering evaluation of the CNSS, which consisted principally of robustness and environmental tests.

(e) User/performance trials of the nets and CNSS were conducted by the School of Artillery and the units of 1 Brigade (5/7 Royal Artillery Regiment (Mech), 8/12 Medium Regiment, 1 Field Squadron and 2 Cavalry Regiment). These trials were designed to determine whether the tendered supplies were able to carry out their assigned roles in a military environment, evaluated against the RFT requirements. The trials evaluated such factors as robustness and durability, ease of handling and assembly, ease of maintenance, noise, practicality of design, compatibility between camouflage nets and CNSS.
